The Government very much regrets the necessity of moving this motion. I think all honourable members would concede that legislation in this House has been batting along at a pretty reasonable pace. Since the session began there has been a great deal of legislation handled. There have been delays. Those delays have been the product of Government and Opposition party committees, in some instances wanting, as is their right, a closer look at legislation. It has also been the product of the fact that we had two weeks out earlier in the year for the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference. Even though we have caught up in terms of numbers of weeks for what we have usually had at this point, nevertheless, that denied us the opportunity to add additional weeks in this period of the year.

I think honourable members ought to be aware that to some considerable degree these days the Senate controls the business in this House. That is a product of the fact that the Senate is putting a deadline on legislation that it is prepared to consider from the House of Representatives in the course of this year. Honourable members may or may not be aware that the Senate in fact intends to activate that at the end of the first week of the next two-week block of sittings. That will put further pressure on us. It will probably oblige me to move another of these motions in the not too distant future. I agree that it is pretty unsatisfactory that we have to do business this way, but in the exigencies of the situation it is virtually essential.

There is an alternative, and that is to sit for a substantial portion of December. It is not my view that that is a sensible alternative because my experience as a member of parliament tells me that December for members of both sides of the House is an important constituency month. Most members appreciate the opportunity to be with their constituents for what are usually the wind-up functions for the plethora of organisations that members work very hard for and work very hard to keep in contact with. All these factors have come together to produce the situation in which we find ourselves. The only matter which we need to increasingly think about in this place is the impact of the way in which the Senate conducts business on the way in which we have to conduct business in this House. That is a matter of interest to both sides of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) made out the Opposition's case very well. He said that it is an unsatisfactory way of doing business. I have said on previous occasions that as the Commonwealth assumes more responsibilities and as the population grows, it will be necessary for this Parliament to sit for longer periods.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the sitting pattern for next year, already the Government has given an indication that the House will be sitting for a fewer number of days in the autumn sessional period than in the current sessional period. Indeed, the start is scheduled for late February. The Minister has indicated that he believes it undesirable for the House to sit during December. What he did not point out to the House and to the public is that not only will we not sit in December; the House will also not sit in January or for most of February.

It is now only 9 November and it is shameful that, at this stage in the sitting period, the Government should be bringing in the guillotine. For the benefit of the public and others who may read this debate, the guillotine means that the Government is limiting debate, and it is limiting debate on a whole range of issues. I will not read out all of the Bills on the Notice Paper in respect of which debating time will be limited, but I will refer to some of them.

The first-the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill-is of tremendous importance because it addresses the financial arrangements for road construction and maintenance throughout the Commonwealth. The Government has neglected road construction and maintenance; it has a poor record in this particular area. So what does it do? It limits debate and reduces the opportunity for members on both sides of the House, I suspect, to be able to direct to the attention of the public the problems in this area and the parlous record of the Government.

Another Bill which must be of interest to all families is the Child Support Amendment Bill, and then there is a package of rural legislation. Debate on all of this legislation is to be truncated today to meet the convenience of the Government. I also direct attention to a package of Bills concerning new arrangements for broadcasting. As will be pointed out by the Opposition during the debate on the Bills, the provisions contained in this package will have far-reaching consequences on the broadcasting industry, yet the Government will truncate debate.

Right at the end of the day we come to a package of taxation Bills-the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill, the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2). Of course, contained in one of those Bills is the Government's decision to break yet another promise and to introduce a gold tax, but because of its embarrassment in this particular area it will truncate debate on the issue.

On a number of occasions I have directed attention to the fact that the Government has the worst record of any government since Federation in terms of reducing time for private members to air their grievances and to ask questions. By reducing the number of sitting days, not only is the Government ensuring that there is inadequate time to consider important Bills coming before the House; it is also again reducing the number of Question Times.

I have pointed out in other debates that not only are Ministers taking longer to answer questions but also they are reducing the number of days available in which to ask questions. I say to the Minister, in all sincerity, that he would have been doing Australia a better service by extending the period of sitting rather than by bringing in the guillotine to reduce debate on these important issues.

Also, I invite him to reconsider the sitting pattern for next year. Instead of bringing us back towards the end of February, Parliament could resume at the normal time so that a guillotine will not have to be introduced towards the end of the Autumn sessional period. The Minister will bring us back late and then, towards the end of the Autumn sessional period, he will truncate debate again by introducing the guillotine. The Opposition opposes the motion and will vote against it.
Question put:

DEBATE.TITLE: GOVERNMENT BUSINESS ENTERPRISES (MISCELLANEOUS REFORMS) BILL 1988[COGNATE BILL:SUPERANNUATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 August, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I understand it is the wish of the House to debate the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous) Reforms Bill 1988 concurrently with the Superannuation Amendment Bill 1988. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an absolute disgrace that the Government has introduced a guillotine on the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill 1988 and the Superannuation Amendment Bill 1988, two very important Bills which are now before the House. A number of questions lie behind the legislation before the House and the Opposition wishes to examine them and wishes to force answers from the Government on them. Yet we find that the Government has allowed a very short time for us to debate these two extremely important Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now turn to the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill. This is a Bill which proposes new arrangements for the appointment, remuneration, tenure and dismissal of the chief executive officers of the Australian Shipping Commission, Commonwealth Bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. The Bill amends the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973 to provide that statutory office holders and the chief executive officers of certain government business enterprises will be removed from the formal determination-making jurisdiction of the Remuneration Tribunal. The Bill also has a number of other effects which, quite frankly, the Opposition believes do not go far enough in reforming government business enterprises.

As a general rule, where the government business enterprises operate in a competitive environment, they should be treated in a similar manner to their private sector counterparts. In the past, public sector business organisations have been substantially advantaged through favourable taxation treatment and the like and disadvantaged through a host of government regulations and controls. Reform of business enterprises is long overdue. For about two years now the Government has been considering a more level playing field, if I can use the jargon of the times, for government business enterprises.

The provisions in this Bill are only an infinitesimal step in what should be an extensive overhaul of statutory authorities and government business enterprises. While legislation containing other reforms has already been introduced into this place in recent days, in the view of the Opposition there is a need to hasten the legislative and reform process. The key point is that the Government must quicken the pace of adjustment and it must speed up its micro-economic reform of which it makes such great play. Anything short of a comprehensive program of reform in all of Australia's important industries will further undermine our competitiveness and hence our ability to get out of the economic mess into which this Labor Government has brought us.

This House recently debated the Government's decision to provide a more neutral taxation regime for government business enterprises, such as a removal of excise exemptions. This new taxation regime for government business enterprises will impact quite heavily on their operating costs which will inevitably lead to price pressures. Already Australia Post and Telecom have announced price increases for postage stamps and telephone charges respectively. The inescapable conclusion is that the Government is passing the buck on to the community. It is treating government business enterprises as milking cows for increased taxation revenue. The legislation before the House is not so much an expression of the Government's desire to reform government business enterprises, as a display of the Government's determination to collect as much tax revenue as possible. It is more greed on the part of the Government to build up the Budget surplus than it is a sincere, serious attempt to reform government business enterprises so as to advantage the consumer, and it is ultimately the consumers who will feel the effects. The Government has been less than honest and sincere about its reform of government business enterprises.

In the context of organisational constraints there are three major issues that remain unresolved in the Government's so-called blueprint for reform. The role of the Loan Council remains in place. This is because the Government is unwilling to free government business enterprises of global borrowing limits determined by the Loan Council. This acts as severe restraint on the ability of these enterprises to determine their most appropriate debt to equity ratio and also acts to distort investment decisions. The Government has yet to define exactly the new superannuation arrangements of government business enterprises. The details will not be known until March and April next year following a review of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme presently being conducted by the Department of Finance.

Moreover, the Government has failed to follow through on its so-called privatisation agenda about which so much was heard earlier this year and which the Government, following its conference in Hobart in the middle of the year, has run away from at a hundred miles an hour. `Privatisation' is a word that is not used by any Government member. At one stage the economic rationalists in the Government, the dries, those who could see that micro-economic reform was absolutely essential, supported this concept but now it has been abandoned.

The Opposition believes that many of the existing Government business enterprises should be privatised. I list as examples Aussat Pty Ltd, Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines, 49 per cent of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and the Australian Industry Development Corporation, and there are several others. As a first step-that is all, just a first step-towards privatisation the Government should fully commercialise these Government business enterprises. Privatisation is an essential component of a credible medium term strategy of structural and micro-economic reform. Since before the 1984 election the Opposition has been promoting the concept of the privatisation of Government business enterprises but the Government keeps putting the issue on the back burner because it is too difficult, internally, for it to face up to. Too many of the left wing and the Centre Left lack the courage, moreover I would suspect the intellectual aptitude, to face up to this essential problem. Caucus in-house fighting and interfactional brawls have prevented a proper consideration of the privatisation issue. While the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), the former Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, and even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have tried to push along the debate, left wing intransigence has held it up so far.

According to the Prime Minister, privatisation is a reasonable and rational reassessment of public sector priorities. He has argued that privatisation would save the Commonwealth hundreds of millions of dollars in capital injections, which would then be available for social programs and even tax cuts. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) shakes his head. He is a man who proclaims to be of independent thought. That will soon be put to test by the gold tax but on privatisation, which is the subject under discussion now, I would have thought that he, in his desire to ensure that equity be returned to social welfare planning and the tax regime, would support the privatisation of inefficient public enterprises. Even as recently as two weeks ago, Senator Walsh, the ever rational Minister for Finance, tried desperately to reignite the privatisation debate by suggesting the breaking up of some of these government business enterprises into subsidiary companies which could then be allowed to raise private equity. This is certainly an interesting proposal worthy of discussion. Perhaps the current Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) will elaborate on this point or suggest new proposals at the privatisation conference he is attending at the Australian National University tomorrow.

In the meantime, while this Government is bedevilled by internal dissension, government business enterprises are bleeding to death. Unless they are provided with private equity in the near future, they will suffer a slow but certain suffocating death. There is a need to bust open these government business enterprises to greater competition and private equity so as to improve efficiency, customer service and choice. Until this is done government business enterprises will remain more inefficient than they need to be and the Government will milk them for ever increasing contributions to the tax coffers.

I turn now to the Superannuation Amendment Bill. The purpose of the Bill is to make certain government enterprises more accountable for their own performance in managing superannuation. Government enter- prises operating under the new guidelines will be required to report their actions in relation to superannuation as part of their annual report. The Bill also allows the Industrial Relations Commission to conciliate and arbitrate on affected superannuation arrangements. This is an opportune time to discuss superannuation. Sadly, there is not sufficient time allowed to examine even part of this tremendously complex and serious issue, because the Government has guillotined debate.

People need to understand that the Government, either through mismanagement of the business of the House or, more likely, through a fear of extended debate on issues such as superannuation, wishes to gag Opposition speakers and, in doing so, cut off the opportunity for some of its better backbenchers to make a worthy contribution. I may add that I do not see any such persons who fill that criterion in the House at the moment, but one lives in hope. One or two may yet enter the chamber. On Thursday, 27 October 1988 an editorial in the Australian had this to say: `The Hawke Government has made a mess of superannuation'. Nothing could more succinctly or pithily summarise the position than that statement, because confusion reigns absolute in the field of superannuation. The May economic statement has wreaked havoc in the industry. Experts, fund trustees and members of superannuation funds remain utterly confused nearly six months later.

According to the industry, the immediate problems facing superannuation funds can at best be dealt with only through short term solutions, because the Government, in total abdication of its responsibility, has still not presented the industry with an acceptable course of action. In many ways the funds remain unclear as to what the impact of the new taxes will be. There needs to be a clearing up of the mess that has occurred over superannuation. Where is the legislation? Nearly six months after the release of the May economic statement there is no sign of when the legislation covering all of the superannuation tax changes mentioned in that statement will be tabled in the House.

The issue before the House is an important one, dealing as it does with superannuation arrangements for a number of enterprises involving statutory officeholders, employees of statutory authorities and certain Commonwealth owned companies. But there is a bigger issue: what is happening to the industry and all of the contributors as a result of the may economic Statement? It is an absolute disgrace. The state of superannuation under Labor has been a disaster. Ray Palmer, who is well known to people as a leading actuary, says that the responsibility for the chaos in superannuation lies mainly with the Australian Labor Party. Heavens above, who else does it lie with? Labor is in government. It must make the decisions, and it cannot do so. It is as if the complexities defy the abilities of its Ministers to take charge of what is admittedly a difficult question. We are waiting for the legislation. In the meantime there is no certainty, there is certainly no simplicity, and people are unable to plan their superannuation arrangements. There is a massive amount of regulation which, quite frankly, puts small superannuation funds at risk. More than half of Australia's 350,000 superannuation funds will be out of business as a result of the recent reporting guidelines imposed by Labor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order--
—Not only do Government members gag debate; they try to interrupt speakers on this side of the House.
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland will resume his seat. I call the honourable member for Chifley on a point of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, we are dealing with the Superannuation Amendment Bill, which deals with new supervisory mechanisms for the provision of superannuation benefits to Commonwealth sector employees. It has nothing to do with private superannuation funds or small private superannuation fund managers.
—The honourable member for Gippsland might address his remarks to the matter that is before the House.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, my time has almost expired, due to the Government's wrongful gagging of the debate this morning. I will bring my comments to a close.
—The honourable member for Gippsland has 15 more minutes if he wishes to proceed.
—In fairness to others who wish to contribute to this debate, I shall draw my comments to a close.
—The Chair is bound only by the clock, not by party agreements.

—My anger is not directed at you, Mr Deputy Speaker; it is directed at the Government for its totally and utterly irresponsible gagging of debate in this place. One wonders what hope democracy has when a government cuts off speakers willy-nilly on important, sophisticated legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) said in a speech in Sydney recently that there should be four central principles for a retirement incomes policy: adequacy, fairness, security and sustainability. Quite frankly, since coming to office Labor has made a mockery of those noble sentiments. Adequacy in what? Certainly not in superannuation cover. Fairness to whom? Certainly not to the thousands of pensioners who will have their pensions reduced. The Minister talked of security. What security? There has been no security. Since this Government came to office, there have been no fewer than seven major changes to pension income and 20 to superannuation. The Minister talked of sustainability and coping with the inevitable problems associated with an ageing population. Yet previously the Minister has labelled such people as alarmist.
I move the following amendment, which has been circulated in my name, in regard to the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not opposing the passage of this limited Bill, the House condemns the Government for its continued failure to act on major issues which will allow for the cost-effective, efficient and competitive operation and ownership of government business enterprises and authorities'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded? Has the honourable member finished his speech?

—No, not quite. There are one or two further comments that I need to make in relation to this legislation that will be of great interest to the Government. However, I realise again that the Government has gagged us and my comments must come to an end.
—The seconder has obviously arrived. Is the amendment seconded?
—I have pleasure in seconding the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry. I did not realise that the shadow Minister for science and energy, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), had concluded his remarks. I am very pleased to discuss the amount of gagging by the Government because the most restrictive aspect of it is that there was not an Opposition member in the House to second the amendment.
—That is not correct.

—I think the record of Hansard will show it. I do not want to have a wide-ranging debate about all aspects of superannuation and all the legislative changes that we may have brought in about superannuation. I want to discuss the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill and the Superannuation Amendment Bill that are before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I first want to discuss the Superannuation Amendment Bill 1988. I would have thought that the Opposition would have said, `Well, look, we're actually supporting this Bill for a couple of reasons'. Probably the principal reason is that it will allow statutory authorities, with the approval of the Minister for Finance, to bring in superannuation schemes that are more closely identified with those similar to or consistent with those operating in private enterprise. Unfortunately, the shadow Minister did not say that. Regrettably, he seemed more fixated about what was happening not with the Commonwealth superannuation scheme but with other superannuation schemes. That is perfectly legitimate, I might add. Unfortunately, it might have detracted from his making a positive statement about this particular Bill.

The Bill, of course, will initially apply to Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines, the Australian National Line and Aussat Pty Ltd. Later on, following a review by the Department of Finance, it will allow organisations such as Telecom Australia, Australia Post, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation to develop their own superannuation arrangements within appropriate guidelines.

I ask the House: Who will be the principal beneficiaries of this? Firstly, the existing Commonwealth superannuation scheme benefits those who see themselves in a career service with many opportunities for rapid promotion. The longer that one is in the service and the higher the stage of promotion one has reached the more attractive this scheme becomes. That is probably fair enough. But it is reasonable to point out that that disadvantages, if you like, those at the work face who do not have those same opportunities for promotion. For example, the current scheme does not benefit the typists, the blue collar workers and the cleaners in the organisation.

I certainly welcome this Bill and the reforms that it introduces. They will significantly benefit the ordinary worker who contributes so much to these organisations. I think the proposal will enjoy the unanimous support of the people whom it will affect and the trade union members who represent them.

I turn to the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill. The shadow Minister for science and energy made a couple of comments about government business enterprises (GBEs). He attacked the Government, saying that we are using these corporations as milking cows. He then went on to say that they were bleeding to death. That is a mixed metaphor. If the honourable member wants to get his quotation right, it is `cash rich milking cows'. How do cash rich milking cows bleed to death? It is a mixed metaphor and is entirely inappropriate. The Opposition provides a dilemma for us on this side of the House. Consistently, Opposition speakers say that government enterprises should have the same sorts of restrictions as private enterprises and that they should not be in a privileged position. In government they introduced some of these changes. We have certainly picked up the concept, but in doing so we are attacked. The Opposition says that we are doing the wrong thing. Having worked in a government enterprise, I believe that there should be a so-called level playing field. I am pleased to see that the Government is implementing that concept. I certainly reject totally the charge that the Government is treating these organisations as milking cows or alternatively that they are bleeding to death.

Once again we get the call for privatisation from the Opposition-the call it hears ringing out loud and clear from England. As truly independent Australians, Opposition members pick it up and mindlessly call for its application. If we are talking about ideologues or those who are incapable of exercising independent judgment, they reside on the Opposition benches. What this Government is doing, and what it can be proud of doing, is undertaking a complete review of all our government business enterprises. No government has had a better understanding of them. We have put in place measures that either apply to all of them-the Superannuation Amendment Bill is a reflection of that-or apply only to some of them. The significance of the measures is that they are designed to make these organisations more efficient, more effective and more customer-responsive.

Let me ask Opposition members what significant reform they introduced in their seven years of government to government trading enterprises-absolutely none, not one significant reform. They are not interested in reform. All they are interested in is flogging off government business enterprises. I am disappointed in the honourable member for Gippsland who I thought, as a National Party member, would have defended organisations like Australia Post and Telecom Australia and would have defended this Government's action in ensuring that rural and provincial Australia will not be disadvantaged as far as communications, mail services and information services are concerned. But, no; the Nationals will not do that. They are in the clutches of the economic dries over there. Wherever the economic dries can get a dollar they will get a dollar. They want to flog off these organisations lock, stock and barrel. They have no interest in them. They have no interest in their long term survival. They have no interest or concern for customer services. All they want to do is to flog these organisations off to private enterprise and then squander the money.

On the other hand, Government members are concerned about the long term survival of those organisations; they are concerned about the future of the employees and, most importantly, they are concerned about the quality of service that customers receive from those organisations.

A number of reforms to the enterprises are encapsulated in this Bill. An important one, for example, is the removal of the payment of the chief executives from the authority of the Remuneration Tribunal. Such executives, when the boards appoint them and negotiate salary ranges, will have to stand up to international competition. No executive will get the benefit of the new salary without first having to apply in open, international competition and take his chances. One of the other things we have done with these GBEs is to loosen industry reform (IR) coordination. We have taken away the financial planning horizon which in practice used to be little more than six months but nominally 12 months and given them a much longer planning horizon so that they are able to establish business plans approved by the Government for periods of longer than, in effect, six months but notionally 12 months. That is exceptionally important. No other government has done that. Another important aspect of remuneration is the freeing or loosening of IR coordination. Some of these authorities have suffered because their employees have been poached by private enterprise. In not having the flexibility to vary in a small way some of those conditions, they are lost.

I am pleased to support these reforms. They are consistent with Labor Party policy. The honourable member for Gippsland, the shadow spokesman on this matter, who spoke before me said that we were treating government business enterprises as milking cows and attacked us for a lack of fortitude in relation to privatisation. I listened to Rod Bastian, who was representing small business, on radio this morning. I am sure that the honourable member for Gippsland would have been shocked to hear Rod go public and say how disappointed he was with the Opposition members. I note that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) is a former small businessman as are many honourable members on this side. It is no wonder that small business is recognising who its real friends are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill provides new arrangements for the appointment, remuneration, tenure, and dismissal of the chief executive officers of the Australian Shipping Commission, the Commonwealth Bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. To accomplish this, the Bill amends the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 to provide that statutory office holders and chief executive officers of the relevant government business enterprises will be removed from the determination-making jurisdiction of the Remuneration Tribunal. So after five years of debate, reports, submissions, and more reports, all this Government has been able to do is present us with a Bill which argues about who will decide how much the chief executive officers of four government business enterprises will be paid. One thing is very clear: the Government does not have its heart in improving the operating efficiency of government business enterprises. It has proved that by its extraordinary reluctance to actually implement the changes recommended by a number of reviews which have pointed to the inefficiencies in the current arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is the Government moving at such glacial speed? Initial steps in the process of reform are so tentative and halting because the Government refuses to grasp the nettle that blocks the path to reform of government business enterprises because it is terrified of any discussion about privatisation. If it seems that we are dabbling at the edges of this debate, it is because the major issues that we should be debating have been hijacked by factions within the Australian Labor Party. Those major issues are all related to the single word `privatisation'. Last November when the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) introduced the final version of a policy information paper entitled `Policy guidelines for Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises' he said:
Unfortunately objectivity in the public debate on achieving efficiency in these Commonwealth business enterprises has often been blurred by ideology.

Never has the senator, unwittingly perhaps, spoken truer words because that is exactly what happened to the privatisation debate in this country. I say `unwittingly' because he intended those words for the Opposition. But the fact is that the debate on privatisation in this nation has been hijacked by the ideologues of the Labor Party. The Labor Government has never had an easy time with privatisation. For years the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Treasurer (Mr Keating) slammed the Opposition for our proposals to privatise certain public assets. In July 1985 the Prime Minister said:

Privatisation is a one-off fire sale, a sale of the century, of your assets-the assets of the people of Australia. The Opposition would transfer them into the hands of a privileged few, to the cost of everyone of us.
Could this be the same man, the same Prime Minister, the same Leader of the Labor Party who said just two years later:
As you know I recently called for a comprehensive debate within the forums of my Party on those parts of its platform which express opposition to the sale of government business enterprises.

I suggest two tests must be applied. First, does public ownership of a given enterprise mean that significant functions are undertaken that would not be if the private sector had the responsibility for funding, owning and operating the enterprise? If the answer is `no', then, second, what are the disadvantages of retaining ownership of that public enterprise, as opposed to transferring it to the private sector? This in effect reverses the onus of proof. The question should not be: `Why should we sell a given enterprise?' but `Why should we continue to tie up our resources in it?'

That was the same Prime Minister who was castigating the Opposition for talking about privatisation but who three years later said, `Perhaps we ought to reverse the onus of proof to see whether existing government business enterprises ought to remain within the Commonwealth domain'. He went on to say in the same speech:
Efficiency in the achievement of national goals is the key, not some ideological debate about appropriate aggregate levels of public ownership.

That is interesting. Unfortunately, the public conversion of the Prime Minister towards this more realistic approach to privatisation was short lived because he was rolled by his faction-ridden Caucus. Following the Caucus meeting, the executive of the Left faction issued a statement which said:
It was an important victory which called on Ministers to prepare proposals which would strengthen and enhance authorities in full public ownership.

So not only did the Left say that the Prime Minister was comprehensively rolled but also it said that there was to be no privatisation but there was to be a further enhancement and expansion of the Government's role in the private sector. So whilst the Prime Minister has publicly acknowledged the need for and benefits arising from privatisation he will not act because of the prehistoric views of the economically irrational left wing of the Labor Party. While nearly every other Western nation is moving to improve the efficiency of its government business enterprises by privatising them, we in Australia are left languishing.
Last September the Treasurer was hoping that the debate on privatisation would get a renewed boost from this year's Australian Labor Party National Conference in Hobart. He said last September:
We will address the matter in terms of the next National Conference and try and loosen up that capacity for the Government to review those things.
But the Labor Conference in Hobart last June struck down any hope that may have existed for open debate on the issue when it passed the following resolution:
The conference:
A. Recognises that a fundamental tenet of the Labor movement is a total commitment to full ownership and control of enterprises in the public sector.
D. Notes that no change in current policy affecting these enterprises may be implemented except following decision by the National Conference.

There is Senator Walsh's objectivity blurred by the intrusion of ideology. The death of debate on privatisation in this nation under this Government has now left Labor with the task of implementing a program of reform of government business enterprises without what has proved in the rest of the world to be the most powerful weapon in the arsenal of such reform-that is, privatisation. The left will not allow it, so the Government remains hogtied.

The use of privatisation to improve efficiency is not limited to the Western world. I direct the attention of the comrades of the parliamentary Left sitting opposite to the fact that on 21 September this year the Soviet Union announced that if 31 of that nation's public enterprises were not able to turn their losses into profits within six months, they would be turned over to private management. We now see that the Left guard, which is controlling the whip hand in the Labor Party, is now further to the left than the Soviet Union's Communist Party. That is how relevant the Labor Party is to today's politics.

It is the people of Australia who have the most to gain or lose in this debate. The investment of the taxpayer in the major government business enterprises of the nation is enormous. The Commonwealth business enterprises employ about 50 per cent of all Commonwealth employees. Their fixed annual investments comprise more than three-quarters of the Commonwealth Government's capital investment. The capital accounts of the 16 major government business enterprises represent an investment of $2,400 for every Australian family. Privatisation will provide benefits to both taxpayers and consumers in lower prices for goods and services, wider ranges of goods and services, a more rapid rate of adoption of innovations, greater productivity and a reduced burden on government and Ministers.

Not too long ago those involved in the public sector consisted mainly of law enforcement officials, policy advisers, taxation personnel and the military. Over time, government has become more and more involved in transportation, telecommunications, delivery of health care services, education and even shopping centres. Today, of the 480,000 non-military employees of the Commonwealth Government, nearly 330,000 of them are employed in government owned trading operations and service industries. Subjecting those organisations to Public Service constraints instead of allowing many of them to develop as efficient private sector organisations is costing us all dearly. We pay more tax to fund them and more for the services provided. The taxpayers are the all round losers from the Government's failure to grasp the nettle and get on with the job of privatisation. Government business enterprises competing with private industry are at a distinct disadvantage from a management point of view. Under their charters they are unable to react as quickly to the demands of the market or to the needs of the consumers.

I understand that the Government has put a guillotine on me and that my Whip wants me to wind up. This is one of the most important issues facing this nation because the rate of change in our community is too slow. The Government has backed off from any significant changes to government business enterprises, and while I will wind up, I stress that it is a significant issue. I understand why the Government wants to gag debate on it; it is running scared.

The left wing is manipulating the Government against the best interests of the community, and I conclude by saying that the management of government business enterprises is hampered by centralised decision making, lack of both incentives and clear penalties and the fact that there is often unavoidable political control over key management functions and decisions such as investment, financing and marketing, and even over the scope of services offered.

The coalition stands by its policy regarding privatisation, and stands ready to debate the role of privatisation in the reform of government business enterprises. The Opposition does not look forward to years of dreary debate on the minuscule detail of reforming government enterprises. Many of the government enterprises have no business remaining in the public domain, where they unnecessarily draw on ministerial and parliamentary resources, clutter up the legislative process and, more importantly, are not allowed the freedom to get on with the business they do best in competition with other enterprises engaged in similar pursuits, whether they be providing home loans to young Australian families or shipping iron ore to Japan.

This debate is not about loosening the control of the Remuneration Tribunal over the terms and conditions of employment of certain chief executive officers; it is about reform of government business enterprises and the environment in which they operate. I urge the Government to get serious about its reform of the Commonwealth Government's business enterprises and support the amendment moved by my colleague.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--
—What are you going to do on the gold tax?

—If the honourable member for Gippsland will wait, he will find out what I will do about the gold tax. I have my mind fairly fixed on a course, and I do not need advice from him. The honourable member for Gippsland was born with such a large silver spoon in his mouth that I am surprised he can even sit down.
—Here we go again; same old routine.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Gippsland.

—In this cognate debate I will address my remarks mainly to government business enterprises. In so doing, I want to say of the last speaker, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), that never was a member so aptly named; he is all bark and no bite. In fact, it is my view that if voting in his electorate were not a congenital thing, he would not hold his seat. I want to deal with some of the issues that have been raised.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my view, often expressed in this place, that the Opposition does not understand how business works. There would not be one single solitary place, not even Naracoorte or Mount Gambier in the honourable member's electorate, where the telephone system would pay for itself. That phone system relies on a cross-subsidy. This is also true, of course, of the phones in the electorate of the honourable member for Gippsland. Not one single exchange will pay for itself; they are all cross-subsidised by the golden triangle of Telecom Australia-the Sydney, Melbourne, Canberra axis. Do these honourable gentlemen believe that a privatised Telecom would service these people and provide them with world class services at the price enjoyed by the rest of the people in Australia? Of course it would not, and if honourable members do think so, then they clearly do not know what private enterprise is about or what it should be about.

One has only to look at the history of things to see that. My mind goes back to the situation of the railways in Britain prior to the war when private enterprise existed. Profits were guaranteed by the Government. The government of the day guaranteed a 5 per cent profit to shareholders no matter how efficiently or inefficiently the railways, for example, were run. This is the nature of private enterprise which Opposition members want.

I want to inject two ideas into the debate during the short time I have. Railways are essential to Australia and they are very good at moving freight over long distances. Eventually, I would like to see a unified railway system throughout Australia. In the short term I do not think that is possible and it is probably not wise. Without a doubt, the most efficient railway system in Australia is that run by the Western Australian Government. It is a very efficient organisation, because it is largely decentralised. It is an organisation for which a former Minister for Transport, the Hon. Julian Grill, should take a lot of credit, because he was responsible for a lot of the restructuring. The Australian National is also a very efficient railway system, although it has inherited a lot of problems in the railways that it has absorbed.

The idea I want to put forward, and I hope it is taken seriously by the various overlords of the railway system in Australia, is the need to develop a unified freight handling system for all railways. It should be possible to put freight on in Sydney and to have it delivered anywhere else throughout the railway system in Australia, on a system in which all the railways work closely together and divide the profits of that enterprise. I think this would be very valuable.

I would like to see the same system applied to passenger travel. In the Trans Australian and the Indian Pacific we have the potential for world class tourist facilities. They are tourist attractions in their own right-or could be, if they were developed properly. For them to develop properly, there is a need for an overall management system. I believe the railways of Australia must work together to ensure that that is the case. They must do away with unnecessary crew changing, unnecessary train changing and unnecessary engine changing. All those things must be unified in the interests of efficiency. If those two ideas are taken up, I believe I will have made a useful contribution to the debate.

The Bill also opens up the area of industrial relations. I say to Australian National, in particular, that there is what I perceive to be a serious decline in the morale of the staff of Australian National, particularly at the Parkeston depot in Western Australia. It is nonsense, in my view, that we should have Parkeston and West Kalgoorlie so close together; and I believe we should have an amalgamation. That will need goodwill and commonsense on the part of both Australian National and Westrail. We cannot have a recurrence of the outrageous situation in New South Wales whereby Australian National pays for much of the infrastructure facilities at Broken Hill, yet the New South Wales Government has all the control. That is manifestly unfair, and I can understand why Australian National is wary of that happening in Western Australia.

I urge both parties to show reasonable commonsense. I believe that will occur and that we will see an amalgamation, with its consequent economies. In the meantime, Australian National has a very strong obligation to let its people at Parkeston know what is happening. I perceive morale there to be low because people have been kept in the dark; they simply do not know what is happening. It is not as though these people are at all militant; the level of industrial strife is very low indeed. But if this simple problem of communication is not addressed, I predict that there will be industrial trouble in the New Year-and I will lay the blame for that entirely and squarely at the door of the management of Australian National.

In terms of the potential to increase Australia's export earnings, there is probably no greater potential than that of the Australian National Line (ANL). I believe ANL has the capacity to earn a lot of dollars for Australia, and also to give Australia the security that an island nation requires. I would like to see a continued development and expansion of our shipping lines. That will require a lot of goodwill and a lot of commonsense-and a lot of goodwill on the part of the union. I believe the Seamen's Union has the capacity to act in that way. In talks I have had with the union, I have found that among the ranks there are people of commonsense and understanding.

It is nonsense to talk in isolation about the overmanning of Australian crews. We cannot reduce the manning of our ships until we build ships that are suitable to be manned with fewer crew. It simply cannot be done; it would be both dangerous and foolish to do it. There is also a need for capital injection, a capital injection that has been denied for many years. It is interesting to listen to the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) when he gets up and barks about the inaction of this Government-especially when we consider the actions of this Government as compared with the actions of his Government. That Government was in power in Australia for seven years. It had unlimited power; it had control of both Houses of the Parliament. What did that Government do in terms of trying to bring government enterprises into the present day? It did nothing. It was absolutely frozen in its attitude. That contrasts very sharply with the actions taken by this Government. I am not a mindless privatiser; nor do I believe entirely in the free market economy, because, from my observations, it certainly does not work. Rational economists make the grave mistake of believing that we live in a rational world. That is their achilles heel. However, I believe in efficiency, and in privatisation, where it is the appropriate course. But to talk about big business being efficient is absurd.

If honourable members opposite ever had any dealings with large corporations, with large insurance companies or large mining companies, they would find them more bureaucratic than-or at least as bureaucratic as-most government departments. When one talks about bureaucracy, no doubt there is a wide variance. I can single out government departments that are extremely bureaucratic. Others, I believe, are more forward looking. Such attitudes display both a lack of understanding and a simple lack of knowledge-perhaps because of a blind adherence to rhetoric. When honourable members opposite talk about efficiency, they really should define exactly what efficiency means. There are many things I would like to add to the debate, but I shall have to confine my remarks to those points.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Interestingly, as far as the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reform) Bill is concerned, a great emphasis was placed on the appointment of chief executives to these restructured state enterprises; and I shall come back to that point. The legislation seeks the reform of certain minor aspects of the operation of some government-run business enterprises. Indeed, so minor are the proposed reforms that we have before us a classic example of how shallow the Government's rhetoric about micro-economic reform, beginning in the public sector, really is.

SPEECH.PARA: If the much talked about structural reforms are to have any lasting effects, they must involve a good deal more than increasing the ability of government instrumentalities to pay more for their senior executives. No matter how competent the chief executive is, he or she cannot overcome the limits of an organisation that in its conception is fundamentally flawed. In the case of government owned business enterprises, no executive officer can overcome the fundamental problems and dilemmas of government ownership, which produces an economy that is less efficient than it might be and which increases the burden on the limited resources of taxpayers.

This Bill will allow the portfolio Minister to appoint chief executives of the Australian Shipping Commission, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. All of those bodies must be considered prime candidates for privatisation, if not under this Government then certainly under a government led by the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). The proposed reforms to government enterprises, of which this legislation forms a part, make sense only if the reformed businesses are eventually privatised. If privatisation does not occur, we shall discover that the blusters of both the present Government and the Australian Labor Party about reform will have produced little in the way of greater efficiency but will have reduced the accountability of government-owned enterprises and businesses to both the Government and, more importantly, the Parliament.

The danger of declining accountability can be illustrated by two particularly outrageous and topical examples. The first is being investigated by the Senate Privileges Committee and involves the refusal of the Aboriginal Development Commission to answer questions from Senate committees after a decision by the ADC's independent board. Of course, this follows on from a series of allegations about the inefficient operations of the Commission. It helps to show the problems of accountability when the role of government expands beyond reasonable bounds. Independence from the scrutiny of Parliament and legislative responsibilities might in some way offer efficiencies to government business enterprises, but it removes some incentives to work in the interests of Australians. It does not impose on those enterprises the disciplines of the market-in fact, the opposite is true.

The Aboriginal Development Commission has not been sufficiently accountable to Parliament and the result has been a scandalous waste of taxpayers' money. Clearly, these problems are not simply those of the constraints of government preventing the Commission from competing with the private sector. Yet when it comes to government business enterprises, the Australian Labor Party would have us believe that the reputation for inefficiency which the public sector undoubtedly has is only the result of not having a commercial structure. This is not true. The failures of government when it expands beyond those quite narrow limits for which it was instituted and for which it exists are the result of fundamental causes which cannot be wished away by the will of democratic socialists who have seen so many of their other hopes dashed by reality.

This brings me to a second illustration of the problem of accountability in government business enterprises-the record of the Western Australian Government when it gets involved in the private sector as a participant rather than an independent arbiter. The Western Australian Government is the model which many honourable members opposite saw as a way out of the privatisation debate. The corporatist policies of the Dowding and Burke governments saw government-owned business enterprises as a great contributor to the revenue of the State government, growing through entrepreneurial activity, clever management and the support of the local private sector-a tool to keep local resources in local hands.

To achieve these ends the State Labor governments have formed a number of companies along commercial lines and reformed the management of government assets to be able to take up commercial opportunities. The Western Australian Development Corporation (WADC), Exim and Goldcorp are amongst these new government-owned companies. The State Government Insurance Office was merged with the Motor Vehicle Insurance Trust and given a new charter as the State Government Insurance Corporation. The Superannuation Board was restructured and the Rural and Industries Bank was encouraged to seek new opportunities for growth in a similar way.

If I have the time I will go on to show that the reforms which the Western Australian Labor Government first began to implement in 1983 are substantially the same as the Federal Labor proposals for changes to government business enterprises contained in this Bill and the proposals for corporatising various government authorities. The lessons from the experience in Western Australia about the accountability of government agencies and the executive arm of government to Parliament and the people must be learnt thoroughly if the same mistakes are not to be repeated. We should remember that the tragic loss of taxpayers' money in the Rothwells Ltd fiasco would have been avoided if correct principles of limited government had been adhered to and observed by that Labor Government.

These events and the principles which they so eloquently demonstrate were anticipated by some of the more perceptive commentators. Notable amongst them was an Associate Professor of Politics at the University of Western Australia, Professor Patrick O'Brien, who published two devastating critiques of the Burke Government, only to be vilified by the hacks of the Labor Party for his trouble. Before the event he correctly identified the problems of the Western Australian Labor Government as more than just errors or the personal corruption of looking after mates and associates; but the result of a particular approach to government which he identified as corporatist. Essential to this idea of corporatism is the blurring of differences between government, business and trade unions through tripartite councils, close personal links between representatives of all three groups, and government involvement in business and union affairs to facilitate the corporatist model.

This Bill looks at government business enterprises, so it is not now appropriate to go through the intricate web of activities of the Labor Party in government in Western Australia which have been widely seen to be, and are in fact, corrupt. However, I urge all members of this House to read Professor O'Brien's article on the issue which is published in this month's edition of Quadrant since I cannot believe that many members, or even some members, of the Labor Party would really approve of the actions of their Western Australian counterparts. The new government business enterprises in Western Australia were created on a basis as commercial as is possible for an instrumentality of the Government. That is acknowledged.

The Western Australian Development Corporation, although established by an Act of Parliament, is subject to minimal scrutiny by the Western Australian Parliament and actually hides behind commercial confidentiality or, when it is convenient, Crown privilege to avoid the accountability of traditional government authorities. The WADC produces an annual report which, as honourable members would appreciate, is often late and is not subject to the investigations and scrutiny of the State Auditor-General. Complicating the examination of the WADC is its ownership of a number of companies which either invest or operate other functions on its behalf.

The State Labor Government was particularly proud of securing the services of a prominent businessman to be the Corporation's Chief Executive. He is a personal friend of mine, one whom I respect and admire for his achievements in the private sector. However, the WADC is a classic example of the type of government business operation that the Keating-Hawke Labor Government risks creating with its so-called reforms. The record of the WADC is, to say the least, uninspiring. Its profits are mainly derived from the privileges conferred on it by the State Government, or what can only be described as creative accounting. The privileges which I refer to include the disposal of government-owned land and assets, management of funds which had previously been the responsibility of the State Treasury, trade in legal tender gold coins, advantages in securing development approvals and a favoured position when dealing with government departments. For those reasons, the Corporation is becoming a more popular joint venture partner for those seeking to avoid possible difficulties with other State government authorities, and that is how it is being utilised.

Because of an arrangement which I feel loath to honour as the Government has applied the guillotine, I am unable to continue my remarks. Out of respect for my colleague the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin), I will leave it there. I simply want to say that we are a fair way along the track. These measures indicate that we could go further down that track if we do not learn the lessons which have been so starkly presented to us in Western Australia and which have matured in recent times.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The actual content of the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill and the Superannuation Amendment Bill relates to new changes to the procedure for the appointment and remuneration of senior executives in the Australian Shipping Commission, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, the underlying principle being to free these enterprises from excessive government control over their day to day operations and to allow them to become more competitive and efficient commercially. Under the new arrangements, appointments of chief executives will be made by the relevant portfolio Minister upon receiving a recommendation from the enterprise board in the relevant authority. Chief executives appointed in this fashion will have no security of tenure. This procedure will ensure that a Minister makes decisions in close consultation with officials from the government business enterprises (GBEs) for which he is responsible.

SPEECH.PARA: The terms and conditions of employment for chief executives will be determined by each individual enterprise board in the GBEs covered under this legislation. These boards will also be responsible for the determination of remuneration for their chief executives and, for this purpose, the legislation amends the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973. The Remuneration Tribunal will no longer have the power to make determinations in regard to chief executives. However, it is a requirement of this legislation that enterprise boards consult with the Remuneration Tribunal in the course of their determinations in this area. Enterprise boards will also make determinations on remuneration for their senior executives consistent with the arrangements determined for chief executives.

The Superannuation Amendment Bill 1988 is also aimed at the removal of government restrictions on the operation of GBEs. It enables ministerial guidelines to be laid down for the payment of superannuation. GBEs can then operate within these guidelines without the need for further reference to the Minister for Finance.

That is the actual content of the legislation but obviously as the debate has unfolded it has broadened into a more general consideration of issues relating to privatisation and the performance of government enterprise generally. We have also seen a number of utter irrelevancies brought into the debate, such as the proposal for a gold tax, the performance of the Aboriginal Development Commission and so on. There is very limited time in this debate and I thought it might be appropriate to make a few observations about the privatisation argument because that seems to have figured fairly prominently. An earlier speaker seemed to liken the position of those opposed to privatisation in the Australian context to defenders of the highly and totally bureaucratically planned economies of the Soviet Union and eastern Europe. Of course, that is an utter absurdity. The public sector and the government business enterprises in Australia carry out a fairly restricted range of activities, substantially relating to the provision of infrastructure which is crucial for economic development. If we are going to talk about the Australian case we should focus on the performance of Australian government business enterprises in that area and whether there is any reason to believe that simply transferring those enterprises from the public to the private sector will confer any significant economic advantages.

The first aspect of that argument on which I thought I might comment is the fiscal argument for privatisation-that if the Government privatises enterprises it will derive a windfall gain from the proceeds of the sale of those assets. It is further argued that in the case of the United Kingdom under the Thatcher Government that has been utilised to facilitate tax cuts. Also, the argument runs that if one privatises public enterprises then the Government will not have to fund out of Budget outlays necessary capital injections into those enterprises and thus it opens up the possibility of the Government spending the same money in other areas. That is an argument which has a certain superficial appeal, but I believe that if it is rigorously analysed from an economic point of view it is utterly spurious. The economic literature on the subject is quite unambiguous. The main thrust of the credible economic literature on this is that unless there are very specific reasons to think that transferring an enterprise from the public to the private sector will, by that very change of ownership, lead to a significant increase in the efficiency with which that enterprise operates, then the argument about the claim that one gets a fiscal advantage from selling off the enterprise is quite spurious. Any benefit that one gets is purely cosmetic. It is purely a function and a result of the type of national accounting conventions that we have in Australia which treat the sale of an asset as a negative outlay.

Obviously if one sells an equity in a government business enterprise and that is treated as a negative outlay, it reduces outlays and does so without seeming to increase revenues. On the surface we get quite an attractive picture coming out of that. But if we adopt national accounting conventions which are more in accord with those utilised by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and the United Nations, there is a quite different accounting treatment of sales of government assets and also of capital injections into government business enterprises. The focus in those systems is on what is termed the general government deficit which abstracts from those effects. The point is that if the Government sells equity in a government business enterprise on the one hand its spending requirements on the surface are less because it does not have to inject capital and as a result of that its borrowing requirement is less and so there is a smaller requirement to service public debt. In the final analysis the saving is the reduction in the resulting public debt interest. On the other hand, however, by selling equity in a government business enterprise the Government forgoes a future stream of dividend income that otherwise would have flowed into that enterprise. According to the economic theorists, unless there is reason to suppose--
