SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the fourth significant piece of roads legislation introduced by the Hawke Government since 1983. This Government has an unparalleled record in the 65-year history of Commonwealth road funding. It is a record of failure, theft, deceit, broken promises and economic incompetence. Never before has any government been so short-sighted and stupid as to introduce road funding legislation which cuts expenditure levels in money terms and introduce legislation to cut funding to an established program. Yet this Government is so myopic that it has done both of these things and, despite promises to the contrary, repeated them.

SPEECH.PARA: Time has exposed the lack of commitment by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to his word. In 1984 he undertook that the Hume Highway would have four lanes all the way between Sydney and Melbourne in time for Australia's bicentenary. The clock is ticking away, it is now November, and I just wonder how many uncompleted miles of four-lane highway there are. I am sure the people of Queensland will also remember the promise made by the same Prime Minister about the Bruce Highway. I think his attitude to road funding and to promises about that and other areas of government activity highlights his lack of commitment to honouring his words and the totally arrogant approach of his Government.

Some time ago, when the first ever cut of $50m to an established road program was made by this Government, Australia was told that this decision was prompted by exceptional economic circumstances arising from international events and would not be a precedent for the Hawke Government's future road expenditure. How long did it take for the Government to repeat that action? The answer is that it was about two months before a further $20m was ripped off the Government's new Australian land transport program to mark the third such funding cut in a little over 12 months; the first being when the program was introduced. The story goes on.

The Bill before the House again sees the Hawke Government cut road expenditure in money terms. It marks another failure in the Hawke Government's self-determined program of micro-economic reforms, which has become a bit of a joke. The transport portfolio really highlights the failure of this Government to come to grips with what it describes as `hard decisions'. In 1983-84 when the coalition's legislation determined the level of Commonwealth road expenditure, expenditure on roads stood at $1,203m, representing 66 per cent of diesel and petrol excise revenue collected from road users. This record belongs to the Liberal and National parties; in fact it belongs to my National Party colleague the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), a former Minister for Transport. It has nothing to do with the approach of the Hawke Government to road funding, or its commitment to providing for the maintenance of this important infrastructure in our community. What has happened to road funding since is so appallingly bad that any honest member of the Australian Labor Party would be embarrassed to debate the issue in public.

From that peak expenditure level-I repeat, established by a coalition Government-the Hawke Government's decisions have cut funding to $1,215m in the current financial year. Yet it has the nerve to brag about it. As we all know, the Hawke Government has talked long and hard about battling inflation but its record on inflation is about as good as its record on road funding. Therefore, when we look for a measure of the decline in real road building effort we perhaps should turn to the Government's own Ministers to provide the evidence of just how savage the funding cutbacks have been. Only this year, on 24 May, the Minister for Finance, Senator Peter Walsh, advised that in 1987-88 dollar terms the Government's road expenditure during 1987-88 was $1,244m compared with a peak some four years earlier-going back to when the level of expenditure was determined by a coalition Government-of $1,593m. Again that was under the policy of the honourable member for Gwydir.

Senator Walsh's own admission proves that road funds have been cut by $350m in four years. This latest decision chops another $100m, giving a total reduction of $450m. That is how much the Hawke Government has cut off road funding during its period in office. It has stolen the full value of the Australian bicentennial road development (ABRD) program from the people of Australia, but it has maintained the 2c per litre levy introduced to pay for it. If we look forward to the turn of the century, that theft, that misappropriation, will add up to in excess of $5 billion. Later I will identify what this means in terms of genuine cost to Australians-costs relating to economic activity, social factors and, most appallingly, the number of Australians who will die on our roads during the period.

The Hawke Government's contempt for road users does not stop merely at cutting expenditure levels. This desperate Government has ripped off road users in virtually every Budget it has introduced. The result is that fuel excise rates for diesel and petrol are at an all-time high of more than 21.5c per litre. So when the road user fills up his vehicle, he can look at the price per litre and remember that 21.5c of it goes to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Grim Reaper himself. That is about 40 per cent of the final pump price in most areas. Yet I recall when the Treasurer was in opposition he talked about each petrol pump being an office of the Australian Taxation Office. He was really referring to what he was going to do. It was his intention to turn every petrol pump into an office of the Australian Taxation Office. Soon we will have pictures of Trevor Boucher on the top of each pump. In the starkest possible terms the Hawke Government has managed to slash the relativity between what it spends on roads and what it collects from road users from a situation in 1983-84, under the policy of the Liberal and National parties, when 66 per cent of excise was spent on roads, to less than 23 per cent of excise being spent on roads today. That underlines starkly the approach of this Government to road funding and its approach to imposing tax on fuel. I invite members of the Labor Party to justify that action when they respond in this debate.

The cynicism of this Government in its exploitation of the Australian motorist was probably greatest when in the August 1986 Budget it made the third roads expenditure cut in little more than 12 months, while increasing fuel excise rates by 3c a litre in the same Budget. That sort of arrogance, that sort of contempt, has become a hallmark of this Government. This Government's record of cutting $450m in road funds so that the share of fuel excise going to roads is below 23 per cent speaks volumes for the absolute contempt it has for the road users of Australia-in fact, for the taxpayers of Australia. One can only conclude that roads do not matter to the Government, that they are not important to the Government's economic and social priorities. In fact, one Minister is reported as having said, `What do a few more potholes matter?'. They really do not understand. They do not understand how short-sighted their policy approach is. These decisions are already costing Australia dearly and will continue to do so while the Government is allowed to get away with this appalling record on road funding. I see the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) has joined us in the House. I hope that he will not continue to grin about this subject because it is a very serious matter. A number of industry associations and road user groups have been working hard to try to convince the Government of its mistakes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I cannot allow the honourable member's comment to go unchallenged. I was just conveying my greetings to the other shadow Minister at the table.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Again, this is an example of how the Government is determined to stifle debate on this important subject. This Bill is being debated under a guillotine and the Minister takes frivolous points of order in order to reduce the time available for debate. He should be ashamed of himself. When this speech is circulated-and it will be-that point will be noted by road user organisations. I look forward to the Minister's response explaining his actions.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me get back to the main issue, which is more important than the attitude of the Minister. Like other Ministers who have held his job, I am sure he will be shuffled fairly shortly. The Government has been oblivious to these comments, and in fact the Minister has been critical of road user organisations for even daring to criticise the policy that has been handed down from on high. The Executive Director of the Australian Road Transport Federation (ARTF), Mr Gamble, has described the Government's decision as `economic madness redoubled'. He is a very responsible person who represents road user organisations right throughout Australia. The Australian Road Transport Federation has estimated that the cumulative effect of the Government's road funding cuts will cost Australia very dearly. It will cost almost 7,000 lives and untold injuries through more road crashes, in excess of $4.2 billion in higher vehicle operating costs, over $3 billion in Australian industry because of lower productivity created by longer journey times, and the inevitable increase in inflation as industries pass on operating costs to consumers. Yet inflation is a priority for this Government. Let me take one simple example. The road transport industry estimates that it now costs $1 for every minute that a major freight vehicle is held up in traffic. The $5 billion-plus that the Government has ripped off road funding cumulative to the turn of the century could go a long way to saving an enormous number of those minutes.

The Australian Automobile Association (AAA), another major and respected organisation which represents some 4.7 million road users, has embarked on a public campaign to highlight the short-sighted approach of the Government, yet it was roundly criticised by the Minister for daring to come out and criticise the Government's policy publicly. As recently as June, when the then Minister for Transport and Communications Support, the present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris), was bemoaning the high cost of road crashes in terms of its economic burden on Australia, he stated that the cost per crash victim ranges from between $450,000 for a fatality to $6,000 for a victim with minor injuries, and the overall cost of road crashes in 1987 was estimated by the Government's own organisation to be $5.7 billion. In the same statement the then Minister referred to the Federal Government's objectives for road safety, including the construction of better roads. Members of the Government might remember that the former Minister initiated a campaign in which he told us that better roads are safer roads. So according to one of the many previous Ministers who have recently been responsible for roads, the better the road system, the greater the road safety benefit.

On 12 April the former Minister for Transport and Communications Support highlighted the dramatic benefits that road improvements can have on safety, so much so that he expressed the hope that these improvements were not going to be offset by less careful driving which, according to the current Minister in a celebrated press statement, seems to be the only cause of road accidents. That, quite frankly, is a disgraceful approach. The former Minister said at that time:
A huge investment by the Federal Government in roads improvements, increased road safety campaigning and the development of safer vehicles have all contributed to saving lives . . .

He went on to identify a number of major road improvements and compared crash figures on new roads with figures for those they had replaced. To take a couple of examples from that press report, the Minister referred to the Calga-Somersby section of the Pacific Highway saving nine lives a year and the Wyong bypass reducing road crashes by 88 per cent a year.

That Minister went further in highlighting the benefits of the Wyong bypass. He pointed out that, because of the reduced number of deaths and injuries on the Wyong bypass, the savings to the community were estimated at $9.6m per year. That was just one project. In fact, as industry representatives have pointed out, on some of these projects the rate of saving lives has worked out at about one life per year saved for each $4m in road building effort undertaken; yet the Government is cutting road building expenditure by $450m a year. The fact is that it cannot get away from taking responsibility for this matter. If one Minister is prepared to say that road expenditure saves lives, another Minister cannot say that the major problem with road safety and road deaths is careless driving. They cannot have their cake and eat it, too.

The current Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support has attacked the Australian Automobile Association for pointing out the number of lives that will not be saved because of the $450m a year that the Government has slashed from Australia's road building effort. In a statement on 11 October, to which I have alluded previously, the Minister advised us that he was enormously disappointed with the nature of the campaign being conducted by the Australian Automobile Association. The Minister went on to say:

. . . it is counter-productive to have campaigns of this kind which can leave the motoring public with the impression, for example, that the number of crashes on the roads, including almost 3000 fatalities during the last year, result from the condition of the roads. . .
The previous Minister was busily singing from the tree tops about how the Government had saved lives by spending money on roads. The Minister continued:

These organisations, our research, public knowledge, public understanding, indicate quite clearly that the main reason for the level of crashes and for the level of fatalities rests with the motorists themselves because they do not modify their driving behaviour to fit the conditions of the roads upon which they happen to be travelling. . .

What a ridiculous statement to make! When the roads degenerate into dirt tracks, what are we supposed to do-get out and walk beside the cars? One could gain the impression from this almost hysterical response that road improvement would make absolutely no contribution to saying lives and reducing the number of road crashes. We have this totally contradictory approach by two successive Ministers.

Before the current Minister criticises others for their assessment of what losses have been caused by this Government's road funding cutbacks, he should come clean and provide his own estimates of how great those losses are. I will be interested to see whether he does so when he sums up this debate. Nor can the Government hide behind the tired old excuse trotted out by the current Minister that anyone who wants more money spent on roads must tell the Government where to cut other programs. On 17 August he acknowledged that it would be possible to spend more funds on roads-for example, a further $420m-`but it would have to come from other Federal programs'.

It is a shame that the Minister was not in the confidence of the Treasurer, because the Treasurer had the answer, had the Minister been able to talk to him before the last Budget was handed down. It did not have to come from other Federal programs; the Treasurer gave it away by cutting $400m from the beer excise. The last thing that this country needs is cheap beer when our roads are falling to pieces. In fact, it was to be part of another of the Treasurer's too-clever-by-half schemes to keep the lid on an increasingly restless work force who know that their standards of living have been eroded as never before under this Government. We thought that the policy of keeping the masses quiet by keeping them drinking went out in Victorian times. It says a lot for the approach of this Government and the contempt this Government has for the people of Australia. Australians have not even got the lower beer prices that the Government promised, but they are still paying for it with poorer roads because the Government indexed the sales tax on beer.

As I said earlier, this legislation marks another sorry chapter in the Government's failure to act on its self-imposed program of micro-economic reform. The transport portfolio abounds with similar sorry stories of the failure of the Hawke Government to come to grips with the real issue. The story is repeated everywhere one looks-on the waterfront, in coastal shipping, in the escalating losses of Australia's rail systems, and the failure of the Government to establish an environment in which there can be genuine competition between modes and within industries. The Government's Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) recently reported that industry reforms could shave $2 billion a year from Australia's transport bill, boosting gross domestic product (GDP) by 1.6 per cent. But what has the Government done? Nothing. EPAC calculated that annual savings of $850m could flow from reform on the waterfront; $200m could be saved by reform of coastal and trans-Tasman shipping; and $700m could be saved from reforms of bulk land transport, particularly coal and wheat. And what has the Government done. Nothing. In fact, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) has set up another task force to look at these matters.

Transport savings of $2 billion would generate a rise in GDP of $4 billion. This Government's road funding cuts stand with these other lost opportunities as testimony to the level of benefits that we have forgone because of the way in which this Government has approached the real transport issues. By any measure or examination, it has failed. It has failed by repeatedly cutting road funding. It has also failed to come to grips with the real issues in terms of transport efficiency.

It is now over 12 months since the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport released its recommendations. I would be interested to hear what the Government has done in that regard. I am sure that, in summing up this debate, the Minister will tell us that he has consulted with State colleagues on an industry proposal that would enable the Federal Government to open up grain and similar markets to genuine competition. The reality is that still nothing has been done; not a thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Set up a working party.

—That is right; set up another working party. Because of the Government's incapacity to act on the real issues, how long does Australia have to tolerate this sort of policy paralysis? The $4 billion worth of contributions to the economic development of this country estimated by EPAC is going begging, simply because the Government is sitting on its hands. Based on the EPAC estimate, the Government's delays in making genuine transport reforms are costing this country over $5m a day in transport costs and taking almost $11m a day from Australia's gross domestic product. Nor can this Government say that its hands are tied-that it must wait on the States. That is another tired old excuse that just will not wash any more. The Australian public have had enough.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has been in power now for over 5 1/2 years-in fact, I think it is in its sixth year. The Government knows it has the power to act. It has acted in respect of vehicle mass limits to establish a national uniform standard. It can lead the way in opening up markets to genuine competition that will cut Australia's costs. The absurdity of what this Government has offered as excuses for inaction over its 5 1/2 years in office would be laughable if it was not costing so much.

What does this legislation offer? Apart from further expenditure cuts, we find the Government seeking to pat itself on the back for establishing a new category of national arterial roads. Why has the Government established this category of roads? The Minister's second reading speech informed us that it was to increase the contribution made to Australia's economic development by the Commonwealth road program. How much greater would the contribution be if the road program also included the $450m a year that this Government has stolen from Australian road users? The Opposition supports the concept of the national arterial roads being added to the established road categories. It is one of the few redeeming features of a very disappointing piece of legislation. When the Bill is discussed in the committee stage I will move a number of amendments, on this and other issues, that have been circulated in my name.

It is appropriate, however, at this stage to highlight the most blatant abuses which the Government has attempted to perpetrate upon Australia's road users and this Parliament as part of the legislation. We were told that the share of excise charges to be paid into the trust fund is to be called a road user charge. The major road user organisations have advised the Government that it is no such thing. The ARTF, the AAA, the Australian Bus and Coach Association and the Australian Livestock Transporters Association have left the Minister in no doubt about their opposition to this latest attempt at the trick with mirrors. In fact, the Treasurer gave the game away, the day after this program was announced, during his appearance at the National Press Club. The Treasurer made it clear that the Government's approach was to decide on a level of road funding expenditure and then work out the sums necessary to convert that to a share of fuel excise. He completely disowned any commitment by this Government to any sort of genuine hypothecation of fuel excise to fund Australian roads.

Given these sorts of comments and the Hawke Government's record, road users are naturally nervous about what the Government might do next. Any words of reassurance ring hollow, given the Government's record. For example, promises on road funding have been broken within two short months. Users ask: How can any genuine government attempt to describe an excise rate that moves in the opposite direction to road use as a road user charge? If road use goes up, the excise rate goes down so that the level of funding is unchanged. It is yet another desperate attempt by this pathetic Government to try to hide from the community its appalling record on road funding. It is a trick with mirrors. It is a nonsense of the highest order.

Throughout this legislation there are attempts to ensure the Government eliminates any parliamentary involvement in road funding decision making. Notwithstanding its already appalling record on road funding, it wants this Parliament to give it power arbitrarily to alter road funding levels. In too many instances, this Bill seeks to allow the Minister the opportunity to cut the already desperately low level of road funding by the mere stroke of a pen. `Trust us' the Hawke Government says, when its record shows it can take as little time as two months to break a promise. This legislation should not be passed in its current form. As it stands, in the last two years of the Australian centennial roads development program the legislation would enable the Government to cut the excise rate going to road funds to virtually nil should this be so determined by the Minister after consulting with the Treasurer. We know what the Treasurer's attitude is to cutting things he does not care about. The poor transport Minister of the day would be summoned to the Treasurer and told what he was to do and that would be the end of it. Some consultation! The Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, who is at the table, knows that is the case. There will be no process for the Parliament to review the decision. There will be no public debate.

That is the attitude of this Government because it gags anything that is a bit uncomfortable for it. We see that today and, as I said, this Bill is under a guillotine. The Hawke Government is so ashamed of its appalling record that it wants to hide road funding in the darkest recess of the Government's darkest closet. Probably the only thing behind it is Aboriginal affairs. Quite frankly, that is where the record of this Government on road funding belongs. It is a total national disgrace.

Not only does the Government wish to have such incredible flexibility vested in it alone; it also wants to maintain similar flexibility with regard to indexation adjustments during this last two-year period. Indexation would not happen as a matter of course but rather when determined by the Minister. Again it is an indication of how untrustworthy this Government is. Asking the Parliament to pass this legislation in its current form is like giving keys to the blood bank to Dracula. In other words, we again find this cavalier approach. Any balances in trust funds at the end of the existing Australian land transport program and the ABRD program or this program are to be applied not in accordance with legislation for the purposes for which the funds were allocated but rather as determined by the Minister. We can see what would happen if the Treasurer took a liking to grabbing the funds. We could all speculate just how the Minister would determine how those funds would be used. I do not think he would stand up very long to the Treasurer.

One of the most obnoxious attempts to further rip off road users is the selection of the indexation factor to maintain this pathetic level of road funding. The Government has already achieved one cute trick which enables it to increase continually the rip-off of Australian motorists and industry by indexing excise rates each six months to the consumer price index (CPI). Because the amount road users pay to the Government is indexed to the CPI, a normal person would regard it as fair enough if the road program's share were also indexed in the same way so that relativity between what one paid and what one got would remain.

The Australian land transport program was certainly intended to operate in that way although we have seen what the Government did to that. However, this time the Government does not even bother with that sort of facade. Instead we find the Government is to index the road funding share by the implicit price deflator (IPD). The House will not be surprised when I tell it that over the last three years the implicit price deflator has increased by some 8 per cent less than the CPI. I wonder why the Government is doing that? Again the Government has deliberately selected an index to minimise its financial contribution to road funding.

It is the meanest sort of penny-pinching I have even seen by a government. It is certainly the meanest approach to legislation that I have seen introduced in this Parliament. It is a further indictment of the way the Government has tried to be too clever by half in treating road users with absolute contempt. The Minister, in his desperate struggle to find something positive to say, has come up with a new comparison to try to camouflage the Hawke Government's record. He has elevated the old adage of `lies, damned lies and statistics' to a new plateau.

As I have shown, the Hawke Government's road funding record speaks for itself. It provides cuts of $450m a year and for the share of fuel excise going to roads to be reduced to an all time low of less than 23 per cent. Those opposite cannot get away from those simple facts. The motorists of Australia know it. If the IPD is such a wonderful measure of road costs one would be given to understand that the Minister's road funding comparisons with the funding of the previous Government must surely have been made using that index. In fact, I specifically asked the Minister whether his comparison was made using that index, and, if not, why not. A situation where the amount road users pay and what they get in return are indexed to the same series is fair to all. But this Government does not believe in fairness and equity, does it?

This Bill contains a similar provision to the ABRD program to allow some funds to be directed to upgrading urban public transport services. Industry has highlighted how various Commonwealth urban public transport programs have disadvantaged public transport users and road users. Virtually no Commonwealth funds have been directed to areas served by private operators such as those in the western suburbs of Sydney. The only money the Commonwealth has spent is a couple of hundred thousand dollars in Darwin. The Commonwealth Government must establish some arrangement which makes the distribution of these urban public transport funds more fair and equitable. As I stated earlier, amendments to these and other provisions will be pursued when the Bill is in the committee stage.

We have before us one of the most pathetic pieces of legislation ever introduced into parliament. It is legislation which perpetuates the Hawke Government's approach of shirking its responsibility to provide the road system Australia's economic and social needs demand. It is a further chapter in the Government's appalling record in road funding. It is not legislation which the Opposition could support in its current form. It is legislation which, in addition to the changes we will be proposing, should be passed only if the Government is prepared to return the level of funding established by the coalition when it was last in government. As a government, it has stolen $450m from road users while imposing a massive burden through increases in amounts they must pay. It has squandered a similar amount in a way that deserves the community's contempt. It will not get any votes from it. It has shown that it is incapable of delivering micro-economic reforms. I formally move the amendment that has been circulated in my name:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`the bill be withdrawn and redrafted to provide for the indexation factor to be related to the all groups consumer price index, being the weighted average of the 8 capital cities, rather than the implicit price deflator for gross non-farm product'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite obvious from listening to the shadow Minister for transport and aviation, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), that his frustration at being on the Opposition side of the House is showing. But he will have to be content with that for many years to come. We are in government and we will be in government for many more years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill continues the outstanding Federal commitment to road expenditure since 1983. With the passage of this Bill, road expenditure will be $7,390m by the end of 1988-89. As a Queenslander, I am pleased that in outlays Queensland has received $1.529 billion, the second highest of any Australian State. In my own electorate the Bruce Highway is an important part of the national highway system. I am sure the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) would agree with me when I say that the Maryborough to Childers section of that highway has been significantly upgraded and improved. The section from Childers to Miriam Vale is today far safer than it ever was.

The projects which are currently under way and will have a beneficial effect on my electorate include the Benaraby to Rockhampton upgrading. This will be widened for 11.2 kilometres. The estimated cost will be $3.1m, with $1.9m approved so far. The traffic flow along the Bruce Highway will also improve with the $20m Nambour bypass, of which $14m has been approved to date, and $7m for the Maryborough bypass. These are all good, positive development projects which are of enormous benefit to visitors to Queensland and commuters within my electorate.

The road funding effort meant that by September 1986 Australians could, for the first time, drive around the perimeter of Australia on a sealed road. We have heard from the Opposition that something like $5 billion that should have gone to roads has been stolen over a period of years. But the Opposition has not had the courage to say where it would take any extra funding from. Would it take it from the pensioners, health, housing or education? We have seen a steady stream of shadow Ministers come into this House and say that they would give more money to their own portfolio areas. At the same time, the Opposition shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), says that he would cut outlays and bring in tax cuts. A six-year-old child would recognise that that is economically impossible. They have the luxury of being in opposition, where they will be for many years. So they are not accountable. But we on this side of the House are accountable. We have the guts to stand up and be counted and to make the tough decisions that are necessary in every portfolio. It is little wonder that John Elliott will not come and join his colleagues. Who would want to be associated with a bunch of failures?

All members of parliament would be aware of a blatantly political campaign being run in Queensland by the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland (RACQ) and by motoring organisations in other States criticising the road effort of the Federal Government. The dishonesty of this campaign totally neglects the role of State and local governments in road funding. Most of the roads the RACQ singled out in its campaign come under the jurisdiction of State or local governments. The RACQ uses 1983-84, a record year in road funding expenditure, as its benchmark for road funding. It operates under the ludicrous logic that, if there is record spending, record amounts must be spent each year. The road funding effort of the Hawke Government in its first five Budgets exceeded the road funding of the Fraser Government in its last five Budgets. It is a pity that the shadow Minister did not mention that fact. Expenditure on roads as a percentage of total Budget outlays was 1.72 per cent in the last five years of the Fraser Government compared with 1.82 per cent under the Hawke Government. These are facts, not fiction.

In Queensland, the Federal Government provides about 50 per cent of the expenditure of the Department of Main Roads. In my electorate, the Federal Government approved $1.66m for the building of a bridge across the Burnett River at Gayndah. The previous Federal member did so little about pushing the State Government to begin the bridge that, in 1987, the National Party State member for the area tried to announce the commencement date as a new project. The State Government should get its act together and complete the bridge. Nowhere does the RACQ mention this type of thing in its advertising. It has been mute in its criticism of the State Government for building toll roads. Toll roads are now going to be built on the Sunshine Coast in the electorate of the Queensland State Finance Minister, Mr Austin. This has just about split the local National Party organisation asunder; yet nothing has been said by the RACQ in Queensland about toll roads.

Another outrageous piece of cynicism in regard to road funding has occurred with the performance of local government. Recently the Banana Shire Council spent thousands of dollars of ratepayers' money constructing road signs criticising the Federal road effort. How ludicrous! From March 1983 until June 1987, the Banana Shire Council received $2.28m in Federal grants for unspecified road works. This was about double what was received by every other shire in Hinkler. As a proportion of total outlays, the Banana Shire Council's road funding effort declined from 57.66 per cent in 1983-84 to a miserable 31.35 per cent in 1984-85. It rose slightly to 55.06 per cent in 1985-86. In 1983-84, the Council spent $6m on roads. This figure declined to $5.3m by 1985-86. So, we have a shire criticising the Federal Government when its own funding for roads has slumped, not just in terms of its total budget outlays but also substantially in real terms. Again, the RACQ is nowhere to be seen in this debate to keep local governments honest in road funding.

Sadly, many local governments and local shires in Queensland are nothing but the guerilla training grounds for National Party candidates. I have a text here from an interview on radio 4QR on 2 November with Mr Vern Mathieson, the General-Manager of the RACQ. He said:
Local authorities know what to do, they've got the expertise, they know what's got to be done, they just don't have the money.

That is not fact. They do not have the priorities. It is about time Mr Mathieson put the facts clearly. If he is ignorant of the facts, I will be more than happy to tell him what they are. Mr Mathieson also said:
. . . we're not being political . . .
Not much! He went on to say:

We are putting just as much pressure on the Federal Opposition to stand up and be counted and at the moment there's a deafening silence from them which is disgraceful, they haven't got the guts to stand up and say this has gone on for long enough and give a firm commitment to do something about it.

We all understand why. It is because the Opposition does not have a leader. It does not have a policy. As I said before, it is little wonder that John Elliott does not want to come and join the Opposition. He is far too successful making money with his company to join the-how shall I describe it? It is pretty hard to find a word that adequately describes the Liberal Party at the moment. It is certainly wracked with dissension and internal divisions. Its members could not win a B grade football match at the moment. The leadership of the RACQ is misleading its members, is dishonest. If it can afford to splash around other people's money in what is little more that a one-sided road funding debate, it can afford to drop its membership fees or to sponsor more defensive driving courses.

I now wish to turn to the question of local authorities in the road debate. In my electorate I have a dozen local authorities with 137 local councillors. In Bundaberg, I have three local authorities situated in the one city block. There are 32 councillors serving 44,000 people. A similar situation exists in Warwick, Cambooya, Mackay and Townsville. It would appear that there is not much economy of scale in the road operations of such shires and councils. A South Australian study carried out by Easton and Thomson in the Australian Journal of Public Administration may provide a clue to a solution. Their study found that, if councils were amalgamated, the savings in road funding would be enormous. Why does the Opposition not talk about that? Again, it is because local governments and shires in Queensland are the guerilla training ground for their own party hacks.

I am suggesting that an inquiry should be undertaken in Queensland before such amalgamation occurs. Obviously, with some far-flung shires it would be difficult to see much improvement. But in areas like Bundaberg and Warwick it might be possible for councils to get together and to amalgamate the road component of their administration if full amalgamation is not possible.

Let us analyse the benefits. The study indicated that combining two councils so as to achieve a combined council with twice the road length of the separate councils would result in a massive 91 per cent decrease in the per kilometre cost of road maintenance. It is a great pity that the shadow Minister does not understand, or has never read, this paper. Administration, overhead and road expenditures comprise 43 per cent of total local government expenditures. If we have to watch our costs, surely to goodness local and State governments should have to do the same. We have been propping them up for the last five years. It is about time they stood on their feet and were accountable.

I stress that only an inquiry can determine which councils are suitable to take on such a task. No responsible State local government Minister can ignore a report like that. It may well be that some local authorities can at the very least get together and share the road element of their administration. There is nothing more tragic than for existing shires that are struggling to survive each outlaying over a quarter of a million dollars for a grader and seeing those graders lie idle two or three days a week. The same people who run these shires promote private enterprise yet want to be subsidised in a social respect by the Federal Government. At the same time they kick the Federal Government for having to raise taxes to do so. In other words, they do not want the responsibility of making tough decisions themselves.

I turn to the construction of a new bridge across the Burnett River in Bundaberg. The bridge was promised to Bundaberg by the Bjelke-Petersen Government but was never built. The current State Minister for Public Works, Main Roads and Expo, Mr Gunn, now says that there is no money for it. It is time for the State Government to look at ways of funding the project. This year all port authorities have to pay tax to the State Government. The State should examine the local port authority to see whether it has idle funds or else could waive the tax on the understanding that the funds would go to the construction of a new bridge, given the fact that the existing bridge is almost falling down and is unsafe for traffic and for pedestrians, which is a disgrace. The port authority would be an ideal body to liaise with, because this year it has, as a member, the head of the town planning committee of the Bundaberg City Council. The bridge, at last report, was to connect with Walla Street in Bundaberg City.

At the very least, the State Government should announce the route of the bridge so that unscrupulous people cannot profiteer at the expense of the rest of the city. There have been rumours that there is a change to the route involving Scotland Street. If Scotland Street is superior, the State should make certain that the names of all companies and individuals to be affected are made public. In this way people can judge for themselves just what is right. There is a constant complaint in Bundaberg that people with inside knowledge can benefit at the expense of the average person. The bridge is very important to people in Bundaberg, particularly those living in north Bundaberg. It is essential too to the expanding fruit and vegetable industry and to the Bundaberg Sugar Co. Ltd.

Queensland has received fair treatment with road funding. However, if the Queensland Minister for Main Roads cannot persuade his Cabinet to spend more money on building a bridge in Bundaberg one of the other statutory authorities may be the answer. I believe the Port Authority may be the best bet. The bridge would certainly ease problems of transportation of both sugar cane and raw sugar. It will form an important function in providing transport access to the port. The Department of Main Roads should give consideration to this proposal.

I congratulate the Minister on this Bill. I believe it continues the Federal Government's road funding program. It is a great pity that honourable members on the other side of the House are prepared to say how much money they would spend without saying where they would get it from. As I said, they will take from the elderly, pensioners, health, housing and education. We on this side are prepared to stand up and be counted. We are not prepared to walk away from any issue or any problem we face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill sets out the directions that the Government will follow in relation to its responsibilities regarding road construction. In so doing, it consolidates the mechanisms that it will use. It sets out a program which deals with the needs of yesterday. The evidence that the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) gives in his speech in support of that program is an apology really for a program which Australia needs to build up its transport links. In fact, I feel sorry for the Minister. He is new to his task and I have enough regard for him to believe that he would not have written that drivel in support of his program. He has been fulfilling the program set out by that wily coyote of government finance, the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, who in the May statement clearly set out the future denigration of the Australian road program under this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn for evidence to the second reading speech of the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support and the propaganda he proposed in the first two pages of it to justify what Australia will soon know as a most inadequate program in support of the Australian motorist. On the first page he said:
. . . this legislation will set the direction of road funding towards the year 2001-
God help Australia if that is the standard to 2001-
the centenary of our Federation.
He said that transport would be cheaper, safer and more efficient. On page 2 he had the gall to say:
we have managed to establish an impressive record on the road funding front.

In answer to a question in the Senate on 4 May this year Senator Walsh set out what the relativities are between what used to be an adequate program and support for roads in Australia and what this Government's substitute is. He said that in 1983-84, which was the last program of road funding which was subject to the rules and directions of the Fraser regime, the figure for road grants was $1,593m in 1987-1988 dollars. What is the Minister proposing here? He is proposing $1,215m, which in 1987-88 terms would be lower than the $1,593m in 1987-88 dollars of the Fraser years. The Minister's allocation would be lower in last year's terms, obviously because of inflation. What has he proposed to do? What has he promised? He will maintain the funds for the next two years. He will make no addition. Funds will be frozen in real terms at this year's terms. Transport is increasing at about 4 per cent a year-but the funds are frozen at this year's terms. This is an adequate program? We have made important advances to go down from $1,593m to $1,215m? That is an advance? I think Australians would like to know about that.

It we look further into the program we find that the Minister intends to provide more money for certain new arterial roads by removing funds from other road projects. That has not come out in the debate. The Minister has not said that. By concentrating on a reduced program, of course, he will remove funds from other road projects that are now being supported. It is inherent in the argument. A number of key roads that have financial support will have their funding reduced so that this new emphasis, this new concentration on a new category, can be fulfilled. Again, Australians would love to hear about that.

The emphasis on page 8 of his speech referred again to maintaining funds. He went on to talk about the excise charge rate. This fiddle is supposed to relate 4.95c of the 21.5c a litre collection of excise from fuel to the $1,215m which is being spent on this road program. Of course it is a fiddle. As the shadow Minister for transport and aviation, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), said, when the excise goes up overall the rate will have to be reduced to contain the program in its fixed funding. So it is a fiddle. If the Minister is so explicitly trying to say to Australians, `I'm putting this charge rate up so you can recognise what is being spent out of your excise dollar on Australian roads' I challenge him to arrange to have every petrol pump show the excise. If he wants to be honest about this let every petrol pump show all Australian consumers that the excise is 21.5c a litre. This is just a fiddle. It means nothing to the motorist. Does the motorist think that he is paying only 4.95c a litre in excise? That is what the Minister would like Australians to think. Let the petrol pump show these figures. They would show excise of 21.5c a litre with only 4.95c a litre going to roads. Let the Minister face up to that honesty in government, that truth in advertising, if that is what he wants to introduce to the subject.

The scene is pathetic. We could emphasise the disparity between the Fraser years of extensive and expansive government in its 1983-84 program, especially on Australian roads, and the low expenditure that is projected in our bicentennial year. It locks Australia into a lower than required expenditure on roads. If we look at some of the statements made by experts we will know where all this will lead. In a January 1988 publication of the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics there is a reference to the age of roads. It states:
. . . the mean ages of the networks in 1985 were in the range 10 to 20 years;
rates of construction in 1985 ranged from 0.6 to 3.0 per cent of total network length;
continuation of the 1985 rates of reconstruction would lead to mean network ages in 1995 in the range 16 to 27 years . . .
The general assessment leads one to the view which is outlined in Chapter 1, the introduction to this publication:

The Australian network of sealed rural roads has been established largely since the Second World War with peak growth rates occurring during the early 1960s. As a consequence most of the network is still relatively new and has not, so far, imposed major burdens of reconstruction and rehabilitation. However, sealed roads have finite lives, of the order of 30 years, which lead to the expectation that current rates of reconstruction and rehabilitation may have to be dramatically increased if the assets represented by the road networks are to be maintained.

That is a 1988 report. This Bill, this program, does not provide the finance for the reconstruction that is required by that expert study. The Government is proposing to significantly run down the quality of existing roads as well as being faulty in the construction of new highways.

So under Labor the existing road network will deteriorate to a very serious level. I do not say this without referring to the general aspect which I have found in my political life, and that is that there is some sort of bias inherent in Labor governments against the adequate construction of roads. In South Australia in the late 1960s and early 1970s there was a big effort to acquire significant land corridors for road transportation into and out of the city. Under great pain and public protest and at some expense to the State budget, a corridor was obtained called the north-south corridor, reaching from Anzac Highway to Darlington. The properties were acquired and the corridors were awaiting use.

They stood there, subject to political controversy of course, but the scheme represented the one clear outlet from Adelaide to the south. Adelaide is a city which, by interstate standards, is still relatively free of road blockage; nevertheless, it is in desperate need of planning of future roads so that it can avert the problems of other cities. But what did the State Labor Government do in South Australia? The Bannon Government sold it. The last properties have now been sold and the corridor brought the State Government of South Australia $12m. For $12m it jettisoned the southern corridor out of the city of Adelaide.

I could go on about that for quite a while because it is one of the catastrophes of metropolitan Adelaide-the city which puts on the grand prix and does so much for the show. We all know about the cakes and circuses of the Bannon Government. Yet that Government could sacrifice the one acquisition so desperately needed and so hard fought for and won in South Australia. There is a bias among Labor governments about providing adequate road back-up for the Australian road using community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is that?

—I do not know. As I said when I started, I sympathise with the new Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support that he should have to put his name to such drivel as is contained in that speech and to support the inadequate program contained in that Bill. It is almost a desperate move of government to so cut the needs of such a basic support area of, particularly, the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: If one travels to Europe, as all of us have at some time or another, one sees the close consolidation of 400 million people in Western Europe and 320 million people in the European Economic Community. They are so close set in terms of where they can have their roads and facilities built to such a high standard. In Australia we are so widespread and the need is so much greater to serve this far-flung community, yet we have this deprivation in respect of the standards that were set by previous coalition governments. One is almost bereft of words to describe the dereliction that the Bill and the program set out for Australia, but for the Minister to have the hide to say he is maintaining funds when, in fact, he should be increasing them, illustrates it all.

I am bitterly disappointed with the Bill, and I doubt whether the Minister will stay in the portfolio for very long because I do not think the Australian people will tolerate what he is trying to put over them, nor will they accept the Minister's propaganda. I challenge the Minister, once again, to arrange to have displayed at petrol outlets around Australia what the Minister spends on roads from the 21.5c excise that the Government takes on every litre of petrol sold. When the Minister accepts that challenge, at least I will be willing to listen more amiably to his program for next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) is quite fond of using the word `drivel' to describe arguments, and I can understand that because he certainly gave the House a fair dose of it himself. It is a typical Opposition line to come in here and say that road funds have been cut. That is obvious and clear; I will not come into this place and argue that black is white, but that is the end of the story. Government members hear nothing at all about where the funds can come from to increase the funds for road building.

SPEECH.PARA: The same Opposition cries long and hard that there should be deep and quality cuts in government spending in order to fund tax cuts immediately-not next year, but now-and they should be funded by deep cuts in the Government's spending. Yet every time we have an Opposition spokesman on one area or another coming into this House, there is no question that more funds should be allocated to a particular area. I listened to the debate yesterday about veterans' affairs with some interest. The shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), said, `There is no question of our cutting veterans' affairs funding. This very important section of the community must be looked after. We will be putting more funds into veterans' affairs'. Yet Opposition speakers today have said that the funding for Australian roads is inadequate; there have to be more funds for roads, so let us put more funds into roads.

From where are all the quality spending cuts coming which will fund these great tax cuts which Australians are being offered by the Opposition parties? The reality is that although the particular mechanism we are debating today-the development of this new trust fund and new road program-is, in itself, relatively simple, it does reflect the front line of the economic debate in this country.

The level of government road funding by the Hawke Government has been perfectly consistent with the prevailing economic conditions which the Government has found itself in, and I will explain that in depth later on. It is also consistent with the line put by the Opposition because it plays to particular audiences. It goes to its local government audience and its road user audience and says, `There should be more funds for roads'. Then five minutes later it goes into the next room and talks to another audience and says, `The Labor Government is the biggest taxing, highest spending government of all time! We'll get in there and slash all this spending and cut down all this extravagance'.

That is the inherent inconsistency of the Australian Opposition which it cannot escape and from which it will not be allowed to escape. The Australian people are not stupid; they may recognise that they, as a community, would like to see more funds spent on roads but they know that if that is going to be the case, those funds have to be found through either increasing taxation, diverting funds from other programs, increasing the deficit or reducing the amount we are repaying on our debt.

They are the three alternatives. It cannot be done with mirrors; money does not grow on trees and that is the hard, harsh reality of it all. The Bill generally simply combines the two existing Australian road programs-the bicentennial road program and the Australian land transport program.

A trust fund will be established into which will be paid a specified share of customs and excise duty on motor spirit and diesel fuel. The program itself will run for five years, with years two and three being guaranteed to be maintained in real terms. That is the minimum and a provision exists for the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) to agree to increase the amount spent on the program if the circumstances permit, but there is at least a guarantee floor in the amount to be paid for Australian roads.

Let us briefly look at the history of funding which has created so much interest on behalf of the Opposition. In March 1983 when the Hawke Government was elected Australia was in the midst of a deep economic recession. For the first time since the Great Depression we were experiencing a period of actual negative growth. The Australian economy was shrinking. We had double digit inflation and double digit unemployment, and at that time the Government boosted a number of programs aimed to get the economy moving. One of those programs included a large injection into road funds, because road building itself is a high employment industry and it also boosts local economies, especially with more funds going to local council. The State governments also boost local economies to increase local employment.

If that is combined with programs like the community employment program, which had a specified component also linked to road building, one sees that there was a massive increase in road funds in those early years of the Hawke Government. Funds since then have been slashed, but one cannot divorce that from the overall economic context because Australia's economic conditions changed also in that time. We went from a situation where commodity prices were quite high and then collapsed. We saw a massive decline in what the world was paying for our exports and, as a result of that and the fall in the Australian dollar, we saw a large increase in the amount of our international debt.

One cannot pretend that those factors had no influence on government decisions. They obviously did. As a reality, the Government had to take steps which meant a reduction in the Government's call on domestic savings. That meant government spending was reduced, so the pressure on domestic demand and the call on private savings were also reduced. Therefore, there were cuts in government spending; and this year the Government is running a Budget surplus in order to start retiring the large amount of debt which successive governments have accumulated year after year by running Budget deficits.

All that means that programs and projects have had to come under very close scrutiny, and some have been cut. What has happened to road funding must be put in that overall context. It is pointless, artificial and hypocritical to highlight road funding and point to the fact that funding has gone down, yet say nothing about the surrounding circumstances, about government spending as a whole and about the prevailing economic conditions. Road funding has been reduced because the conditions which allowed money to go into road funding have changed. That is the reality of it, and there is no easy way around it.

This particular program sets a level of funding which is adequate in terms of payments to both the States and local government. It must also be remembered that both the States and local government receive large parcels of untied grants, which they then spend according to their priorities. If local councils, for example, believe that road building is a high priority for their particular area, they are then obliged to allocate Commonwealth financial assistance grants to road building. They have to put off building a cultural centre or a sporting complex or a new swimming pool if road building is the highest priority. Instead of building an infrastructure for water works or sewerage works, they can put the money into the building of roads. That is a decision for an individual council to make.

This Government has had to make tough decisions. As much as possible, it has attempted to quarantine the most disadvantaged in our community-pensioners, veterans and those on low incomes-from the effects of those decisions. Through the social welfare program, it has attempted to give more money to single-income families through the family assistance supplement. It has attempted to look after those people who need help. That means that other ranges of government activities must come under close scrutiny; and funds have been reduced across the board. That is why funding for Australian roads has been decreased.

If the Opposition is serious in its attempts to convince the Australian community that more money should be spent on roads, I challenge members of the Opposition to nominate how much should be spent on roads and where the money would come from. That is not asking too much; I think it is a fairly straightforward request. Do members of the Opposition propose to slash other programs? Where are those programs? By how much would they slash them? Would they increase other taxes to pay for it? Would company tax go up? Would indirect taxes go up? Would personal income tax go up? Alternatively, are those opposite simply saying, `Well, we will give up the idea of starting to pay back some debt and we will start running Budget deficits again'? Which of those three alternatives does the Opposition suggest the Government should look at to provide more funds for roads?

There is a great furphy running around that petrol taxes are at high levels and that not enough is given from petrol taxes. That really misses the point. It is not argued that money from tobacco taxes should go back into the tobacco plantations or other areas related to smoking. Nor is it argued that money from beer excise should go back into hotels or into areas related to beer. Petrol excise and taxes are a means of collecting government revenue-no more and no less. There is no magic in linking the amount of petrol tax to the amount spent on roads.

The reality is that an adequate amount should be spent on roads. Whether that money comes from petrol taxes, income tax or company tax really does not matter; it must be raised through one of those mechanisms. If it is not raised through increased taxes, it has to be raised by scrapping other programs. When the Opposition comes to grips with those realities and puts forward concrete proposals about where the money is coming from, its proposals to expand road funding will be taken seriously and will be given credibility. Until the Opposition does that, it will remain a bit of a joke. The Opposition is trying to keep one section of the community on side while approaching another section of the community and saying that it would cut spending and provide tax cuts. That simply does not add up. The Opposition knows it does not add up; and it is being less than honest with the Australian community for claiming otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch), spoke with some conviction and at great length. I shall pick up on his final remarks about where the money goes. When the proposed graduate tax was being debated, the Australian public believed the money raised would go into general revenue. The people of Australia do not believe that all taxes such as the petrol excise should be pumped into general revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate gives me the opportunity of speaking on the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill. The Bill can only be described as a disgrace. The end effect, and the bottom line, of the legislation is once again to rob the motorist of his or her entitlement to a reasonable standard of service, a right earned by the massive taxes paid annually by motorists across the nation.

Australians will remember the Hawke Labor Government as the Government that took more revenue than ever before at the petrol pump, at the motor registration bureau and in sales tax-and as the Government that gave back the least. Make no mistake, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) regards motorists as nothing more than a convenient source of revenue. In this financial year, oil taxes alone are expected to total $7 billion. The Treasurer will scoop up more than $2 billion from crude oil, nearly $5 billion from petroleum products and, in total, oil taxes will make up nearly 10 per cent of the Federal Government's overall revenue.

During the past 5 1/2 years of the Hawke Labor Government, the Federal Budget has quadrupled-it has multiplied four times, from $20 billion per year to more than $80 billion per year. Fuel taxes have been a major contributor. They have been increasing to the point where, today, approximately 50c of every dollar motorists spend on petrol now goes to the Federal Government's general revenue account, which makes a mockery of the previous speaker's attempts to gloss over that fact.

Last year, only personal income tax earned more revenue for the Government than taxes on fuel. Australians should be aware that personal income tax has been increasing at a rate to challenge oil taxes. One of the underlying and fundamental principles in the Treasurer's latest Budget is that the average rate of inflation for the current financial year will be 4.5 per cent-which would be admirable. Anyone who keeps abreast of the news will know that the Treasurer's projection has not been doing too well. Inflation does not stand an iceberg's chance in hell of averaging 4.5 per cent for the 1988-89 financial year.

It is interesting to note that one of the major contributors to the so-called overheating of the economy is the Hawke Labor Government's petrol taxes, which make up a 5 per cent weighting in the consumer price index (CPI) calculation. In fact, if the Treasurer were to reduce oil taxes by 10 per cent, it would mean a drop in revenue to the Federal Government of a mere $700m out of nearly $7 billion, but it would mean a drop in the price of petrol at the petrol pump of 2c to 3c per litre. The CPI would then undergo a massive turnaround of 0.5 per cent, which would be a substantial realignment.

The benefit to the consumer would be immediate and considerable. Consumers now pay approximately 30c in tax for every litre of petrol or diesel that they buy. Every time they fill their tanks they pay almost $20 in tax. For the average family, that is about $1,000 per year, after income tax, which is a lot of money to try to save on the average salary of some $400 per week.

While fuel taxes account for almost 10 per cent of Federal revenue, spending on roads accounts for less than 2 per cent of Federal outlays. Despite the fact that motoring is an essential part of life for the vast majority of Australians, it attracts luxury taxes at every turn. But the cost to the nation of allowing our massive road infrastructure to deteriorate steadily pales into insignificance next to the tragic toll which will be exacted in human lives. Although it is the motorist who is the cause of traffic accidents-for a variety of reasons such as fatigue, frustration and inattention-it is naive in the extreme to imply that traffic conditions and road conditions are not major contributing factors to those reasons. We cannot keep putting more and more traffic on the same road and not have more accidents and mishaps.

Because of the Hawke Labor Government's pathetic record on road funding, the States now spend some 60 per cent of their works expenditure on maintenance. Naturally, that amount comes from their Budgets, which come from rates and taxes paid by businesses, taxes which are added to the cost of their products, which is then paid by the consumer. Payroll tax is another business tax which is then passed on to the consumer, as are council rates and water rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101a. The debate may be resumed at a later hour when the honourable member will have leave to continue his speech.

—I refer the Treasurer to the recent failure of the merchant bank Rothwells Ltd. I ask the Treasurer: Did Rothwells Ltd comply with its obligations pursuant to section 11 of the Financial Corporations Act 1974 and submit regular monthly and quarterly returns to the Reserve Bank of Australia setting out its financial position? If so, did those returns give any early indication of the extent of Rothwells' impending financial difficulties? Did the Reserve Bank, pursuant to its powers under the Act, seek any further information from Rothwells on its financial position? When did the Reserve Bank first inform the Treasurer of its concerns about Rothwells' financial position and the possible consequences for the stability of the Australian financial system? Did the Treasurer or the Reserve Bank take any action in relation to the developing situation at Rothwells? If so, what was it; if not, why not?

—As far as I can recall, the Reserve Bank kept an eye on Rothwells at the time of its immediate problems post-October 1987, as it did with other corporations. At the time I know the Bank was speaking to parties associated with Rothwells; it told me that. As far as I know, the Bank maintained an interest in Rothwells to some extent. To what extent I could not be certain. I could not be certain as to how deep that interest was. I could not be certain as to what documents Rothwells may or may not have lodged with the Reserve Bank, but I could find out and let the honourable gentleman know.

—I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon a parliamentary delegation from the United Kingdom, led by the Rt Hon. Sir Bernard Braine, DL, MP. On behalf of the House, I extend a warm welcome to the members of the delegation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HEALTH INSURANCE FUNDS: COVERAGE OF LONG TERM PATIENTS IN HOSPITALS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Community Services and Health, concerns the future of long term patients in Victorian bush nursing hospitals. I refer the Minister to recent threats by some Victorian health insurance funds to withdraw cover for some long stay patients in Victorian hospitals and, in particular, bush nursing hospitals. Can the Minister inform the House as to the action the Government is taking to ensure that these funds continue to pay hospital benefits for nursing home type patients?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the threats to which the honourable member for Burke has referred. I just want to put on record quite clearly the practices in this matter. It has been a longstanding practice for nursing home type patients to be accommodated in both public and private hospitals and for the health funds to pay benefits at a lower nursing home type benefit rate for them. Those provisions were introduced in 1979 by the honourable member for Gwydir. In 1979, when he introduced those excellent provisions, he made quite clear the responsibility of the private health funds to cover those nursing home type patients.

ANSWER.PARA: However, despite the fact that this practice has existed for almost 10 years, two Victorian funds, the Australian Natives Association (ANA) and the Hospital Benefits Association Ltd, have indicated an intention to consider denying benefits to nursing home type patients in some rural and bush nursing hospitals. In particular, the ANA announced that it would cease paying for seven aged patients in the Pyramid Hill Bush Hospital, but temporarily withdrew the threat following intervention from my Department. I regarded that threat and the way it was made as a particularly heartless action because it threatened the security and welfare of many aged people and, of course, engendered a very real fear amongst those patients.

Many of these patients have been contributing in good faith to their health funds for many years in the belief that those 1979 provisions, introduced by the Opposition in government, would be honoured and followed. However, these funds are now seeking to exploit what they believe is a loophole in that 1979 legislation allowing them to abrogate a responsibility which they have accepted for almost a decade. It is the Government's view that the funds have both a moral and a legal obligation to pay. In order to reinforce that obligation the Government will introduce legislation tomorrow clarifying that requirement and confirming the arrangements that have existed since 1979.

In the longer term, the Government is prepared to work with the funds and the State governments on particular problems involving aged and long stay patients. I think all honourable members should note, particularly some of the glib critics on the Opposition side of the House, the real advances that have been made in this area under this Government. I am aware that in the smaller towns multi-purpose facilities providing a range of services-acute services, nursing home services, hostel and home care services-are often the most optimum arrangement. Of the 36 bush nursing hospitals in Victoria, 14 have already approved nursing home annexes; two have hospital annexes; and another has approval in principle for both nursing home and hostel beds. As well, in the past two years the number of bed days taken up by nursing home type patients in Victorian public and private hospitals has dropped by a third, with significant savings for the health funds. It has dropped because of the policies pursued by this Government, because of the success of our expansion of the home and community care program and because of our success with the aged residential program involving nursing homes and hostels.

The Government will continue to pursue such policies and programs to improve the health and community services for the aged in this population. However, in the short term, we are not prepared to allow these funds to threaten the welfare of these patients. I expect that the Opposition will support the legislation when it is introduced.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RICHARD FARMER AND ASSOCIATES PTY LTD

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services as the Minister responsible for the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Has the Minister seen reports of the generosity of a company named Richard Farmer and Associates Pty Ltd, liquor merchants and consultants, which, although it had a loss of $258,000 last financial year, was able five months later to find $75,000 which it donated to the Wilderness Society? Secondly, has the Minister seen reports that the Society thanked the company for its generosity in defraying what it called `expenses incurred earlier in the year'? Were the expenses incurred earlier in the year incurred in support of Australian Labor Party candidates in the Federal election? Will the Minister investigate this apparent case of laundering of election funds and whether any other breach of the Electoral Act has been committed? If he will not investigate that, will he kindly tell us why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that the Wilderness Society submitted a return of electoral expenditure under the relevant section of the Act after the 1987 Federal election and its return disclosed expenditure of $131,938. I am informed by the Australian Electoral Commission that the Society was not required to disclose the $70,000 donation that has been mentioned in a return relating to the 11 July 1987 election, even if that donation was used to cover expenses incurred during that campaign, since the donation was given after the election. Section 305 of the Act--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members would be experts on this matter. I have no doubt that Dr Hughes will be taking note of the mirth of the Opposition, its actions and its information supplied to me as the relevant Minister. If I could just continue, section 305 of the Act, as it will apply to returns to be submitted after the next general election, will require bodies such as the Wilderness Society to disclose donations of $1,000 or more received by them between 12 July 1987 and polling day of the next election, if those donations are used for purposes related to the next election-in other words, the $70,000 donation should be declared at the next election. In any event, Richard Farmer and Associates Pty Ltd is a private company and can make political donations to whatever organisation it so chooses.
