—My question to the Treasurer relates to an article in the Age today, the headline of which is `Small business rebuff for Libs'. The article outlines how Victorian small business leaders are sharply critical of the Federal Liberal Party of Australia and warn that they will be forming closer links with the Labor Government. Can the Treasurer inform the House what policies the Government has put in place in order to assist small business which have led to this timely, yet accurate assessment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the article in the press.

—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. As I heard the end of the question, it referred to the `timely, yet accurate assessment' which allegedly had been made in this article. How does commenting on that fall within the Treasurer's province?
—The question was in order. The Treasurer will answer the question.

—I noticed the article and I will respond to that part of the question which deals with the changes the Government has put in place now systematically over a period of nearly six years to improve the whole economic and business environment of Australia, particularly that for small business. Principally, the Government restored economic growth in Australia in 1983-84 and the economy has been growing strongly in each and every year since 1983-84, only slowing to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) average of around 2 1/2 per cent in 1985-86. In every other year it has been in excess of that. We have had employment growth of 17 per cent; more than 1.15 million jobs which has lifted buoyancy in the economy-the very thing which small business relies upon. It relies upon growth in the economy and on economic business opportunities in order to prosper. At the same time, by our incomes policy, we have reduced real unit labour costs over time so that the costs of running a business are lower and hence the profit share has been restored, which is part and parcel of not only ongoing profitability of small business but also of the retention of higher levels of earnings within small business. Through a floating exchange rate and deregulation we have ensured the competitiveness of the Australian economy-the domestic competition of local products from small business with those from abroad-and through financial deregulation we have guaranteed that small business is now getting financial support from the financial system which it was not getting previously. Importantly, in relation to the tax system we have ensured a flatter and more fair playing field in taxation which particularly supports small business.

ANSWER.PARA: When this Government came to office a dollar of company income in the hands of the small business person was taxed 78c in the hands of the shareholder. That is now 39c with a reduction in the company tax rate and up to 49c with the distribution. Under the Liberals we had a thing called `division 7 tax' which penalised small businesses for not distributing their income, their profits. They were forced to distribute, otherwise they paid a penalty and upon distributing were then taxed at 60c at the margin if they had income above $35,000. They were getting belted 78c out of every dollar-that is how the Liberals looked after small business. Is it any wonder with the imputation system which frees dividends--

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the imputed tax level.

—It is the lowest rate of tax in the OECD for the honourable member's benefit; the lowest rate of tax on distributed income in the OECD is available to small business in Australia, thanks to this Government. Is it any wonder, therefore, that small business people are saying, `We will continue to be close to this Labor Government, we are entirely fed up with the Liberals who do not have a policy. When they were around for 30 years they kept division 7 tax, they kept the double tax on dividends, we had no imputation system and the financial markets would not service our interest'?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Tuckey

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, on a point of order: I first remind you that the question referred to Government policy and, secondly, in support of my point of order I refer you to page 1063 of Hansard of 9 September 1981 in which Mrs Child said:

INTERJECT.PARA: I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. I draw your attention to the Hansard of 27 August. You ruled:
The Minister will answer the question and not engage in irrelevancies, such as contrasting the Government and the Labor Party.
The Speaker on that occasion ruled:
I think it was a very sound decision. I ask the right honourable gentleman-
meaning the then Minister for Trade and Resources-
to draw his answer to a conclusion.
As the Treasurer has concluded answering the question I ask that you ask him to bring it--

TALK.START.PARA: —I haven't.
—He has finished providing the information requested, so I ask you to ask him to draw his answer to a close.
—The honourable member may bring his point of order before the Chair but he may not then rule upon it; the Chair will do that. The Treasurer is in order.

—The whole commercial landscape of Australia has changed. It is now an international economy; it is a competitive economy and there has been more growth in small business in these last 5 1/2 years than there was in the previous 20. The Opposition knows that well. Is it any wonder that a recent poll found that 39 per cent of those interviewed thought the Opposition was indecisive and did not have clear policy statements; only 8 per cent thought it had clear policy plans; only 5 per cent regarded Mr Howard as a strong leader; and 34 per cent thought he was a weak leader. Is it any wonder, therefore, that the small business community has moved away from the Opposition to the Government. In the face of this policy change is it any wonder that all the small business organisations are now barracking for us and belting Opposition members on any radio program on which they appear.

—Has the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs instructed his acting department head, Mr Bob Winroe, to commence discussions or action aimed at transferring the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) staff into the Public Service as officers of his Department? Has the Minister consulted or obtained the support of the ADC board for such moves? Does the Minister intend to pursue a Department of Aboriginal Affairs takeover of ADC staff in order to achieve at least partially the objectives embodied in the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill of destroying the ADC and further limiting Aboriginal control over their own affairs? Is this an attempt to pre-empt growing Cabinet concern over the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) proposal?

—Again we have a range of questions from the happy traveller. I think the question was, `Have I instructed Mr Winroe to do anything in that regard?'. The answer is no. Secondly, when dealing with the question of ATSIC and its future the honourable member talks in terms of the defence of the ADC. I am proceeding with Government policy towards the introduction of ATSIC. We have advertised that widely by virtue of debate in this chamber, to which the honourable member offered very little resistance, I might add. It is now awaiting passage through the Senate and I can assure the House that we will be proceeding with that proposal. But I find the honourable member's question most interesting because for the last two or three weeks a range of accusations has been made, and there has been an attack launched on the ADC the like of which we have never seen before, with calls about its incompetency, et cetera. Opposition members have attacked officers of the ADC at will and now they have the audacity to come in here and talk about the Commission. They have set about to destroy the ADC. We have set about recognising that there needs to be a greater coordination of services for Aboriginal people-something that, incidentally, speaker after speaker on the Opposition side has called for. All I am saying is that we will address the question of ATSIC as soon as those opposite let me proceed with the legislation which sets about rectifying the things they are critical of.
—Can the Prime Minister advise the House of the principles underlying the Government's taxation policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the outset two fundamental principles have governed the development of the taxation policies of this Government. They are fairness and economic efficiency. We have been determined to ensure that all sections of the Australian community pay their fair share of tax, and through such measures as the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, company audits and other anti-avoidance measures the Government has made the tax system in this country fairer and has ensured that those who previously, under conservative administrations, were able to avoid their fair share of tax and add to the burden of ordinary, honest wage and salary earners have at last been brought to account. So much for our fairness, which is acknowledged within this country and internationally.

ANSWER.PARA: Equally importantly, the second principle of this Government's taxation policies has been economic efficiency. We have sought to bring to an end the situation where commercial decisions could be based, as they so often were, on questions of tax shelters and tax avoidance. We have sought to create a situation in which commercial decisions will be based on prospective economic returns. As I say, those two principles have governed the Government's approach to taxation policy from day one, and as part of the implementation of those principles the Government announced in its statement of May this year the termination from 1991 of the tax exemption for goldmining. That was precisely in line with the two principles of fairness and economic efficiency.

May I say that as recently as last month the Leader of the Opposition said at an investment seminar in New York that he would support such a decision. That is the situation. The Government made its position quite clear in May of this year and the Leader of the Opposition has indicated his support for that principle. Unfortunately the Leader of the Opposition was rolled on the issue, and by whom was he rolled? He was rolled by his own deputy leader, the shadow Treasurer. He rolled his own leader on this issue. So the Leader of the Opposition on this important principle got rolled by his deputy leader, by his shadow Cabinet and ultimately by the party room. I suppose it should not have come as any surprise that on an important issue like this the Leader of the Opposition got rolled, because he has been rolled on everything recently. He has been rolled on--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It is always good to hear from the Prime Minister about people who have been rolled, but he was asked a question about the principles underlying Government policy. All the speculation and allegation about what takes place in other places, for example in our party room, have nothing to do with that question. You know that, Madam Speaker, he knows it and everybody here knows it; so I would say that if relevance is to have any meaning in this House you must put him back on the right track.
—The Prime Minister will return to the question.

—The honourable member should get back and start worrying about big Mac. That is what he has to worry about, because he is gone. Madam Speaker, I respect your indication that I should not go on with a list of issues on which the Leader of the Opposition has been rolled. I will not list them any more. I will simply say that he has been in his current position for so long and not delivering the goods that he ought to be paying demurrage. I insist that the principles we have followed from day one are the principles of equity and economic efficiency. They are sensible taxation principles which, as the Treasurer said in answer to an earlier question when he was looking at what has transpired in this country in terms of helping small business and others, have produced in this country a fairer and more efficient tax system. This has been an intrinsic and fundamentally important part of the fact that under the economic management of this Government we have produced an economy and a form of economic management which, as has been said by the Secretary-General of the International Monetary Fund, provide a model for the rest of the world.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS: SPORTS ADVISORY COMMITTEE

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware that an officer of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Department's Sports Advisory Committee, who was identified in Senate Estimates committee hearings, has been, firstly, the subject of sworn allegations of an extortion racket in the early days of the Aboriginal Development Commission; secondly, the subject of allegations relating to misappropriation of funds for the Boomanulla oval in the Australian Capital Territory; thirdly, associated with the National Aborigines Day Observance Committee for the 1987 celebrations in the ACT from which funds are still missing; fourthly, subject to investigations with respect to the women's conference in Chinchilla earlier this year; and, fifthly, recently summonsed by the police for a variety of offences? —Can the Minister for Transport and Communications advise the House of the steps that the Government is taking to ensure that new airline operators will have access to terminals after the ending of the two-airline policy in October 1990?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Deregulation of the aviation industry is an important element of the Government's micro-economic reform agenda. I thank the honourable member for Eden-Monaro for raising this issue. Of course, the Government gave the required three years' notice of the ending of the two airlines policy in October last year. That means that by October 1990 the Government will no longer be regulating four key areas in the aviation industry; that is, controls over the import of aircraft will be removed; controls over the amount of capacity that can be provided by airlines will no longer apply; the Independent Air Fares Committee, which currently sets air fares, will be abolished and fares will be subject to the Prices Surveillance Authority; and new domestic operators will no longer be prevented from operating on trunk routes.

ANSWER.PARA: That is a very substantial step towards giving us a more competitive airline system. There was one major inhibition to such greater competition occurring from October 1990: under existing leases for the terminals in the major airports there was limited access, or probably no access, for new operators at that time. Therefore, the Government has renegotiated terminal leases to enable access to be provided to new operators. Those new leases provide that in each of the major airports which has been transferred to the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) each of the major operators has to provide gates in its terminal if there are no common user facilities available. Common user facilities are available in Brisbane and Hobart. The other airports-Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth, Coolangatta and Launceston-will all have gates available by the provisions in the renegotiated leases. A minimum degree of terminal access is guaranteed to any new operators. In addition, the FAC can also provide sites for new entrants to develop their own terminals if they so wish, or the FAC may elect to construct additional facilities. This means that there are a variety of ways in which terminal facilities can be made available to new operators.

The FAC has recently advertised for expressions of interest from potential new airlines as to facilities they may require beyond those that are available under domestic terminal leases-that is, the minimum level that is being provided through the renegotiation of the leases. The House may be interested to know that there have been quite a few expressions of interest from potential new operators, indicating to the FAC that they are interested in discussing the possibility of additional terminal access.

What is quite clear is that from October 1990 we will have a much freed up aviation industry. It will be a much more competitive industry than that which was presided over for so many years by the previous Government. Unlike those in the previous Government, who now in opposition talk a lot about deregulation and the need for greater competition in industry, this Government has actually moved to bring all of that about. We will undoubtedly have a much more competitive industry, with great benefits to customers and the nation, following the implementation of our policy in October 1990.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MOUNT ISA ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER DEVELOPMENT RECREATIONAL WOMEN'S ASSOCIATION

—Has the Treasurer seen criticism of his statement in the House yesterday on monetary policy? Can the Treasurer indicate to the House the current state of monetary conditions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, bill rates rose by about 0.3 per cent and this morning the Reserve Bank readjusted the rediscount rate to accommodate that shift. As well as reactions from other people, there was a reaction from the shadow Minister for finance, who put out another foolish statement on monetary policy, indicating that the Government has been holding down interest rates and that we have now come clean. The shadow Minister for finance stated:

ANSWER.PARA: He has obviously decided that sufficient time has now passed, since the Victorian State election and the Oxley by-election, to admit that monetary policy has been tightened . . . The truth is that from the very first business day following the Oxley by-election the Reserve Bank started to tighten monetary policy, as evidenced by movements in cash rates.

In today's Australian Financial Review there appears a graph-anyone, particularly any interested person, can see it-which shows rises in interest rates, official and unofficial, from April. Unambiguously, there has been a rise from April. In other words, only the most mischievous person would try to make the fallacious claim that the Government was holding down interest rates when it was obvious that interest rates, for certain reasons, have been rising since April. But even worse, people should not say that interest rates should not be rising, on the one hand, and then, on the other hand, in speeches say that they should be rising. In his speech to the Institute of Public Administration, the shadow Minister for finance said:
Domestically, our main problem is that the economy is overheating.
He went on to say:
The marginal tightening of monetary policy since April of this year seems quite insufficient to have dealt with these forces.
In other words, we need further tightening of these policies. He said in a letter to the Australian Financial Review of 7 October, on page 6:
The market and most of the rest of us-
including him-
are wrong and there is no case for any further tightening of monetary policy.
In other words, in the positive, we are right and there is a case for further tightening of monetary policy. The shadow Minister for finance has been arguing for the tightening of monetary policy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Treasurer is again moving into areas which, as you have pointed out quite correctly during a previous Parliament, are none of his responsibility and he should return to Government policy.
—The Treasurer was in order with the question.

—We have this pantomime of members of the Opposition, particularly the shadow finance spokesman, who apparently has decided to speak on monetary policy in place of the shadow Treasurer-whom he must adjudge to be incapable of speaking on the subject of monetary policy-saying, in the community, `It is shocking that interest rates are rising', but privately saying to business audiences, `Interest rates have to rise', and accusing the Reserve Bank Governor of being directed by the Government to hold down interest rates, when anyone in the market will have known that they have been rising consistently since April. At the end of his shabby press release he used the words `Unless the Treasurer moves decisively to reopen fiscal policy'. This Government has reduced outlays by 5 percentage points of gross domestic product. His sole job in life as shadow finance spokesman is to put up cuts in public spending on behalf of the Opposition. He still has not done it. Senator Stone did not do it. We had statements from the Leader of the Opposition about how they were going to have a finance policy announced in September.
—You are a fake.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo. If he continues to interject, I will name him.

—The fact is that the Opposition has one task, and one task only-to cough up the spending cuts to provide for tax cuts. It is trying to be mealy-mouthed by saying, `This is shocking; interest rates are rising', while privately urging this policy in every economic forum around the country and attacking the Reserve Bank Governor for being a dupe of the Government when he has presided over the most remarkable transformation of a monetary system in the world: the floating of the dollar; the total deregulation of the Australian economy; a terms of trade collapse; a currency collapse; and a massive adjustment of fiscal policy. The shadow Minister, like a mature child, says that the Reserve Bank Governor is on a string being run by the Government, while at the same time he says that interest rates are being held down by that bank and by that Governor in response to political pressures, when it is obvious to any interested observer that interest rates have been rising consistently from April through the period of the State election in Victoria and the by-election in Oxley. There is not one ounce of veracity in any comment made by the Opposition finance spokesman, the honourable member for Wentworth. He has been running around like a delinquent. He is regarded by the Treasury and the Reserve Bank of Australia as a delinquent.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.
—Madam Speaker, I rise on a point of order. During the last answer to a question it was absolutely impossible to hear what the Treasurer was saying.
—I quite agree with the honourable member for McMillan.
—The noise from the Opposition side was such that we could not hear. Either we will need the sound louder or the Opposition will need to be a little bit quieter.
—I accept what the honourable member for McMillan says. The level of noise in the House has been quite atrocious.

—I refer the Minister to the controversy involving the loss of taxpayers' funds and alleged corruption within the Victorian Economic Development Corporation and the intention of the Victorian Government to amalgamate this body with the Rural Finance Corporation. Does the Minister have any concern with this proposal, and what will be the effect upon rural lending if the VEDC's dubious debts and operations become the responsibility of the Rural Finance Corporation operating within the rural adjustment arrangements?
—The answer to the honourable member's question is no. It is purely a matter for the Victorian Government.

—Is the Attorney-General aware of a recent High Court case in Australia involving the journalist Peter Hastings which held that journalists must reveal the names of confidential sources who have given them information? Could the Attorney-General indicate what implications this may have for freedom of the press in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The case concerned was a State matter but the principle of whether information should be disclosed was dealt with by the High Court of Australia. It is important to note that under the rules of the New South Wales Supreme Court a person wishing to commence proceedings against another person whom he cannot identify may seek an order of the court requiring a third person who may be able to identify the defendant to attend before the court and to produce relevant documents. So we are talking about the confined litigation rules of the Supreme Court in New South Wales.

ANSWER.PARA: The High Court described the article in question as containing a very serious type of defamation. The order would not have been made had the Supreme Court been of the opinion that the respondent had an effective remedy against John Fairfax and Sons. But those persons, if sued, had a possible defence but were not prepared to indicate that they would not rely on it. So we were left with the position that somebody was allegedly defamed. The New South Wales Supreme Court rules clearly indicate that the court itself may make an order so that one can identify the person one may sue.

I note also that this case was an appeal from the New South Wales Court of Appeal, which had already found the same way. That in turn was an appeal from a single judge of the Supreme Court of New South Wales who had also found the same way. In every respect we are not basically dealing with the freedom of the press. We are dealing with the issue in law as to what these particular proceedings related to. As I said, whether there was a problem in this sense really related to those proceedings and not so much to defamation.

However, what the High Court had to say is worthy of comment because people are entitled to have some protection. May I tell honourable members that State Attorneys-General, meeting with me in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, have for some time been trying to work out what might be a national law on defamation. We cannot really get any agreement on it because the newspaper proprietors have certain views as to what they feel they are entitled to print. The issue is, of course, that the people who are affected ought to have a right of reply-that is one of the first things that ought to be considered-instead of having to go to litigation. Be that as it may, the High Court in its judgment said this:

It is a fundamental principle of our law, repeatedly affirmed by Australian and English courts, that the media and journalists have no public interest immunity from being required to disclose their sources of information when such disclosure is necessary in the interests of justice.
The High Court declined to set what it called:
such a high value on a free press and on freedom of information as to leave the individual without an effective remedy . . .

The issue basically relates to the fact that somebody was seeking a remedy against somebody who would have been able to give that person the opportunity to sue, and that information was declined. It has no relevance to the freedom of the press other than that. As we know, defamation proceedings can take place at any time. In this particular case, the court recognised the fact that the person sued had a defence. Therefore, there was no opportunity for the plaintiff to succeed. There was an opportunity within the New South Wales Supreme Court rules to ask that somebody else be identified who could be sued.

The States, of course, need to give consideration to this matter. It has implications for defamation laws, which are predominantly matters for the States. It is a question of giving balance between policy considerations arrived at by the High Court and the States themselves.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DOWNS ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDERS CO-OP LTD

—Madam Speaker, you might notice I have a suit on. Maybe I do have an interest in horses. The fact is I do have an interest in horses, like a lot of other people in this place. I do not own any horses. I do know the person the honourable member is referring to, Darby McCarthy, whom I watched ride a lot of horses and who was one of the great jockeys Australia has produced. Darby McCarthy is connected with the organisation that the honourable member referred to. Yes, he sent my wife some photos of a horse on one occasion. And at one time we even contemplated that we might take out a lease on a horse. But we did not, we have not, and there is no horse of mine on Darby's property. I have not been to the property.
—It's not Darby's property.

—It is the property of the community group, the organisation which Mr McCarthy is attached to and part of. The questions the honourable member asked relate to the Aboriginal Development Commission and, as the honourable member knows, it is a statutory body. I will inquire of that particular body and get the full details of the other parts of the question and respond to the honourable member.
—Will the Minister for Administrative Services tell the House what progress has been achieved in streamlining the efficient delivery of services by government agencies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House might recall that approximately a year ago I said that I would be reviewing on behalf of the Government the way in which Government provided services to itself. The criteria that I used were whether the Government ought to be in the business of supplying the service at all and, if so, whether it ought to be charged for it, and whether the service delivery provision ought to be opened up to competition with the private sector.

ANSWER.PARA: Over the last six months we reviewed something like nine divisions in the Department of Administrative Services. We spotted off the way it provides services against a principles paper that I produced earlier this year. We have reformed the operations of the Australian Property Group, the Construction Group, the Australian Government Publishing Service, the Analytical Laboratories and the Surveying and Land Information Group, to name just a few. We have made decisions on a case by case basis. We have made certain decisions about cost recovery, basically as a matter of demand control. We have opened also many of the service areas to competition on the basis that we should open them up to the efficiency pressure of the market.

It is all right for the Opposition to seek to comment on these matters, but it was in power for a long time. It talked a lot about deregulation, about reform of the public sector and about reform of the way government provides services to itself. But what the Opposition is stuck with is that it did nothing about these matters in all the time it was in office.

A great degree of reform has been effected through the process that I have mentioned. While opening up a significant number of government services to competition and to effective cost recovery, we at the same time have been able to protect matters of public interest. As far as the Construction Group is concerned, project management services will be untied totally as from the middle of 1991. It will be put on a full recovery basis regarding its costs from that time. Similarly, for the Property Group, all of the government business enterprises attached to the Commonwealth have been untied as far as their property services are concerned. Departments which are providing significant network services, such as the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security, in areas outside the commercial business districts of major cities will be untied also for lease or fit out.

Another example of the way that we have untied these services and protected the public interest at the same time is the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories. Public interest matters, such as the testing of imported food and drugs, have been tied to the Government Laboratories. All other areas have been untied and are subject to full cost recovery.

So, I am able to assure the House that in this area, where it has been necessary to balance a number of considerations such as employment and the efficient delivery of services and, at the same time, to effect a degree of commercialisation, we have been able to do all of those things and not throw the public interests baby out with the commercialisation bathwater.

DEBATE.TITLE: MOUNT ISA ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER DEVELOPMENT RECREATIONAL WOMEN'S ASSOCIATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek your indulgence to add to an answer.
—The Minister may proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Dawson noted, there is also a difficulty relating to funds made available to the sponsoring body to purchase a bus for a playgroup which has been established by the AICCA. These funds have been inadvertently used for ongoing operations of the agency. My Department and the sponsoring body are endeavouring to rectify that situation at present. No further funds will be provided to the AICCA until the difficulties have been satisfactorily resolved. Departmental officers are also monitoring the agency on a day to day basis. Funds have been provided for a bookkeeper and also special arrangements have been made for a local accountant to set up a financial system for the agency.

I also point out to the House quite clearly that, until these difficulties arose, the Mount Isa AICCA provided an excellent service for Aboriginal children who otherwise may well have had to be sent away to much larger towns out of the Mount Isa setting.

DEBATE.TITLE: LIVING STANDARDS AND FUTURE PROSPECTS FOR ABORIGINAL PEOPLE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The drastic effect upon the living standards and future prospects for Aboriginal people resulting from the Government's indecision and policy vacuum.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat quite clearly the terms of today's matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The drastic effect upon the living standards and future prospects for Aboriginal people resulting from the Government's indecision and policy vacuum.

In drawing that situation to the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), I guess that we could have no better example of it than on Wednesday, 2 November when the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program The World Today conducted the following interview. A Mr Carey commenced his remarks by saying:

Namoi Reserve is out of sight and out of mind. It's decidedly worse than Toomelah, which was called Third World, and which caused Justice Marcus Einfeld to weep. Some 200 people live in 27 dwellings, loosely described as houses. Most are constructed of galvanised iron, some have dirt floors and in summer the water pressure drops leaving Namoi's residents high and dry. In the floods, it's the reverse. This morning I spoke to two Namoi residents and asked them what they thought of the money which had been spent on the Oasis Hotel.
Plenty of references in this place have been made to the Oasis Hotel recently. The interview continued:

Woman: (Not identified). I reckon the Oasis should be closed down. Think about people over here. They've got a foundation, up there, they're buying cars, rent-a-cars, and what are the people doing over here? Bloody still living in tin shacks.
We don't want rent-a-cars or an Oasis. We want homes.
Carey: What then do you think of all the money that is being spent at the Oasis?
Man: (Not identified). The money they spent on the Oasis should be for houses. We don't need another pub in town.
Carey: Where did the idea come then, to spend the money on the Oasis?
Man: Charles Perkins.

He was referring to Mr Charles Perkins, the former Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The fundamental issue that we are debating here today is the way millions of dollars have been wasted and not spent as those people-the Aboriginal people who are still suffering deprivation of the level described-clearly wish it to be spent. It is outrageous. There has been plenty of time to fix the situation.

The Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) was first formed in 1980. The Act was assented to in the fifth month of that year. It was an attempt to give to the Aboriginal people more decision-making powers and to give them money to that effect. Since then, the Parliament has voted $650m to that organisation. Since 1967, when this Parliament first took responsibility for Aboriginal spending, a nominal $3,000m has been spent or, in real terms, $4,600m. That would represent a lot of houses, health treatment and education. But the Minister knows and I know that, certainly in the more remote areas of Australia and as close as the Namoi Reserve, there is no evidence that that money has been spent to good effect. It is a disgrace and, unfortunately, the Minister's administration has been responsible for that for the last five years.

Early problems could be expected, but in February 1984 the Standing Committee on Expenditure decided to look at the Aboriginal Development Commission in a routine way to see how it was going. There was nothing sinister about it, but as soon as the inquiry was announced there commenced a flood of allegations of bad management and corruption. I was so concerned that, when I read in another paper that the then Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission, Mr Perkins, was about to be promoted to the position of Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, I telexed, as a member of that Committee, the then Minister, Minister Holding, requesting him to hold over any decision on that until such time as the Committee had completed its inquiry. I had two reasons for that. The first, of course, was that we felt that the person responsible for the ADC should not be in charge of the Department during those inquiries as quite clearly a lot of evidence would be expected to come from the Department. The other reason was the allegations. The fact is that the Minister ignored that and everything else and promoted Mr Perkins. I suggest that that promotion at that time has contributed substantially to what has occurred since. The Minister put arrogance and idealism ahead of prudence and commonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who, me?

—No, the previous Minister, Mr Holding. This happened in his time. Many of these things occurred then and evidence was given under oath. It caused the Expenditure Committee to say in its report to the Parliament:

SPEECH.PARA: A number of other matters brought to the attention of the Committee have involved serious allegations of mal-administration which in some instances may lead to criminal prosecution.
Mr John Coombs, QC, assisting that inquiry, said that two matters should be referred to the Federal Police. He said:
Perkins was generally an evasive and unhelpful witness from whom the Committee's attempts to seek answers were probably a waste of time.

All this was reported to Parliament in 1985. Strangely enough, the Government's embarrassment was such that towards the end of that inquiry efforts were made to confuse and hose down the issue. In the end, the final report was delivered to this Parliament at midnight, making sure that all media deadlines had passed. That was another disgrace.

The reality is that we are now in a position where the Opposition has attempted to give the Government all that evidence-and I say to the Minister that some of it will make his hair stand on end-but the Minister and his colleagues have declined the offer. We know that there is in camera evidence. We know that it should not be published, but it is obvious that a Minister who genuinely means that he wants to clean things up should look at that evidence and consider it. It has got me beat why the Minister is avoiding looking at that evidence. The Opposition has not suggested that it be published. The Opposition has not suggested anything other than the Minister look at it and have the authority to give it to his inquirers if that is the result. He might in his remarks tell us why-if he is genuine in his desire to clean up this mess in the interests of those people at Namoi and all the others who are suffering because all that money has been wasted-he does not want every scrap of evidence, as he has said he wants, in this place day after day. It might really lift his stocks if during his speech he said that he would welcome such a motion to be put again, and in fact put it himself. He could carry it without our assistance. He will never be trusted in this place while he will not accept the opportunity to look at that evidence. It is amazing.

The allegations in the report in many cases have surfaced again. And now the Government is embarrassed and it is the same old story: what the Government tried to hose down five years ago is coming back to haunt it. It is also haunting the Aboriginal people because another five years of money has been wasted and misdirected while all that has been happening.

We have heard the Minister talk about the Woden Town Club. I am a bit surprised that the Minister thought he should explain to us the difference between a guarantee and a grant. Mr Dowding in Western Australia thought he knew the difference between a guarantee and a grant. With the aid of Mr Burke he guaranteed $150m and the taxpayers of that State will have to pay it. The Minister knows that the Woden Town Club will never make any money. It can barely open its doors. His guarantee has become a grant. Maybe not today, but it is another $300,000 that will not be spent on housing, that will not be spent on health, that will not be spent on the education of Aboriginal people-the fundamental things that the Aboriginals need, and the Minister knows it.

I can mention other grants. There was $514,000 in grants and loans given to that same club over and above the $300,000 guarantee. There were no repayments, there was no interest paid. There was no mechanism in place to get back a bit of money through the ADC, which was seen as a form of merchant bank for the people who need it most. And now is the time the Minister is objecting. There were grants for the Oasis Hotel in Walgett, Nardoola near Moree and Tranby Co-operative College, which got $500,000 for very dubious uses. The other thing that has been around for a long time is Inada Holdings. The Minister's predecessor was deeply involved in that. What about Aboriginal artists? Art is something with which the Aboriginal people can lift themselves by their own bootstraps, yet it has been subject to massive losses, massive empire building, and massive involvement when it was not necessary. About $300,000 was necessary. It had some financial problems, but they were resolved. A lady called Natasha McNamara, who is well known and trusted throughout the community, had got it back on its feet. As soon as that Aboriginal arts operation got back on its feet, the Secretary wanted it. He fought them in the courts. He formed companies. What is the current situation? Four million dollars later a number of the stores that were opened are now closed. In fact, in its last balance sheet that was audited it reported a loss which, when one took into account some tax credits, amounted to a quarter of a million dollars. The Director said, `trading results were a marked improvement on previous years'. That is another $3m or $4m gone. It was not necessary. There was no need for it whatsoever.

Now we have the Townsville Aboriginal and Islander Media Association (TAIMA) issue. We raised the question yesterday and the Minister said he knew about it, that it was down here lobbying the other day. What is its purpose? It is to apply for an FM licence in Townsville. There were 20 expressions of interest in that licence. The only applicant was the inexperienced Townsville Aboriginal and Islander Media Association, which said it could do it if the ADC would lend it about $2m-80 per cent of the project cost. How many houses would that build? The fact is that not one experienced operator would apply for the licence because it knows it cannot make it pay. The two AM licences dropped $1m in the market last year. The Minister told us he knows about it. The application hearing commences on 19 December. Why has the Minister not stopped it? Why is he letting it go on? It is not only going to spend $2m, it will lose tens of millions of dollars every year-more houses not being built. All of those things are working against the people in need. I want the Minister to tell us about that. I do not want him to get into histrionics as he did yesterday. I do not want him to play politics on this issue. We are talking about people's lives.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you been doing?

—I have been very clearly raising the issues of people in need. I put them to the House. The Minister will have the opportunity to say in his speech, `I will not allow the TAIMA issue to continue. I will not allow another $2m of Aboriginal people's money voted by this Parliament to be wasted while the people of Namoi live in tin sheds'. The hearing is set down for 19 December and goodness knows how much money has been spent so far.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the Aboriginal Medical Service? It has become an umpire. It set out as a very good proposition; something to help remote area Aboriginals who fear the institution of white man's hospitals. Now we find it in capital cities. Now we find it in towns that I represent such as Geraldton. Look at the situation in Geraldton. A ministerial submission dated 7 May makes an interesting point. It is a few years old. It was written when the Minister's predecessor was in charge. It states:
In October 1984, the organisation's doctor-
namely, the Geraldton regional Aboriginal medical service-
made allegations in the media that DAA funds had been misapplied and elections mishandled. He was subsequently dismissed . .

Now we hear about Mrs Forward from the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association complaining about the fear of reprisals and Gary Foley saying on Australian Broadcasting Corporation programs that, `We cannot give evidence to this particular group of inquiries because we have no protection'. This man complained and he was sacked. I shall read the following part of the submission:
Following receipt of material in confidence from a G.R.A.M.S. staff member the DAA Area Officer examined the books of account in early May 1985.
Why he did not examine them six months earlier when the allegations were made, one would not know. The submission continues:
This revealed numerous irregularities in salary payments, loans to employees and their relatives, and unusually high levels of expenditure in some areas without adequate supporting documentation.

The submission then has `seen by Minister' stamped on it, but little was done about it. The people's money was still wasted and, of course, institutions of Aboriginal medicine are being established where people have been quite adjusted to ordinary hospital treatment for many years.

In one area I visited they put in an Aboriginal medical service and had to close the general hospital for lack of support. So those people who were white and in the district went without medical services. All of these things add up to one thing: the Minister has no policy, does not know where to turn and is not fixing the problem. In fact, the Government, collectively, has ignored the signals for five years and so has the Minister since he has had the task.

If the Minister is not going to fix the problem, he should tell us. But I am hoping that his speech, in the next 15 minutes, will give some encouragement to the Aboriginal people. I hope the speech he gives will give them some hope and that the Minister will guarantee them that these problems will stop, not through the current inquiries but through a proper inquiry where evidence can be given with protection, under oath, and be subject to cross-examination.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will attempt to address the questions raised by the previous speaker, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), and I will start with his last point about the Government having no policy. I will be talking about who has no policy over the whole of my speech. The Government has a policy. We have recognised the shortcomings in the current range of services that are provided, and on 10 September last year I outlined a proposal which I took around Australia. I talked to more Aboriginal groups and communities than has ever been done before regarding any policy area which would affect them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government changed the proposal; we came back to this place, prepared the legislation, put it through Parliament and the Government is now waiting for it to be passed through the Senate. I have no disagreement with the honourable member who has just spoken. I do not like going to places and seeing people in tin shacks. I do not like seeing sick people who have no homes and no water. That is the whole thrust of what I am on about-the Woden Town Club grant-and I will say it again: The Opposition must understand the Bill. That is the dilemma faced here. It is a Bill which the Opposition set up and yet the Opposition talks as though everything happened yesterday.

The things Opposition members talk about have occurred over a number of years. Under the restrictions placed on me, I have attempted at every turn to do something about the situation, but the Aboriginal Development Commission legislation is well known to Opposition members. It is interesting that every time I have tried to take some step, I have been attacked by the very people who are now telling me to do something about the situation. Senate select committees are holding back the introduction of the changed legislation. People are being pilloried every day in here, with no proof, as though they are criminals.

The question is fundamental: If one is serious about wanting to bring about change-and I have said to the Opposition and the Democrats that there is a problem that needs to be addressed-I have a concept here which I believe would do that. I have said to the Opposition, `Show me how it can be improved, and if it can be improved and an agreement can be reached on it, we will do it.' I have said to the Democrats, who have one view in the morning and another view in the afternoon, `Why do you not come forward with concrete proposals?' But nothing has been produced.

A range of issues was addressed by the previous speaker in terms of evidence that he has. I say to the honourable member and I say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker-because you were chairman of the committee of this Parliament which took that evidence under the rules of the Parliament-that in terms of protection of witnesses, those people, as I understand it, came forward under the protection of parliament and gave evidence in camera. Is it fair that, when people come before the Parliament of this country and give evidence, thinking that they will receive the protection of the Parliament, that evidence is then handed out for someone else, who was not part of that inquiry, to look at?

I am as concerned as the honourable member is about corruption but those people are in the same position now. They can come forward to me and present that information if they choose. They will be given protection by me and by the processes the Government has established, but I did not set the rules of this Parliament; those rules to which the honourable member referred have been built up over years. I am surprised at Opposition members. They talk about civil liberties but, when it suits their cheap political ends, they throw them overboard. That is the fundamental question here. It is not about trying to address the problem of tin shacks on the riverbank; it is not about trying to get kids into education or trying to establish an employment program; it is about cheap political shots day after day in this damn place and not one Opposition member will come forward to me with any evidence.

I say to the Opposition and to those people who are quick on the gun to accuse people: if they are fair dinkum about trying to rectify the problems of today-not the problems of 1980-81, not the problems of 1983, not the problems of 1984-85 but the problems of today which I have the ability to do something about, although I am limited in some regards-come forward with the information and help us do something about them. The honourable member referred to the Namoi Reserve and the Oasis Hotel. At the same meeting where the problem of the Oasis was being discussed, a decision was made to build homes for the people at Namoi in a two-year program. That decision has been made.

If one looks at the budgetary expenditure and the way it is structured this year under me, and if one examines the arrangements I have developed with the States, one finds that I can reach agreement with the Queensland Government; I can reach agreement with the South Australian Government and the Northern Territory Government on joint programs to obtain houses for people; I can improve the living standards of people all around Australia. But the only people from whom I cannot get cooperation to fix the problem are these people on the Opposition benches. I say to them again: if they want to fix it up, they should let me know and we will do it. I reached agreement with all of the States on how to fix the town camp problem in the Northern Territory. It involved a massive program jointly with the Northern Territory Government, the Commonwealth Government and the Aboriginal people. It involved a tripartite approach. It was the first time it had ever been done and it will work. The bulk of the proposal and the money were put in by the Northern Territory and I give it full credit.

The questions the Opposition raises about the television station are pertinent and the Opposition is correct in raising that issue. The matter has been raised with me. The question concerns the Aboriginal Development Commission, which is the funding body. Again, it is interesting that the Liberal and National parties set up the Commission when they were in government. It is an economic venture. Whether it succeeds or whether it fails will be judged in those terms. The ADC has business people and experts advising it. When an ADC report came out last year, the Opposition congratulated the ADC. Last year Senator Tambling stood up and congratulated the ADC. Yet now the Opposition is about destroying the Commission. I wish honourable members opposite would make up their minds.

One of the components of the ADC legislation is to try to establish an economic base for Aboriginal people. I have to say-and honourable members opposite should listen-that when the stock exchange crashed and billions of dollars were written off, the people who lost that money were plastered across the front pages of the newspaper as heroes. When Laurie Connell's business venture crashed in Western Australia, he was not subjected to the same viciousness that is expressed about Aboriginal people. That is the difference, and honourable members opposite know that.

If we are going to get into the business of economic development to establish an economic base for Aboriginal people, something which the previous Government's legislation established, can honourable members opposite seriously say to me that every proposal that is put up has to work or the whole thing is a failure? There was not one word from honourable members opposite about the shopping complex in Alice Springs worth $40m. There is not one word about the success stories and the good things that Aboriginal people do. There is not one thing said about the training programs by which Aboriginal people claw their way up and get themselves off the river banks and establish going concerns in Mildura, Echuca, Swan Hill and other such places. Nothing is said. I say again to honourable members opposite: `If you have information about maladministration, nepotism and other problems, it is your duty to bring that forward'. There is a way to fix it. The way not to fix it is to create the division that has been created, not totally by one side--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have had five years, Gerry.

—Wait until I finish the sentence. I thought the honourable member for Braddon had gone back to New York, or wherever he was. I did not know he was here. The situation is that the issue that was raised about the people in the arts proposal--
—That is outrageous.
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.

—Again, the honourable member for O'Connor is justified in raising that point, as was the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), who asked a question yesterday about the same point. In my answer to the honourable member for Gwydir I explained that I was meeting the people connected with that issue this week-and I will do that. I say to the member for O'Connor: I can only do that. I cannot rectify a situation that developed back then. I have said to the people concerned-and I shall keep the names between the two of us-that the people concerned will come and see me, and I shall discuss the issue with them and talk the issue right through; and I shall see what needs to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has set up a three-pronged attack to get at the issues that the honourable member has raised. People have raised problems with particular programs, and they have made general statements about programs. Aboriginal people have said to me, `Well, it should be looked at if it's wrong'. They are not running away from it at all. I resent the philosophy that everything that is wrong has to be talked about-and that Aboriginal people cannot handle anything that they touch. That is not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not talking about the Aborigines; we are talking--
—I warn the honourable member for Braddon.

—In relation to the point that the honourable member for O'Connor has raised about the ADC television proposition, I give him a commitment that I will contact the ADC and get an up to date report on where that matter is, for his information. In terms of the arts question, I am addressing that particular point, because at that time, like the honourable member for Gwydir, I was in touch with people about that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us go to the issue of medical services. If ever there was a program of which both sides of the House could be proud, and of which Aboriginal people could be proud, it is the medical services program. That program arose from a report from the parliamentary Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. I think the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) was the Chairman of that Committee-or perhaps it was just before his time. That report suggested that there was a need for a health care program run by Aboriginal people. The concept was developed by Aboriginal people. As the honourable member for Dundas said the other day, Aboriginal people want to be involved in the running of things; they want to have a say about how things are done. Aboriginal people want to be involved, not just consulted. I say to the member for O'Connor: I will wager that the biggest disasters we have had have probably occurred because of the limited involvement of Aborigines in the decision making process. I want him to dwell on that. I am not having a go at him; but I want him to dwell on that very point, because it goes to the heart of a couple of the issues that he raised. In situations where Aboriginal people have developed a process, the odds are that things will work. Where they have been excluded from the process-where an idea might be put up and someone else makes the decision-the odds are that will fail.

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) provides the remedy for all of the problems raised by those opposite. It is a new commission, starting again, but involving Aboriginal people. That is the difference. Honourable members opposite are trying to knock it down and they will not do one single thing to help fix it up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) that the matter of public importance refers to the drastic effect on the living standards and future prospects of Aboriginal people resulting from the Government's indecision and policy vacuum. There is nothing at all in the wording about the indecision of Aboriginal people and the policy vacuum of Aboriginal groups. We are talking about the Government, and that is what this matter is about.

SPEECH.PARA: I am one member of the House who would like to thank Senator Tambling for his actions in the Estimates committee in bringing this matter to the attention of the Australian people. He has done a magnificent job and his work compares favourably with the work done by the Human Rights Commissioner who visited Toomelah. Senator Tambling has brought to the attention of the Parliament the nepotism and maladministration that have gone on under this Government.

I have listened to many honourable members speaking in the House and I have spoken to other honourable members in the corridors about the problems that Aboriginal people face. Many of them do not know what they are talking about. I have been a member of parliament for eight years. In that time I have tried desperately to do something for the people of my electorate, but I must say, and I am ashamed to say it, that I have failed miserably. The reason I have failed is that I just cannot get through the system. I cannot get through the various departments that have been set up not only by the Whitlam and Fraser governments, but also by the Hawke Government and the present Minister.

The situation gets worse. In my electorate, the Aboriginal people are worse off than they were nine or 10 years ago. This is after the expenditure of millions and millions of dollars-certainly millions of dollars have been spent in my electorate. As a member of this Parliament, I am ashamed to say that I have failed. I am sure the Minister will be true to his word and try to do something about the situation, because it is still desperate.

I shall touch on one issue that I know about concerning the town of Wilcannia. In that town, as the Minister probably well knows, we have an area known as the mission. There are 13 Aboriginal homes there, and those homes are in an absolutely desperate situation. I invite any honourable member-as I know the Aboriginal people would do-to have a look at their desperate plight, a plight resulting from maladministration and the other problems that I have mentioned.

When I talk about the mission, I am talking about the mission run by the Sisters of Compassion. They have done a magnificent job in trying to look after the Aboriginal children. Unfortunately, they are leaving the area. I do not know what will happen then, because they have certainly been angels in the way in which they have cared for the Aboriginal people.

To give an example, in January 1986 I was invited to the mission because the Aboriginal people there had a problem. The sewerage system was overflowing and they could not get anyone to do anything about it. It had been in that situation for a couple of months, once again due to maladministration and the fact that they could not get through the system. I said to them, `You have got the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, various other departments, housing authorities and all these things that have been set up at great cost to the taxpayer. Why are they not looking after you? Why are they not doing something?' They said, `Mr Hicks, we cannot get anything done. We cannot get our message heard'. I went there-honourable members should remember that this was during summer-and the stench was unbelievable. Sewage was running under the houses. People talk about Toomelah. I invite them to visit Wilcannia in summer. Human excreta was running through the houses and there was green slime everywhere, yet the people were expected to live there. I immediately sent a telex to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Two months later I got a reply. I am not sure how long it took to fix the problem but it was at least a month. It was found that a pump in the system had broken down and this pump had not been reconditioned or looked after for five years.

When we talk about expenditure of money and responsibilities, I wonder where we are going. While I was at the mission-I had been there plenty of times before-I took it upon myself at the invitation of the people there to look at some of the housing. It was disgraceful. I used to be in the plumbing trade and I have been in some pretty awkward situations, but I was ashamed to be an Australian when I saw what was there. I believe that the situation in Toomelah brought tears to the eyes of the Human Rights Commissioner. It certainly brought tears to my eyes, too.

I had a look at these homes. Sewerage pipes and flush pipes were broken and there was no way that the system could work. Many of these people are paying rental for that accommodation and they wonder exactly where the rental money is going. No-one seems to know. They do know that a property by the name of Weinteriga was bought for about $850,000. It used to have one family on it. I do not know how its purchase was going to help the Aboriginal people, but it was bought and it was disaster. The $850,000 has gone down the drain. I am pleased to be able to say that there is now an administrator there and I am sure that he will get on top, but I still cannot understand why we go round buying properties for $850,000 when people in the town of Wilcannia are living in Third World conditions.

The people of Wilcannia also have a problem with hepatitis B. When I spoke to the Aboriginal people there they were very concerned about the sewerage because of this hepatitis problem. One women who invited me into her home said, `Mr Hicks, two of my daughters died in this room'. When I saw the conditions under which they were living, I understood the health problems that those poor people had. I just cannot understand how this could possibly happen in Australia this year or last year, given the amount of money that we are spending. Where is the money going? We are asking questions about the Government's indecision and policy vacuum. What is happening to all this money?

In 1986 I received a letter from the previous Minister for Aboriginal Affairs saying that these homes on the mission would be replaced. It is two years since I received that letter. Every time I go to Wilcannia I visit the Aboriginal people on the mission and they look at me and ask, `Mr Hicks, what is happening to our houses?' I say to them, `They have been promised by the Government'. Each time I ring the Department I get put off. Either the footings of the houses have not been designed properly, the design of the houses is wrong, something is wrong with the streets or the streets do not have the proper street name, but the houses still have not been started and these people are still living under these conditions and have to face another summer.

I was not surprised at the statement of the Human Rights Commissioner when he visited Toomelah and blamed the situation on the mismanagement of the Federal Government, the previous State government and local government. But what can local government do? I believe that the Central-Darling Shire is owed by the Department about $40,000 for rates. The shire is struggling as a result of cutbacks in Federal and other funding and is just existing. How can the shire be expected to pay out money?

I visited an Aboriginal home in the town of Wilcannia which was absolutely spotless and the people were wonderful. When I walked into their home they looked at me and I could see that something was amiss. There was very little furniture in the house. The lady of the house could see that I was looking around. She felt a little embarrassed and said, `Mr Hicks, I am sorry, but we are a bit worried because there are so many break and enters that we have stored all our good stuff at our daughter's place'. I asked, `What is the situation?' She said, `With Aboriginal legal aid we have people breaking in and entering, they go to the courts, they get out of the courts, they get a slap on the wrist, they go back to the courts, they come out of the courts and it is just open slather. Mr Hicks, we want something done about it. What is the Government doing about all this?'

It is not only a question of housing but also a question of law and order, health and education. I congratulate the State and Federal governments on the $3m that they spent on the school in Wilcannia. I believe that it is only through education that we will get anywhere. I referred earlier to the legal aid situation in the town of Wilcannia. Wilcannia has 10 policemen for 1,000 people, which is one per 100. I hope that the policemen are getting somewhere. I am one of those people who believe that, not just with the Aboriginal population but with the total population, unless we do something about juvenile offenders and teach them that there has to be some type of law and order they will be in real trouble when they get older. I just mention that for what it is worth.

What are the main causes of the problems in these areas? Of course, it is unemployment. What does the previous State Government do? It closes down the Department of Main Roads, one of the main employers in that area. This has happened because of government cutbacks. I think all these departments have to get together and do something about the problem. It cannot be dealt with in isolation. I am asking the various government departments to get together and cut out this nonsense and all this bureaucratic bungling.

We have talked previously about grants and the waste of such money. For example, it cost $62,000 to clean up around houses and plant vegetable gardens. If I could not do that in, say, two days with 10 good men I would give the job away. I think that is another example of the problems that we have. I must say that the present State Government is trying to do something. In the last three weeks or so three Ministers have visited Wilcannia, so there is some hope.

I would like to touch on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, ATSIC, which I think is pretty sick. I think it will divide this nation. I do not think it is a good idea at all. Aboriginal people are Australians and the last thing we want to do is to divide this nation. I think that is what this Commission will do. I think the Minister should look closely at that legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say at the outset that it is with a real degree of sadness that I rise to speak in this matter of public importance debate today. I am saddened not only by the comments made by speakers on the opposite side but also by the tenor of the debate in this nation on Aboriginal matters. I believe that the tenor of that debate was set back in August this year. The Opposition has taken a confrontationist approach in relation to these matters. This has been borne out quite clearly by the evidence that we have had since August this year.

SPEECH.PARA: When we introduced a motion on Aborigines into this House in August we thought it would be supported by those opposite. In fact, so did certain people in the clergy. In their discussions with the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), they were given the clear indication that support would be forthcoming from the Opposition. However, as a last minute political tactic, the Opposition introduced an amendment to that motion and we had the sad and pathetic sight on the first sitting day in this new Parliament House of the Opposition and the Government divided over a motion which should have been totally supported by those opposite. The condemnation that flowed from the public over the Opposition's approach to that motion covered the full spectrum-the clergy, the newspapers and the Aboriginals themselves.

I see within the House this afternoon a number of my colleagues, my brothers, from the Aboriginal people. I ask them to sit and listen and to ponder on the nonsense, the rubbish and the diatribe flowing from those opposite. I point out to them that today the Opposition's spokesman on Aboriginal affairs did not even get a guernsey. He made a mess of it yesterday, so the Opposition brought on the brawler today to try to make more of it. But the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has also failed. In a pathetic attempt he basically duplicated the matter of public importance which was brought forward for debate yesterday. The Opposition copped a hiding yesterday and it is getting another today.

In August we saw the pathetic and sorry sight of the rednecks in the Opposition moving an amendment to the resolution introduced into this House by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). That was not the end of the sordid approach of those opposite. They have now taken to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) in an attempt to destroy it. That Commission will be in the best interests, not just in the long term but also in the short term, of Aboriginal people throughout this nation. What have those Opposition members done about the treaty? They have attacked and attempted to destroy dialogue between the Government and the Opposition and the Aboriginals of our nation in our efforts to get a treaty together. Nothing positive flows from those opposite in Aboriginal matters; their response is only negative. They should be ashamed of themselves. I think it is a disgrace for Opposition members to come in here and speak in such a way about the initiatives and policies of this Government. If the Leader of the Opposition does not do something positive about it, he should be branded with the same condemnation.
When we talk of initiatives and policies, it is unfortunate that this side of House is the only side that has any initiatives and policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you talk about housing and health?

—I notice that the honourable member has got off his assets test. He has been a single-issue man for the last five years. I am pleased to hear him pick up another one. We might just have a look at this and I will take it very slowly for those opposite. Once again we were condemned as a government when we announced new initiatives and an increase in this year's Budget allocation. I ask Aboriginal people and the Australian people generally to have a look at the record. We were condemned and criticised for increasing the Budget allocation.
—We fixed up the hepatitis B.

—Yes, hepatitis B. If those opposite took the time to have a look at some of our initiatives they would find that the additional health programs brought forward by the Minister included the eradication of hepatitis B and that additional funds were made available. There are many other initiatives such as special health initiatives, priority community development strategies, Budget expansions for education, employment and training programs for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders, an increase in assistance to Aboriginal hostels, special youth, recreation and sport activities and facilities, an accelerated program of initiatives for Aboriginal women and a new public relations strategy for Aboriginal Affairs. These are just a few of the initiatives that were taken by this Government in the 1988-89 Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is now time for serious thought within the community and especially within the Opposition's party room. For too long now there have been many within the Opposition party room opposed to the track being taken by the Leader of the Opposition. They will not say it publicly but they will say it to me. We have the rednecks of the National Party of Australia imposing their ideals and their views on Aboriginal matters on the Liberal Party members of the coalition. It is high time that Opposition members thought seriously about this matter, and, with a little bit of decency, gave due consideration to the Aboriginal people of our nation.

It is unfortunate that I have so little time in which to raise some of these issues today. It would take a lot of time to get the message across to those opposite; much more than I have today. I believe we have to look at the introduction of ATSIC. Most of the criticisms raised here today by honourable members opposite will be eliminated by the introduction of ATSIC. It will immediately remedy the situation of bureaucrats becoming involved in the decision process of the Aboriginal communities. It will give those Aboriginal people at the grass roots level the opportunity to make the decisions about their future-about future generations and the programs that they see as priorities within their communities. We will not have to go through a bureaucratic process which has caused difficulties in the past. ATSIC is necessary. Personally, I will push for the acceleration of the implementation of ATSIC. I know that my Government will continue with the firm line of having ATSIC introduced for the benefit and the future betterment of the Aboriginal people of our nation.

As I said at the outset, the condemnation of the Opposition's policies and its approach to Aboriginal matters goes across the full spectrum of our community. I think it is appropriate to at least quote from some of yesterday's editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald under the heading of `Buck-passing and Mr Perkins'. I would like to quote from the editorial to those opposite and to the people of Australia-especially the Aborigines. It said:
The reality is that turning the sorry condition of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the ADC into a political circus will benefit no-one-
and I fully agree with these words-
least of all the Aboriginal communities of Australia.

Today, as yesterday, the circus continues. We saw another performance by those opposite of the circus into which they have attempted to turn Aboriginal matters. No-one needs any further evidence of this circus than the fact that they produced today, as their main actor, the greatest clown of all, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey).
