Although the Government will accept the Bill as amended in the Senate to ensure its passage, two matters need to be made clear. Firstly, there will always be the need to announce government taxation decisions prior to legislation being introduced to prevent loss of revenue. Press releases will continue to be used to stop tax arrangements immediately. The second matter concerns the amendment that was moved by the Opposition to restrict the application of the non-cash business benefits provisions from the date of introduction of this Bill. It should be highlighted that among a few there is a serious misconception that non-cash benefits of a kind that can be convertible into a value have only become assessable as a result of these amendments. On the contrary, these non-cash but convertible items have always been assessable since 1936 under ordinary concepts of income.

Examples of items taxable since 1936 are motor cars, television sets, microwave ovens and jewellery received by taxpayers in lieu of cash income. The new law merely provides a valuation rule for all non-cash business benefits and extends the net to include non-convertible, non-cash business benefits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only just received these amendments. Mr Deputy Chairman, could you refresh my memory as to how far we are going at this stage? Are all the amendments being dealt with now?
—Yes, they are.

—If we are dealing with amendments 1 to 8, from what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said, that means we are tackling what we would term the double taxation elements. Pursuant to amendments 3 and 6 we must also be dealing with what is perceived to be retrospectivity. The Treasurer and I do not differ if that is the case. I just wish to say a few things to the House. The amendments moved by the Government dealing with double taxation stem from Opposition initiatives in the Senate, and yet again Government legislation would have resulted in what is euphemistically called unintended consequences. A number of these amendments will seek to stop the possibility of double taxation that arose in the Bill as originally drafted.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does support the Government's amendments. I simply note that the amendments highlight the necessity for parliamentary debate. I recall that when the legislation was before the House I drew attention to both the double taxation and the retrospectivity elements of it, and at the time the Minister then representing the Treasurer disagreed. The reality is that this Government has a dreadful history of ill-considered and slipshod drafting; yet with a mountain of legislation to get through the old democratic debate has already been stifled somewhat in this chamber because after we deal with these matters we will get onto legislation that is being guillotined.

In terms of the impact on individuals-and nothing tends to impact more on individuals than taxation-the need for effective parliamentary debate and the role for the Senate itself as a House of review which is able to insist not only on further debate in that chamber but also on having these matters clarified in the way in which we warned was necessary when the matter was before us, are borne out. We were particularly concerned, quite apart from double taxation, with the question of retrospectivity. The Opposition has no objection to the substance of this non-cash business benefits legislation. I said so when the matter was before the House. What the Opposition does object to is the outrageous attempt to apply the legislation retrospectively to a date 3 1/2 years ago. The Government has reluctantly accepted amendments imposed upon it in the Senate by the endeavours of the Opposition, on this occasion joined by the Australian Democrats, to ensure that the legislation would not have that effect.

What happened, for those who may be unaware, is that some 3 1/2 years ago the Government issued a press release saying it would do a certain thing and it has taken 3 1/2 years to introduce the legislation, which is far more intricate in its impact than a generalised press release. People who during that period have sought to rearrange their affairs have been thwarted by legislation that goes much further than in fact the press release indicated. There has to be a limit to the number of days or weeks that a government allows an announcement to run that it is going to impose a new form of taxation. As I recall it was a very short Bill of only two pages but it took 3 1/2 years to move from being a press release to being legislation introduced into the Parliament. This really does underline the value of having a second chamber that can be a check on a government that is legislating in this manner.

It would have been extremely inequitable for this legislation to have applied retrospectively. What is happening now is that instead of it applying from the date of the press release these amendments will ensure that the day of introduction of the Bill will be 31 August 1988. This is proper. As I noted in my speech at the second reading stage, the press release clearly did not give taxpayers much indication of how effective benefits would be valued. The announcement merely stated:
As a general rule the value to be taxed will be the amount which the benefit would have cost the taxpayer in an arm's length transaction.

Taxpayers could reasonably have expected that detailed valuation rules would apply to the benefits from the date on which they were announced, not some date 3 1/2 years later. Under the proposed legislation benefits must be valued, broadly speaking, at the amount the recipient would have had to pay to obtain the benefit under an arm's length transaction. Therefore, to determine the taxable value of benefits received over the previous 3 1/2 years taxpayers will have to ascertain the amount they would have had to pay to obtain those benefits at the time each benefit was granted. Administrative nightmares would have abounded.

The Government has a shameful record of government by press release and it is an insult to this Parliament and an insult to the people to allow this sort of thing to go through. It is a usurping of the primacy of the executive branch of government. Frankly, I think it is a sign of a pathetic administration. The Treasurer and I had very warm words of friendship to one another on legislation that passed last week. I do not say that I am sorry to have been speaking in these terms--

TALK.START.PARA: —Uncharacteristic.

—Yes, it was; it was an aberrant day in the life of the Parliament, I suppose. Here we are, joined, agreeing with each other again. But the problem should not have arisen in the first place. The Opposition is not opposing the amendments, but the Government must ensure that it does not allow either sloppy drafting or such lengthy delays in introducing legislation after it makes pronouncements by way of press release.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Keating for Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill brings forward a series of proposed amendments to the Foreign Takeovers Act 1975. Essentially, these amendments fall into two groups. In the first instance they give legislative effect to existing foreign investment policy by preventing foreign interests from buying Australian urban real estate without approval. At the same time the penalty and enforcement sections of the Act are to be strengthened. The second group of amendments give legislative effect to existing foreign investment policy by increasing the value below which proposals by foreigners to buy Australian businesses are exempt for examination, by excluding from examination foreign acquisitions of mineral exploration rights and by increasing to $20m the threshold above which offshore takeovers are subject to the Act.

Honourable members may think that at first sight it is incongruous that the Government is strengthening sections of the Foreign Takeovers Act while at the same time liberalising other parts of it. However, in the context of the Government's broader foreign investment policy objectives, this is not the case. In its foreign investment policy the Government attempts to maintain a balance between two important interests. The first is the natural desire of the Australian community that local people should have the dominant influence in our economy. The second is the very significant benefits that Australia gains from foreign investment.

Australia has for many years benefited from foreign investment. This is especially the case because we have a small population relative to the size of our existing economic infrastructure, and we have always needed a substantial flow of foreign investment to help expand our economy. This investment has thus provided scope for Australia's rates of economic growth and job generation to be higher than they would otherwise have been.

Foreign capital also provides access to new technology, management skills and overseas markets. This is particularly important now, given the crucial requirement that we internationalise the Australian economy and expand our export sector. For these reasons the Australian Government welcomes productive foreign investment, and has applied its policy flexibly in order to encourage the expansion of such investment. However, we have been concerned that purchases of Australian houses by foreigners with no intention of taking up residence here has in the past contributed to driving up the price of Australian real estate. Distinct from most forms of foreign investment, we see these purchases as providing little or no real benefit to Australia, and consequently this Bill provides a legislative basis for our earlier decisions to prevent such acquisitions.

This Bill provides a test for the Opposition parties. In recent times we have heard little from them about foreign investment policy-yet another indication of the lack of attention they have paid in recent times to the detail of economic policy making. However, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has in the past endorsed a policy of virtual total abolition of the foreign investment restrictions, exempting only so-called strategic areas, such as the media. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), specifically opposed our measures last September to tighten policy against foreign purchases of Australian homes. He may have had a rethink in the meantime. This approach is inconsistent with our desire to dampen price pressures in the housing market by preventing foreign purchases of Australian residential real estate.

This Bill will provide the Opposition with an opportunity to clarify its position on these issues. I can only hope that it adopts the same constructive approach as we have, and abandons its new found excessive zeal for market forces to be unrestrained in this area.

I will now deal in more detail with the amendments relating to urban real estate. Under the new arrangements announced on 29 September 1987, and administered by the Foreign Investment Review Board on a non-legislative basis since then, foreign purchases of developed residential real estate have normally only been permitted in respect of Australian citizens living abroad, intending migrants who have received approval from the immigration authorities to take up permanent residence in Australia and foreign companies buying houses for executives resident in Australia. The September 1987 policy change also abolished the $600,000 cumulative exemption threshold, below which foreign persons were permitted to buy real estate without notification. Under the guidelines applying since that time and to be given legislative effect by this Bill, all foreign acquisitions of urban real estate are examinable regardless of size.

I should emphasise that while the Bill provides for the notification and examination of foreign purchases of all forms of urban real estate-both commercial and residential-the relatively liberal approach to approvals in cases other than developed residential real estate is to be maintained. Under a policy change which I announced on 28 July 1986, foreign purchases of real estate for development-both residential and commercial-are approved unless judged contrary to the national interest. Purchases of developed commercial real estate are approved subject to a flexible guideline for 50 per cent Australian equity, with approvals for 100 per cent foreign ownership being granted if Australian equity on reasonable terms and conditions is unavailable.

The amendments will provide a statutory power for the Treasurer of the day to examine foreign acquisitions of interests in urban land, to prohibit proposed foreign acquisitions of urban land that are judged contrary to the national interest, and to order the disposal of interests in urban land that are purchased by foreign persons without prior notification under the Act and which are determined to be contrary to the national interest. Interests in urban land are broadly defined in the Bill to include both legal and equitable interests as well as interests in companies and trusts where more than half of the assets of these entities relate to Australian urban land.

Hitherto the real estate aspects of foreign investment policy have been administered without legal sanctions for non-compliance. This Bill will rectify that situation. In the first instance, in the event of a breach of the guidelines between October last year and the enactment of the legislation, the Treasurer will have powers to order divestiture of the property where approval was not sought. That apart, there will be no retrospective fines for failing to notify transactions entered into before the amending legislation comes into force.

However, from the date of enactment a series of amendments to strengthen the whole ambit of the Foreign Takeovers Act will apply. These involve five main areas. First, the Bill amends the definition of a foreign person to include the trustees of trust estates having substantial foreign beneficiaries and to provide that a foreign national shall be taken to be ordinarily resident in Australia only if that person has actually been in Australia for 200 days in the last 12 months and is legally free to remain in Australia indefinitely. The exclusion of trust arrangements from the Foreign Takeovers Act has long been anomalous and is now to be rectified. The statutory definition of `ordinarily resident' is designed to provide an objective and specific test which will be more satisfactory than the common law meaning of that term.

Second, the Bill provides a legal basis for the longstanding practice of allowing foreign investment proposals to proceed by raising no objections subject to certain specified conditions being met. In doing so, the Bill also provides penalties for non-compliance with the conditions.

The third area in which the Act is being strengthened is by an amendment which provides for it to be an offence for a person to make false or misleading statements in connection with the Act. In administering foreign investment policy the Government depends crucially on information supplied by the parties to proposals to enable applications to be assessed. The Government has therefore decided that it is desirable that there should be some legal sanction to discourage the supply of false information by foreign investors and their agents.

Fourth, the Bill contains an anti-avoidance power against schemes entered into for the sole or dominant purpose of evading the provisions of the Act. Some care has been taken with the amendments contained in the Bill with regard to urban real estate to cut off possible loopholes. Nevertheless, to avoid needless inconvenience for the vast majority of foreign investors who are willing to comply with the guidelines, the Government has tried to keep the amendments as simple as reasonably possible. The general anti-avoidance powers will provide a disincentive for investors or their advisers to enter into convoluted arrangements to avoid the normal scope of the Act.

Fifth, the penalties contained in the Act have been reviewed, and in most cases increased. In particular, fines for offences by corporations have been increased to $250,000 and offences by natural persons are to carry a possible penalty of imprisonment of up to two years as well as a fine of up to $50,000. I should emphasise that this general strengthening of the Act does not herald a new tough line on foreign investment: the Bill brings the Act more closely into line with foreign investment policy.

The Government remains committed to a generally relaxed approach to foreign investment in all except a few sensitive sectors. Foreign investment is welcome in Australia and policy is administered on a non-discriminatory basis. Over the years foreign investment has made a substantial contribution to Australia's growth and development; to the creation of jobs; to the improvement of technology; and to the creation of export markets. Australia will continue to need foreign investment in the future: it is integral to the steps we have been taking to reform and restructure the economy. Nevertheless, the Government does need adequate powers to deal with the occasional proposal which is contrary to the national interest and to deal with foreign investors who do not comply with the Government's policy.

I turn now to the other amendments in the Bill, all of which act to liberalise areas of the policy. On 30 April 1987 I announced that takeover proposals involving Australian businesses with total assets of less than $5m, or, in the case of rural businesses, less than $3m, would be excluded from the Act. Acquisitions below these thresholds seldom raise issues that require detailed consideration. The exemption from the Foreign Takeovers Act of proposals in respect of Australian businesses with total assets below the thresholds represents a reduction in unnecessary business regulation.

In anticipation of this amending legislation, the Government has been granting automatic approvals to takeover proposals submitted for examination but falling below the thresholds. As a result, perhaps 500 proposals a year are now excluded from examination altogether. It is to be noted that where more than half of the value of the total assets of a company is attributable to urban real estate an acquisition of shares in that company would be examinable under the urban land provisions of the Bill, even if the company's total assets were less than $5m.

Consistent with the relaxed approach of the Government to foreign participation in mineral exploration activities, the Bill also amends the definition of a mineral right in the Foreign Takeovers Act to exempt exploration rights from the provisions of the Act. However, proposed mining developments resulting from successful exploration will still need to be submitted for examination under foreign investment policy. The proposed amendments will also raise the threshold above which offshore takeovers are subject to examination under the Act.

Offshore takeovers are those where an offshore company with assets in Australia is acquired by another offshore company. This type of transaction does not involve any reduction in Australian ownership and control and has been found in practice to be unlikely to raise issues contrary to the national interest. At present, the Act provides for the notification of offshore takeovers if the value of the Australian assets involved exceeds $3m, a threshold which has not been adjusted since it was established in 1975. The proposed amendments will raise the threshold to $20m. Where the Australian assets represent 50 per cent or more of the worldwide assets of the business being acquired, the company remains subject to the Act irrespective of the value of the Australian assets.

In conclusion, the only financial impact of the Bill will arise from the costs of examining a possible increase in the number of foreign investment proposals submitted to Treasury for examination compared to the current situation. It is to be noted that there has been a net reduction in staff in the foreign investment area of Treasury in recent years as a result of liberalisations of the foreign investment guidelines. I note that the Foreign Takeovers Act has now been on the statute books for over a dozen years with only a couple of technical amendments. The Act has served its purpose well by providing a mechanism by which the Government can screen foreign takeovers of Australian businesses. This Bill contains a series of amendments to the Act reflecting major policy changes in the past three to four years, especially in the urban real estate area. I commend the Bill to the House and present the associated explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Peacock) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I stand to take part in this debate concerning the Government's new road program, which will replace the Australian bicentennial road development program (ABRD) and the Australian land transport program (ALTP). Throughout Australia, and in particular in rural and provincial Australia, municipal councils are supporting the various automobile associations in their campaign for increased funds to be allocated for road construction and maintenance. The main thrust of that is to have an increased proportion of fuel excise funds dedicated to road funding.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a little like motherhood. If we ignore the current budgetary constraints facing Australia the justice of the cause is rather compelling. I, and I am sure the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), would like to see greater funds allocated to roads. On grounds of improving the ageing road network, especially unclassified roads, and also on the arguments for road safety, there must be a prima facie case for increasing funds.

I have continually made representations on this matter and over the years have seen this Government become the first to dedicate any of the fuel excise for road funding. In fact, it must have come as something of a shock to the Opposition when that occurred. After a coalition government that for so long maintained the practice of using fuel tax as a source of general revenue, the change initiated by the Australian Labor Party Government was historic. I am fully aware of the concern expressed by a number of local government bodies at the reduction in the amount of excise dedicated to road funding as indicated in the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill before the House. Like those bodies, I am disappointed, but I realise that, in a time of tight budgets and the decision to maintain the allocation in nominal terms when a number of other areas have been cut to reduce the projected Budget surplus of $5 1/2 billion, the principle is still maintained. I and, I believe, many of my colleagues will work to have this locked into the Budget process.

When the Government made its decision to limit finance for roads it ensured that the amounts directed to local government were insulated against cuts. To give evidence of this, I refer to the following figures. In 1987-88 the funds allocated to local roads were $261.1m and in 1988-89 the figure will be $272.5m. Local government is, therefore, being looked after in a very special way in the current financial context because the Government recognises the work which local government does in building and maintaining local roads.

I do not think there is anyone in this place who would question the sincerity of the local government bodies or the Australian Automobile Association (AAA) and its affiliates in their concern for improving the quality of the Australian road system. Not only that but we also recognise they should be active lobbyists for their cause. If a group does not lobby actively one tends to doubt the quality of its commitment. I believe that the commitment of the AAA and its affiliates is undoubted. It is admirable. But they should not forget that they must be credible in presenting their case. They have referred to the need for budget constraints. In their understanding of the pressures facing government in getting the macro-economic and micro-economic conditions right, they should also recognise that others take a different view of their case. For instance, in a recent speech to the Australian Automobile Association in Adelaide on 4 November 1988, Mr Ian Storey, the Chairman of the Road Construction Authority of Victoria (RCA), had the following to say in relation to the campaign being conducted by the automobile associations:

The implication of your campaign is that more money means better roads and I simply don't believe that. Let me quote some figures. Over the last six years the Federal Government has allocated $7 billion to road funding. Add to that the contributions from the States which is normally a matching amount and you have over the last six years an expenditure of $10 billion to $14 billion on roads and that is an enormous amount of money. I suggest that before any of us ask for additional money we have to ask how well spent that money has been and we have to look to how well spent that money will be in the future.

He even suggests that inappropriate decisions about sealing some roads have been taken when the traffic volumes do not justify that treatment. There is little doubt that as we in the Federal sphere of politics are subjected to pressure from a broad range of lobby and pressure groups so are State governments and local governments. No government is immune to the temptation to pass on responsibility for making the hard and unpopular decisions to government at another level.

This brings me to that part of the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill which refers specifically to arterial roads. If we take both the existing arterials and the new category of national arterials together, the amount of funding for arterial roads has been increased marginally over the amount allocated in 1987-88. There is a hard-edged aspect to this new category of national arterials because now they have to be designated as having the capacity in a specific way to enhance the domestic and export competitiveness of Australian industry. In other words, they now have to meet stringent criteria. As the Minister has said in his second reading speech:

The category will fund projects on key routes linking areas of production with ports, airports, freight forwarding centres, rail freight terminals and termini of key arterial roads. The new routes will also provide interstate and international travellers with easier access to tourist routes.

This fits in with the Government's economic adjustment policy and gives a meaning to the allocation of road funds that was not adequately addressed in other programs. I recognise the commitment of State and local governments, as I said before. Most of my local councils are genuinely concerned at the difficulties they face in maintaining existing road standards. Perhaps we need a thorough investigation into the significance of our road system to ascertain whether existing thinking and priorities are adequate for the changing circumstances of this time and the future. I recommend to all honourable members that they read the speech of Mr Ian Storey, Chairman of the RCA of Victoria, which I mentioned earlier. He poses questions that should not be put into the too hard basket because they are unpopular or are in conflict with established wisdom.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is well qualified to meet that challenge.

—That is quite true. I know that the honourable member for Herbert is particularly concerned about the state of the roads in his electorate. As I said, I do not oppose increasing road funds. To do so would be meaningless. In the context of this Bill, which provides a coherence for policy development at all levels, I would like to see more funds spent on roads to accelerate the achievement of the Government's goals. So would the Minister. It is now of considerable satisfaction that the amount of excise receipts is specifically dedicated as a road user charge. The funds are to be paid into a special trust fund operating for the four-year duration of the program from 1 January 1989 to 31 December 1993. In order to gain maximum value for money spent, the Bill establishes a quality assurance system. This is particularly important over the long term and it is innovative. It is concerned not only with road construction but also with road maintenance. As everyone knows, this is an ongoing and expensive business.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst quality assurance is not required of State arterial roads and local roads, I am sure that the cost conscious local government councils will watch this development with interest. It is to be hoped that they will apply the principles inherent. The Opposition has levelled much criticism at the Government's road funding record, but the criticism hardly stands up to close scrutiny, given the economic pressures that we face. This is the first year in which the amount of road funds allocated by the Federal Government has fallen to the highest level attained by the Fraser Government. In 1982-83, the Fraser Government's last year, it allocated $1,219m in 1988 prices. The current Government has allocated $1,221.5m. In the previous year, 1981-82, the Fraser Government allocated $1,106.4m in 1988 prices. The Fraser Government had nothing to be proud of at all. Its funding was not based upon any long term planning, which does not surprise. It was low because roads were considered a low priority issue. Let us not have the nonsense spoken here today that there has been an abrogation of our responsibilities for improving and maintaining our road system. I support this Bill. I commend the Minister. I believe that the amendment should be dealt with by the House as I am sure it will be dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased indeed to see the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) sitting in the chamber this afternoon because I would like to refer to something he told the House on 28 April this year. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: On 13 November 1984 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) pledged to the Australian people that his Government would undertake the greatest road building and maintenance program in Australia's history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—The honourable member for Herbert said it. He went on to urge all parliamentarians to press for increased road funding. What a joke! Increased road funding has not occurred. It should occur, as the honourable member for Herbert knows. I praise him for trying to put the pressure on his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Government to do the right thing by roads. But, unfortunately and regrettably for Australia, he has failed. We hope that he will continue to apply that pressure. Perhaps before the Hawke Labor Government is tossed out at the next election he will be able to induce it to spend a little more on roads.

SPEECH.PARA: The road network is vital to all Australians. It is the vital basis of our economy. Funding to local government, State government and the Federal Government in the 12 months to June 1987 amounted to almost $4,000m, that is, almost $4 billion. But Federal funding in that time was only $1,250m, a little over 25 per cent of the total amount allocated. It is interesting that, in 1987, the State governments produced $1,342m more than the Federal Government. Even local government, out of its stretched resources, provided $1,085m. Unfortunately, the present Government has held road funding at $1,250m per annum since 1984-85. To take inflation into account, as we must, this means that there has been a drop of 25 per cent in road funding in real terms over the last four years. In 1988-89 the amount spent on roads has dropped further, to $1,215m.

I would like to make the point-and it will come as no surprise to honourable members-that I will be talking about the needs of the Pacific Highway. I see the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) nodding in agreement. He knows that I will be talking about it. I will be talking about him too in a moment. The point has to be made that if one is looking at the road network of Australia, the Pacific Highway has a special priority and special precedence. I want to praise and thank the Minister for his courtesy a couple of weeks ago in receiving a deputation of people representing the North Coast Regional Organisation of Councils and the Northern Rivers Regional Organisation of Councils, together with some of my colleagues from the north coast. We appreciate very much the fact that the Minister made that time available. We also appreciate the comments he made and the fact that he expressed-and I am sure I am not misquoting him-his belief that parts of the Pacific Highway already are in need of dual carriageway, four-lane divided highway status. He also gave an undertaking that should the New South Wales Government include the Pacific Highway in its list of national arterial roads he would give it very favourable consideration. All of us associated with the north coast of New South Wales thank him.

Of course, it is not just the north coast of New South Wales that needs attention. We have to realise that the Pacific Highway is not just my local road or the local road of people living between the Tweed River and Hexham; it is a major important artery which serves the whole of Australia. The Minister comes from the Hunter region, and the Pacific Highway is vitally important to his electors just as it is to the electors of honourable members from Sydney, Melbourne, and the rest of Australia.

I also pay tribute to the present New South Wales Government. The relevant Ministers, Bruce Baird and Matt Singleton, since 13 March, have taken action to catch up on what has been quite an embarrassing backlog of work of the Unsworth Government. I instance some work that is going on between Kempsey and Port Macquarie in my electorate. Prior to the change of State Government there were orphan bridges, orphan Annies, in the scrub standing as monuments to Labor's neglect of roads throughout New South Wales. Since the change of Government it is fair to praise-just as I have praised the Minister here-the State Ministers because that road work is taking place and things are actually moving. It is also worth noting that the State Government has allocated additional money for overtaking lanes which are vitally important for road safety. I will come back to road safety in a moment.

The Pacific Highway is one of the most important roads in Australia. It carries one of the heaviest concentrations of vehicular traffic of any highway in the country. It is the second longest highway in New South Wales, running for almost 900 kilometres. Only the Newell Highway is longer. It runs through 24 local government areas, nine of them located between Sydney and Newcastle and 15 located on the north coast, which is the most significant and important growth area of this great nation. The Pacific Highway services a region which has one of the highest natural population growth rates in Australia. It not only serves as a route for facilitating interstate trade and commerce but also provides access to industrial, farming, mining, tourism and other developmental locations along its course. As these grow the communities which they support also expand. So there is a need to improve the Pacific Highway and to put it into its ultimate shape, which must be, as the Minister knows, a four-lane, dual carriageway, divided highway all the way through. I do not ask for this to happen overnight. Nobody in his right mind would do so. I do ask-and I know this is gaining wide acceptance-that there be an acceptance of the reality that the Pacific Highway for its full length, from Sydney to Brisbane, from Hexham to the Queensland border in terms of New South Wales, must be a four-lane, dual carriageway, divided highway.

The National Roads and Motorists Association, a very respected body, makes the point very clearly that, wherever there is a traffic volume of over 8,000 vehicles a day, safety demands that there be a four-lane, dual carriageway, divided highway. Out of 17 points between Hexham and the Tweed at which the Department of Main Roads monitors traffic volume, 11 already are at the point where the traffic volume justifies that four-lane, dual carriageway divided highway.

Time is limited because of the guillotine which, unfortunately, the Government has seen fit to impose on the debate today, but I just want to make some points about road safety. Each road fatality costs the community almost $450,000. The total cost of road accidents in Australia in 1987 was recently estimated at $5.69 billion. That is an enormous amount of money. The vehicle damage in 1987 alone cost Australians $1,690m. If we as a Parliament, as a nation, are fair dinkum about road safety, if we are fair dinkum about the cost not only in money but in pain, suffering and heartache, we have to do more.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a strong argument.

—The honourable member would know better than any one of us. The price is not worth paying in terms of suffering. We have to create an awareness throughout this whole Parliament, both sides of both Houses. We need a bipartisan approach, as my friend the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) would endorse, I am sure. We need to provide the money to improve our roads. It is a great investment not just in road safety but in economics. We know that funding for this new road system, the national arterial road system, will be spent on the basis of economic significance. What we have to do-and I know the Minister wants to do this-is gain more funding so that we can do the right thing not by the roads of Australia but by the people of Australia. This is what it is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make a further point, that the loss or partial loss in the case of non-fatal injuries, of crash victims' ability to contribute at work, at home, in the community, is another $1,710m-$1.71 billion. I could go on with figure after figure, but I will conclude by making the point that the construction of freeway standard roads has reduced the traffic pressure by as much as 80 per cent. Recently, I had the opportunity of driving to Parliament. I drove down the Pacific Highway and then from Sydney to Canberra on the Hume Highway and the Federal Highway. The difference is unbelievable. My constituents and the constituents of the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), if they have not travelled from Sydney through Campbelltown to Goulburn and on, would not believe their eyes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Compare the accidents.

—As my colleague says, the comparison of accidents and costs is unbelievable too. When there is a good road, a dual carriageway, four-lane divided highway, the accident rate rapidly diminishes. My time has expired. However, I make one final plea to the Minister-I know he will heed it-to use his best interests, his best endeavours within the Ministry to see that additional funding is provided for roads in this country because it is important to everyone in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —After more than 5 1/2 years of the Hawke Government, the real value of Commonwealth road funding has been over 20 per cent higher than in the last six years of the Fraser-Howard Government. I thought I would mention that statistic to correct an unfortunate mistaken impression that is apparently harboured by my friend the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). During 1988-89, the Hawke Government will spend $1,221.5m on roads compared with the $851m spent in 1982-83, the last year of the Fraser Government. It is an absolutely shameful record of mismanagement of the administration of highway funds in this country. The Hawke Government's new five-year road funding program will maintain the real value of road funding for 1989-90 and beyond. The Australian centennial roads development program will provide financial assistance to the States and Territories for the construction and maintenance of roads.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill establishes the Australian centennial roads development trust fund. A specified share of an hypothecated amount of customs and excise duty on motor spirit and diesel fuel will fund the program over the period from 1 January 1989 to 30 June 1994. The amount of duty referred to in the Bill as the `charge rate' is to be indexed to changes in the gross non-farm product price deflator. The charge rate is to be indexed at six-monthly intervals in April and October.

The Commonwealth first provided financial assistance to the States for roads under the Loan Act 1922, although specific road funding legislation commenced with the Main Roads Development Act 1923. Road funding has been provided continuously by the Federal Government since the early 1920s under a variety of Acts. Today road funding represents the largest single specific purpose capital grant made by the Commonwealth to the States, as well as being the largest specific purpose payment from the Commonwealth passed on to local government. Federal fuel taxes have been in existence since early this century. In 1926 these taxes were increased specifically to enable the Commonwealth to increase its funding for roads, although there was no formal hypothecation-that is, earmarking of these additional revenues. Legislation allowing the hypothecation of a portion of fuel taxes for roads first appeared as the Federal Aid Roads Act 1931.

This practice continued under various pieces of legislation until the nexus between fuel taxation and road funding was broken under the Commonwealth Aid Roads Act 1959. It was not until the introduction of the Australian Bicentennial Development Trust Fund Act 1982 that formal hypothecation was reintroduced. I must, of course, commend the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) for his efforts in the introduction of that legislation.

Under the provisions of that Act, a surcharge on duties of customs and excise on motor spirit and diesel fuel-initially 1c and later 2c per litre-was hypothecated for road funding. This practice was also adopted under the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Act 1985, which hypothecated an amount of the existing duties of customs and excise on motor spirit and diesel fuel. These two pieces of legislation are still in force. Under these two Acts, approximately one-quarter of the excise rate on motor spirit and diesel fuel is currently being earmarked for road funding. It is a fact that throughout the long history of Federal Government fuel tax hypothecation, there has never been a time in which there has been 100 per cent hypothecation. There has always been some element of fuel taxation that has been regarded as `general taxation'.

With the Australian bicentennial road development program legislated to end of 31 December 1988, the Federal Government has decided to terminate simultaneously the Australian land transport program and replace both programs with the Australian centennial road development scheme, with effect from 1 January 1989. The underlying philosophy of the Australian bicentennial road development program was that it would bring about an accelerated upgrading of road standards throughout Australia. Australian bicentennial road development money could not be used for road maintenance. It could be used only for construction and upgrading.

Once such a program has been operating for a number of years, a point is obviously reached where such funding should also be used for road maintenance. Having achieved a significant upgrading of the road network, there is still a need for adequate levels of funding to ensure that appropriate levels of maintenance can be undertaken to preserve the standard of roads, along with funds to ensure an ongoing, if not so accelerated, program of road improvement. Once a program of more broadly-based road development has been undertaken for some years, funding of that mechanism should be introduced to ensure greater efficiency in the use of available funds. Indeed, this is the philosophy behind the Australian centennial road development program. Under this legislation the new funding levels are guaranteed in real terms and every effort will be made to ensure that the `best value for the dollar' is attained.

This is done firstly by ensuring that only national arterial projects are undertaken which have high benefit-cost ratios, such as the Townsville to Townsville Airport road, by giving more responsibility to the States, which are after all in charge of the day to day administration of roadworks, and to ensure that projects are completed on budget and to an appropriate standard.

With respect to local road funding, real road funding levels are the same as those applying in the early 1980s. Maintenance of real road funding levels for local roads has been promised for the first two years of the Australian centennial road development program. I know honest and intelligent local government leaders are happy that the Government is continuing specifically to fund local roads in the legislation, rather than allowing the funds to be `absorbed' into general revenue assistance, which is one funding alternative which has been discussed from time to time. As with the existing Australian bicentennial road development and Australian land transport program legislation, some road funds can be applied by the States for urban public transport infrastructure, such as bus interchanges and new bus shelters. There are much needed facilities in Townsville and Thuringowa.

I now refer to provisions in the Bill relating to determining the charge rate. In some respect, the year 1988-89 might be regarded as a `transition year', since road funding in that year is a combination of Australian bicentennial road development, Australian land transport programs and Australian centennial road development funding. For the purposes of implementing the Australian centennial road development scheme from 1 January 1989, the charge rate will be arbitrarily set at 4.95c per litre. At the end of 1988-89, regardless of the amount of excise that has been paid into each of the three trust funds-the Australian bicentennial road development program, Australian land transport program and Australian centennial road development program-an adjustment will be made by either an injection of funds from Consolidated Revenue funds into the Australian centennial road development trust fund or a payment from the trust fund into Consolidated Revenue funds, to ensure that the total level of funding for the year will be $1,221.5m.

Clause 10 of the Bill allows the Minister to set arbitrarily the charge rate that will apply from the beginning of each of the financial years 1989-90 and 1990-91. This rate will be that which is expected to enable the `real terms guaranteed' levels of funding to be met in each of those three years. Once set, these charge rates will be indexed in April and October in each year, beginning in October 1989. Clause 10 requires the Minister to set, retrospectively, a `substitute charge rate' if it is the case that the charge rate originally set does not raise enough revenue to meet the guaranteed level of funding. Presumably, if more than the guaranteed amount were raised, the Minister would be permitted to reduce the charge rate retrospectively to such a level as to ensure that only the guaranteed amount were raised. Road funding in real terms for the years 1989-90 and 1990-91 is guaranteed by this legislation. Only an amendment to this legislation, passed by both Houses of Parliament, can alter this guarantee of funding in real terms.

The Australian centennial road development scheme is to run for five years; that is, until the end of June 1994. The legislation is not specific as to the level of funding in the years 1991-92 and onwards. Even though the charges set in 1990-91 will continue to be indexed by the provisions of clause 14 of the Bill, clause 10 allows the Minister to override any existing charge rate and impose a rate set arbitrarily by himself after consultation with the Treasurer. The level of funding in the remaining years of the program are thus completely at the discretion of the Minister. There is no scope for parliamentary approval of any action proposed by the Minister in this respect. The Minister is permitted by the proposed legislation simply to gazette his determination. I have full confidence in the Minister ensuring that there is an adequate level of funds for road works in this country during the period I have just discussed.

In the two minutes left to me, I should like to touch on one other issue and that is to comment on the revised tendering arrangements that will apply under the new program. The Federal Government considers that the best value for the road dollars is achieved through the operation of market forces, and it has always held that view. For roads, this means that we proceed through the tendering process.

The revised tendering arrangements will provide for tenders to be called for all national highway construction projects, all major rehabilitation projects on national highways valued over $2m and all national arterial projects which are for construction only.

The extension of the tendering requirement to national highway rehabilitation costing more than $2m, and national arterials, is a widening of the tendering provision that applied under the Australian land transport program. The tender assessment provisions are also being amended to allow the State road authorities more flexibility in evaluating tenders. That will allow State road authorities to choose the contractor that will provide the most cost effective tender, rather than simply choosing the lowest tenderer. All members of parliament will have had experience in situations where the lowest tenderer has ended up in trouble and has then proceeded to institute action against the State road authority, making all sorts of specious claims against the State road authority to try to renegotiate the price.

I commend the legislation to the House. It is far-sighted; and it is an example of ministerial competence. It shows that the current Minister is in complete charge of his Department. Before sitting down, I should like to compliment the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) on the excellent contribution he made to the debate. One of the privileges of sitting in the House is to listen to the reasoned and constructive debate on this side of the House, interspersed with contributions such as that by the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), who has a sincere interest in road funding in this country. But some of the earlier contributions to the debate on this program by members of the Opposition indicate that they are simply playing party politics and do not have a sincere interest in adequate road funding for this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the comments of my colleagues on this side of the House. Only this week, a prominent road user organisation, the Australian Road Transport Association, branded the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill as the worst piece of economic vandalism perpetrated by the Hawke Government on the basic infrastructure of this country. In fact, this vandalism has been going on for five years now. Just as a common vandal would render a public telephone useless by severely damaging it, the Government has vandalised yet another public asset, our roads.

SPEECH.PARA: What should be, by all rights, one of our greatest national assets is becoming a national disgrace. Western Australia provides an example of what the present conspiracy of Labor governments at the Federal and State levels has meant to the road network in this country and to the millions of everyday road users. In the Labor Government's first year of office, $204.6m, expressed in 1987-88 dollar values, was spent on road construction and maintenance. This year, the corresponding figure is only $157.1m. That is a whopping $48m reduction, or a 23 per cent cut in real terms.

This year, the excise on crude oil, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and petroleum products is set to raise $6,433m. That is a massive amount of money, approaching one-tenth of all Federal taxation revenue. During the year, the three Federal road programs have been allocated a total of only $1,215m. Even using the estimates of the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), which include figures for the Australian Capital Territory, this figure is only $1,221.5m. That means that only about one-fifth of excise from crude oil, LPG and petroleum products is being allocated to these road programs.

The Western Australia State Government cannot be proud of its record, either. After increasing State fuel taxes by 125 per cent, one would think that the State's roads would be paved with gold. Not so, Mr Deputy Speaker. In fact, whereas previous governments in that State had always spent every cent of fuel tax on road works, the Labor Administration had other plans.

This year, only half the State fuel tax will be spent on road works. Most of the difference is to be used to prop up the massive losses of Perth's public transport system. It is no wonder that that State Government has been forced to admit that its road works program is totally inadequate. Figures used by the State Government itself show that every 2,500 kilometres of the State's highways and main roads will require reconstruction over the next nine or 10 years-that is, 250 kilometres each year. To date, the State has been averaging only 80 kilometres a year.

The Bill before the House could have reversed this situation-or at least it could have started to make up some lost ground. The importance of this should not be underestimated. Roads are, of course, one of the key prerequisites for economic growth. Furthermore, road conditions impact directly on operating costs. Rough surfaces have been estimated to increase repair bills by up to 36 per cent, and fuel consumption by up to 20 per cent. At a time when Australian industries must endeavour more than ever before to increase their competitive standing, it is only right that the Government should be assisting them and not adding to their costs.

Substandard roads are a prominent factor in many traffic accidents, as well. Problems such as narrow lanes, broken surfaces, blind corners, soft shoulders and poor signposting contribute to an estimated 30 per cent of all crashes. Only recently, I received a letter from a school bus driver who was concerned for the safety of the children he buses to school every day because of the blind corners and gravel roads that confront him every day; he expressed great concern about the matter.

These are powerful arguments in favour of a sensible restructuring of the existing road programs, which place high priority on the need to improve our roads. Clearly, governments at both Federal and State levels must adjust their spending priorities to pay greater attention to the nation's road systems. Experience has shown that good road maintenance costs about 2 per cent of the replacement cost of a length of road. What is more, timely maintenance can double the life of a particular road. In other words, road maintenance is not a cost, it is a saving.

Road construction and maintenance is highly labour intensive-it creates jobs. The Australian Roads Outlook report shows that, for every $1m of road construction expenditure, 62 man-years of employment is generated. The roads sector has among the highest employment generating capacity of all sectors-so much so that roads and road transport related activities employ around half a million people, or more than one in 10 of the Australian work force. It is against that background that we must consider the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill.

The Government, via this Bill, must be capable of demonstrating a real commitment to our road system if it is to make up for its abysmal record so far. More importantly, any new road program must set the scene for the best possible land transport system to be in operation well into the next century. Already, 77 per cent of all domestic freight is moved by road. By the year 2000, total road travel is expected to grow by 60 per cent, including a 100 per cent increase in road freight. I ask the question: Is this Bill up to the job?

The explanatory memorandum accompanying the Bill states that the new program is to take effect on 1 January 1989. Under the program, the share of excise and customs duty allocated to it under the road user charge system is calculated at $571m for the second half of 1988-89. That is in addition to the $650.5m which will be allocated to the two superseded programs in the first half of the year. One does not have to be a mathematical genius to realise that $571m received over six months is equivalent to $1,142m over a full year.

The Government has guaranteed that funding levels for the new program will be maintained in real terms for two years. Also, it has made provision for the amount of road user charge payable to the program to be increased from the current rate of 4.95c per litre, if necessary, to ensure that the overall funding levels set by this legislation are met. Clearly, this will need to be done, unless there is a substantial change in consumption patterns. Yet, in his second reading speech, the Minister provided no clarification of that aspect. There is a massive difference of $79.5m between the level of revenue that the program will receive from road user charges and the level of expenditure guaranteed by this legislation in 1988-89 and 1990-91. Will the Government cover this shortfall by raising the user charge from its present level of 4.95c? Can we really trust the Government on this matter? Certainly not!

I vividly recall the Government's promise to maintain expenditure on roads in real terms following the passing of the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) legislation in 1985. Of course it is now history that this commitment was thrown into the gutter. Road funding fell far behind consumer price index rises, and the allocation of excise per litre of fuel was subsequently slashed from 3.66c per litre to 3.241c per litre. What is to stop the Government from applying the same deceitful tactic to the new centennial roads program?

There is good reason to suspect that the level of tax revenue to be allocated to that new program will be allowed to drop, despite the Government's claim that the Bill guarantees a secure funding environment. I say this because the legislation indexes the new program's funding using the implicit price deflator for non-farm gross domestic product, not simply the consumer price index, which is used to index fuel taxes.

This Bill is called the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill. However, it is not confined to roads. Unlimited amounts of the new program's annual budget which are set aside for arterial roads could be redirected for use on capital railway projects and urban public transport systems. Mr Deputy Speaker, I put it to you that this is hardly a secure basis for road funding.

Earlier I asked whether this Bill was what we need to set the scene as we approach the new century. I asked whether the Bill was up to the job. Unfortunately, there are too many uncertainties. The funding estimates are not spelt out in enough detail. Indeed, there are no estimates at all for the last two years of the program's life. Furthermore, I do not believe that this Bill reflects a genuine concern on the Government's part for the state of our roads. Certainly the Government has done nothing to try to recover lost ground. As such, this Bill will not reverse the massive decline in real terms of road funding under the present Government. It could even reduce the already low priority given to roads, resulting in less expenditure related to vehicle transport and a greater proportion on more general land transport projects.

In any event, the bottom line shows that this new program is to be established from a very low funding base. There is not enough money in the jar in the first place to do the job properly, so it really does not matter how it is distributed. As one local government representative said, `It is just like shuffling deck chairs on the Titanic'. Clearly, this Bill is not up to the job. As a result, motorists will continue to ask: Where are the roads our petrol taxes are paying for?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill. In so doing, I would like basically to concentrate my remarks on the local level as it affects my electorate of McMillan. Before doing so, I think it is important to say a few words in relation to the debate on road funding that has been going on in Australia. I do not think any other subject has received more attention in local newspapers or more front page coverage in rural Australia. One can almost back it in that at least every two or three weeks a story will be printed in a local paper about some councillor somewhere making statements in relation to roads-some correct, some political and some totally incorrect. I think the public at large is getting rather sick of the constant discussion on this subject. Statistics and figures are constantly quoted, to the point where people have completely lost interest in that side of the argument and want some real discussion as to what is going on in the area of road funding.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), who is at the table, for providing the facts to many people. Since 1983 there has been a genuine approach by this Government. There has been a 21 per cent increase in the moneys provided by this Government in its six years in office as against the moneys provided by the previous government in its six years in office. I think that is something that has been missed in the debates reported in the country press, particularly where figures which are taken from 1984-85 are related to 1988 and the figures for 1983-84 are ignored.

My electorate of McMillan has been one of the real beneficiaries of the money that has been spent by the Commonwealth on the road program over the last six years. In 1979, the Princes Highway east was declared a development road. Since that time the Federal Government has spent an estimated $126m on upgrading a significant portion of the Princes Highway east. More than 70 per cent of the 170-kilometre section between Dandenong and Traralgon is now a four-lane divided carriageway, allowing free access to the rapidly developing industrial sectors along the route and to many tourist areas in Gippsland.

It has been very pleasing for me, as the local member, to watch the massive works that have been going on in that area and to see that highway being gradually improved. Major works currently approved on that highway include the Tynong project duplication from Nar Nar Goon to the Bunyip River. The approved funds for that project total $26.2m and it is estimated to cost $39m. It is expected to be completed in late 1989. I was fortunate to be present at the opening of the first section of that project by the State Minister. It is a beautiful highway and the people in our area certainly appreciate it.

The next section that has been approved is the Longwarry project duplication from Bunyip River to what is called the Robin Hood end, which will connect with the Drouin bypass which was opened in 1984. The approved funds for that project total $17.5m and it is estimated to cost $24m. The expected completion date is 1993. For the benefit of the Minister, who is at the able, I was recently taken on an inspection of that project. It is a massive project, the first stage of which required $1m-odd to fill in a rather large gully. Of course, this section of the highway requires two completely new lanes which will create a completely new highway through new territory. That is a massive project and I hope it will be completed by 1993. However, I have some considerable doubts about the country through which that highway is going because it is such a terribly wet area. The Government may need to put a lot more funding into that project than expected.

The next duplication is from the Moe River. The approved funds for this project at this stage total $3.8m and it is estimated to cost $20m. Completion is expected in 1994. The bypass is to be constructed through the township of Morwell. The approved funds total $19m and the project is estimated to cost $38m. These projects are all in the electorate of McMillan. Completion is expected by 1990. That section ran into some difficulties because it is so close to the open cut mines. In that part of the world we have only 10 or 15 feet of top soil and then 1,000 feet of coal. It is a little difficult to build a solid base for a highway on top of a coal base and, of course, the costs for that project have blown out. When the Minister gets an opportunity to visit the area, I am sure that he will see that for himself. A further $60m is required to fulfil existing commitments and I am sure that this Bill will be vital in that area. As a development road category will not exist under the Australian centennial roads development program, the Road Construction Authority in Victoria has sought completion under the national arterial category, utilising national highway funds. I am sure that that will occur.

Recently I was able to lead a delegation from the Central Gippsland Road Funding Committee, which covers not only my area but also the electorate of the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), which met with the Minister, as the Minister will remember. One of the things that I want to bring before this House is the major problem that areas such as Gippsland have had in the past in the area of road funding. I strongly support the case that people in local government in this area have been putting. I refer to the fact that the formula structures that have been in place in the past certainly have not taken into account the topography, the hilly nature, of the countryside, and the high rainfall in relation to the needs per kilometre of road. The case that that Road Funding Committee put to the Minister was that the formula structure has always created a climate in which other parts of Victoria with more solid bases to build roads, where it is much cheaper to build roads, were getting an advantage over the Gippsland area.

The question that needs to be asked is: Why is that so? Basically, it is because the local government organisations in the country areas which make these decisions and make recommendations to governments are National Party dominated. Where they have a majority they are able to ensure that the money and the formulas suit those areas. Of course, Gippsland has always missed out in relation to the formula style of funding for roads. Whereas 10 kilometres of road can be built for $X in some parts of Victoria, only two or three kilometres can be built in Gippsland. Therefore, we have a difficulty with the formula structure. I have always put forward the case that it would be much better if a method were developed whereby there could be a more equitable approach to take into account the problems that exist in south Victoria, particularly in the Gippsland region.

Another change which has taken place and which I think is a good change as far as local government is concerned-it is a positive approach we do not read a great deal about in the press-has been the increased cooperation between the engineers at local level and the Road Construction Authority main engineer, Mr Norm Butler, in my area. He has convinced some of the engineers to take a more moderate approach to some of the road reconstruction. In the last 18 months they have developed an operation by which they actually mix the road that is already there and put it together-a cement stabilisation approach. By this method they are able to do some of the local roads much more cheaply and efficiently. There is a bit of debate between the engineers as to how long these roads will stand up to the traffic that is moving across them. From what I have seen so far, they have stood up beautifully to the first test. Time will tell which engineers are correct and, out of necessity, there may be a development by the engineers of a much cheaper way of putting our roads back into order, rather than rebuilding them from new bases.

I hope that some of these efforts by local government will mean that our dollars will go further and some of our roads will be brought back to the standard that is required today. Many of these roads were built many years ago and were not designed to carry big milk tankers and log trucks that are using them today. I believe that there has been neglect of roads over many years-not by this Government, but by previous governments which, for 20 or 30 years, did not have a plan for replacing them at the end of their normal life. I hope that this approach which is now being put together will be successful and, on the evidence so far, I think that will certainly be the case.

I do not want to go into the Bill in any great depth as other members have covered that in the debate so far. I just wish to remind the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, who is at the table, of the invitation to visit our area. We hope to be able to give him a couple of days to see the problems that can be caused by a formula approach to road funding and how sometimes some of our political opponents who like to make a lot of noise about road funding create a lot of the problems then seek to blame a Labor government for them, when actually they result from an internal fight amongst some of the local government people who are not able to engineer the numbers to get the formula that they require.

I strongly support the Bill. I would like to see much more money spent on roads if possible because at present it would create a lot more work. In the present circumstances this Bill has an indexed amount of funds and I am sure that if the cases can be made as the economy becomes stronger, more money will be made available.

In conclusion, the only other point I would like to make is that local government in these areas perhaps could do a lot more in relation to amalgamations and use of its machinery and equipment as is happening now in Gippsland. We have so many shires in Victoria and I am always amazed that all the shires can have so much equipment sitting around that could be used much more effectively. I believe that will happen, I think it is something else that the Central Gippsland committee would like to discuss with the Minister when he visits us. I fully support this Bill and in the next couple of years I look forward to an extension of the funds made available for roads as we improve the economy in Australia and start to pay off our debts which are our No. 1 priority at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill, I wish to pick up some points made by Government speakers. This Bill replaces the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Fund and the Australian land transport program which were both introduced by the previous Government. The Australian Bicentennial Road Development Fund was introduced in 1982-83 and in that financial year had only started to raise money for the funding of roads; it had not come fully on stream. It was not until 1983-84 that the full effect of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Fund was felt. It is on this basis that I wish to take issue with some of the Government speakers because they are quite deliberately misleading the members of this House by trying to compare the figures of the previous Fraser Government and the current Government and suggest that there are major differences. If one is to make a realistic comparison one has to look at that first year when the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Fund was on full stream, namely 1983-84, to see how this Government has performed in relation to road funding. Federal road funding money given in the whole of the life of the present Government reached its peak in 1983-84. Since then it has fallen quite dramatically. The funds have been frozen in dollar terms. In fact in the mini-Budget there was a further $33m cut and it was reduced to around $1,215m, and this present Centennial Road Development Fund will continue with its unusual form of indexation. When members opposite get up and try to make a comparison, they are not comparing like with like, they are quite deliberately misleading the public, and I think they ought to be pulled up quickly and made to realise that if they want to be credible they ought to start comparing like with like and not two matters that are quite different.

SPEECH.PARA: The choice of name for this fund is interesting-from the Bicentennial Road Development Fund to the Centennial Roads Development Fund; obviously a step backwards. In terms of road funding it certainly is a step backwards. It reminds everyone yet again that the Government has cut road funding and cut it significantly in real terms every year over the last four years. In real terms it is a cut of something like 30 per cent. At the same time the Government has indexed the fuel excise, so more and more money is being raised. It is going straight into Consolidated Revenue and proportionately less and less is going back to road funding.

I would also like to point out that this Bill reinforces the claim that the Government continues to cut road funding. As pointed out by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) earlier, by using the implicit price deflater-most Australians would wonder what on earth that was; they would think it was a blow-up doll or something-the Government can continue to reduce road funding. It is worse that that. It is not just a question of the Government reducing road funding. We are witnessing the running down of our very infrastructure-an infrastructure that is so important, particularly to people in the country, because in most cases they have no other form of transport. Without decent roads the arteries of their whole lifestyle are removed.

This Federal Government continues to reduce road funding, to run down this infrastructure and to ignore the advice of every shire engineer right throughout Australia when warning after warning is given that the roads are disintegrating and that additional funding will be needed if they are to be maintained. It is not just the roads, it is also the bridges, which have so far not been mentioned. In the limited time available today I will not go into that in any detail but the bridges in many places in country Australia are reaching the end of their life. A massive injection of funds will be needed if we are not to see a wholesale failure of those bridges in many parts of Australia.

The Government not only continues to let the roads deteriorate but it also ignore the warnings, not just of the engineers but also of all the affiliates of the Australian Automobile Association. It continues to ignore the feelings of people. I will give an example in my electorate. On a cold night in the middle of winter, 252 people came to a meeting in a little country town to discuss road funding and to register their concern about the fact that the local roads in their shire are disintegrating and being returned to gravel. This Government continues to ignore the problem and pretends everything is okay because people in the city have not noticed. As I have said before, excise continues to rise. I put it in the words of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) when he said some time ago, but it is still appropriate today, `the Government has made every petrol pump into a branch of the Tax Office'. Like the Treasurer's best friend, Miss Bracket Creep, these taxes just keep growing.

It begs the obvious questions: Is there less use of roads? Are there fewer vehicles today than there were, say, five years ago? Are Australians turning away from cars? Are there fewer trucks on the roads today than, say, five years ago? Obviously, the answer to all these questions is no. Furthermore, not only is the answer no, but there are predictions that by the year 2000 the number of cars on our roads will have increased by 30 per cent and the amount of road freight on our roads will have increased by a staggering 60 per cent. Yet the Government continues to say it will not increase road funding.

These are not just statistics. We want to look at why in human terms this legislation is hopelessly inadequate, at why we are short-changing the public by cutting road funding and at why, again in human terms, we have a national disaster on our hands. In the limited time I have available I want to concentrate on the road toll-the needless loss of life, the needless suffering of families and of victims of road trauma and the loss to our country from all these unnecessary crashes. The statistics concerning what inadequate road funding is causing in our country are staggering. The biggest killer of Australians under 45 years of age is not cancer, not heart disease, but road crashes. Last year 2,800 Australian died on our roads and 30,000 were injured, many crippled and maimed for life. A lot were children. Since 1980 25,000 Australians have died on our roads. They are people, not statistics. That is equivalent to wiping out the entire population of a place like Bathurst or Shepparton, or Port Lincoln and Port Pirie combined, or Bunbury, or Alice Springs twice over.

Since 1980 nearly a quarter of a million Australians have been injured in road crashes, and the fact is that poor roads contributed to 30 per cent of those crashes. Furthermore, the Australian Road Transport Federation, a well recognised and well respected organisation, has estimated that the cumulative effect of Labor's road funding cuts will cost Australia 7,000 lives through road crashes by the year 2000. So 7,000 lives will be lost unnecessarily because of inadequate road funding. That is about 600 a year from now until the year 2000. Frankly, I find it unbelievable that Australians should have to put up with the disastrously high road toll that we suffer. Daily we see the misery brought about by road accidents that, if not resulting in death, certainly leave their victims with horrible disabilities and the victims' families traumatised. The pity of it all is that many of these accidents are preventable, or at least the injuries and fatalities reducible, simply by providing better and safer roads. Why is it that we do not look at the roads themselves as the solution to road accidents? We seem ever ready to do everything else. We increase police numbers, we reduce road speeds, we legislate for the compulsory wearing of seat belts and we control the legal blood alcohol content for drivers; we do all sorts of peripheral things, some of which are certainly worth while, but we have a hang-up about making enough money available to construct decent roads and hence get to the root cause of much of our road toll.
