Why do we have such a hang-up? The Treasurer finds it quite easy to reduce the excise on beer but he seems to find it very difficult to increase funding for roads. I could go on and on but as I know we have limited time I will just say in conclusion that this Bill masquerades as the Government's attempt to cover up its inadequate level of road funding, and its continued inadequate level of road funding in the future. Frankly, I support the amendment of the honourable member for Richmond in which he suggests that the Bill should be withdrawn. I also think it should be withdrawn, redrawn and redrafted, and at the same time the Government's commitment to road funding should be increased dramatically to make a more realistic share of Commonwealth revenue available for roads to do something worth while towards reducing the number of road accidents that occur today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the money coming from?

—That is just what I like to hear from the honourable member for Calare. If the Treasurer can find $400m to cut the beer excise, I suggest he has his priorities wrong. Why should he not put another $400m into road funding?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill and oppose the amendment so vigorously supported by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). Unfortunately I do not think he understands the process which this Bill went through before it was finally brought into the House. I must commend the Ministers who have had responsibility for the carriage of this Bill over past months, and I say that particularly in relation to the review that took place involving not only the Commonwealth Government but State and local governments, major road and transport bodies, and motorist organisations. I remind the honourable member for Wannon about that. Road funding does not exist in isolation from the general economy. I remind him about that as well. The Government looks toward maintaining its existing road assets and recognises the importance of roads as an essential part of our economic infrastructure. I am sure the honourable member recognises that.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill reflects a realistic approach to the question of road funding because, as we are all aware, road funds are limited. The basic purpose of the Bill is to provide a new federal road funding program. From 1 January 1989 that will replace both of the Government's current road programs, the bicentennial road development program and the Australian land transport program. The legislation contains new initiatives which will set the direction of road funding towards the year 2000. I stress that the Government's economic agenda emphasises the need for the structural adjustment of Australia's major industries. Improvement of our land transport sector is integral to this process of structural adjustment. I would have thought the honourable member for Wannon would have recognised that as well. Cheaper, safer and more efficient transport can only mean greater success in our attempts to make industries more competitive, especially in remote areas such as the Northern Territory, which of course is my electorate.

The emphasis in the Bill is on roads of national economic significance by establishing a new category of `national arterials' to improve road access to major industries. Secondly, it aims to get better value for every dollar spent on roads by providing for revised administrative arrangements, with the States assuming greater responsibility and accountability for ensuring that projects are completed on budget and to an appropriate standard. This will guarantee efficiency in the delivery of the new road program. The program continues to provide a base level of assistance for State arterial and local roads.

Road transport is of fundamental importance to the economic and social well-being of the Northern Territory. Anyone who has been there and seen the distances and isolation faced by many of the rural centres will be aware of this fact. Many centres in the Northern Territory, including Aboriginal communities, are without airstrips and are therefore totally dependent on road transport. Unlike the States, the Northern Territory has a small manufacturing base which means that many basic items, including food and petroleum products, must be imported from interstate. It is estimated that road freight accounts for 98 per cent of all intra-Territory freight. On Monday, in debate on the Australian National Railways Commission Bill I commented on the fact that in excess of 90 per cent of freight into Alice Springs arrives by rail from down south, via Adelaide and Port Augusta. Semitrailers with containers are piggy-backed to Alice Springs on the back of a train, offloaded and transported up the track. It is a very important integrated freight network which has been developed using Australian National's railways and the road transport network of the Northern Territory, and therefore roads are of fundamental and essential importance to the Northern Territory in providing the very necessities for people to exist.

Territorians, especially in the smaller inland centres such as Katherine and Tennant Creek, can only benefit from the legislation before the House as the Australian centennial roads development program will facilitate faster, cheaper and safer freight movements into the Territory. The road transport system in the Territory provides the basic infrastructure for the most of the Northern Territory's major industries. I am sure any honourable members who have travelled through the Territory will have seen this. I know the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) has been there recently as a member of the country task force set up by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and he would have been very impressed with the Territory. I must say that the response of the Prime Minister's country task force to the problems evident in the Northern Territory has given me cause to be very thankful that I am involved in that task force, and I thank the honourable member for Calare and the other members of the task force for their efforts.

Statistics on the tourism industry in the Northern Territory indicate that nearly half of interstate visitors to the Territory enter by road. Once in the Territory, 87 per cent of visitors use the road system, so as it is improved it encourages travellers to stay longer and venture further. The Australian centennial roads program identifies the importance of roads for the tourism industry. I refer, for example, to the Olgas road. I say to the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), if I may put in a plug, that the Olgas road is probably one of the worst roads in the Northern Territory but one of the most used. I urge the Minister to give favourable consideration to the upgrading of that road when he is considering funding the next Budget. I am told that the upgrading will cost in the vicinity of $8m. I thank him for his support.

In terms of developing the north, it is apparent that geographical patterns of expenditure are better spread by road than by other forms of transport which rely more heavily on terminal nodes. The pastoral industry in the Northern Territory also derives substantial benefits from Commonwealth Government expenditure on roads. I am sure that those members who have driven in the Northern Territory will have confronted from time to time semitrailers with three bogies, carrying enormous numbers of cattle. The road transport system is fundamental to the success of the cattle industry in the Northern Territory because by far the major proportion of cattle raised in the Northern Territory are driven out of the Territory by way of the road transport system. This roads program will be of importance both in regard to improved assistance for road trains and improved access for individual properties.

Commonwealth road programs have provided vital energy for the social and economic life of the Territory. In fact, since 1983-84 the Federal Government has allocated a total of $234.2m to the Northern Territory for national arterial and local roads. I do not say that we have received enough money, but I understand the restrictions and constraints that have been placed on revenue by the structural changes we have been talking about and the demands on our economy generally. I will continue to pursue the objective of increasing expenditure on roads in the Northern Territory. I assure the Minister that he can expect to see me in his office at some future date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My concern about the Bill before the House, the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill 1988, is whether it will measure up to the actual demands of transport, particularly road transport, over the years ahead. We have to appreciate that today 54 per cent of our transport requirements are met by road transport. I do not think that there would be a local government body or a State government that would be happy with the legislation that is before the Parliament. There are a couple of factors that I wish to raise this afternoon. I am sorry that, as a result of time constraints, we can only make 10-minute speeches, because there are many matters I would like to raise that would have a general influence on demands for better roads in this continent.

SPEECH.PARA: When the first petrol tax Bill was introduced in, I think, 1944-it raised a levy of one penny per gallon-the money was earmarked for road construction. After that, various amendments and new pieces of legislation were introduced, and gradually a greater proportion of the excise on petrol and diesel fuel went to Consolidated Revenue. Today, of the 21.4c that the Commonwealth receives from the sale of every litre of petrol only 5c or a little less is spent on roads for construction and maintenance purposes.

I know that the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) would argue that we have to look at the priorities of roads compared with other demands in Australia. I do not believe that, were I to go to my electors and councils in my electorate and say, `The petrol tax is not specifically to be spent on roads and bridges', they would accept that. So the Opposition can state realistically that there are very strong reasons why the government in power has to treat roads as a major priority. That is what I want to argue today.

I do not want to talk about the fact that road funding has increased since 1982-83. Certainly, that is so. Funding has increased from about $850m to about $1,245m, as part of the Australian bicentennial road development (ABRD) program. Maybe we cannot blame the Government for taking the credit for this extra spending on roads, but we can criticise it for the fact that, after two or three years, that figure has remained at $1221.5m. That is the important point. That is the Commonwealth's contribution to all of the roads in Australia. The States are terribly dependent on this funding. Thank God the newly elected New South Wales Government has said that it will spend approximately $180m a year by putting money received from registration fees into State road funding.

Were I to put up the arguments that have been posed by some of the other speakers from the Opposition benches this afternoon, the safety argument alone is the one which should convince the Government to give priority to roads. Irrespective of health, education, defence and other requirements, from an integral point of view every member of this House is dependent upon the money that is to be spent on roads, because transport is such an important part of the cost of production and the cost of the finished article in every store and industry throughout the Commonwealth.

I have some figures which are interesting, particularly in the agricultural field. The retail price of sheep today includes a 6.6 per cent transport component. For cereal grains it is 12.5 per cent; for cattle, 13.3 per cent; for dairy cattle and pigs, 7.7 per cent; for meat products, 6.7 per cent; and for milk products, 6.9 per cent. I could talk about minerals and other products and resources that we sell. Transport is a major part of that expenditure.

I say to the Government that it has to consider these priorities in light of the huge cost of the safety aspects, approaching $6,000m a year, to cope with deaths upon the roads, damage to vehicles, insurance, and everything else. That is the cost to this nation. Nobody can tell me that there is a greater need for priority of spending than for roads. I ask the Government to consider that point in light of the demands of a continent such as Australia that is so geographically broad. We have mineral resources throughout the land. We have to put roads into those places to service the industries concerned.

The honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) is sitting beside me. I know he would like to speak in this debate-he will not have time to do so because the time allowed for debate will expire-on the issue of the Pacific Highway. Four Federal members recently spoke with the Minister in that regard, and we were sympathetically received by him. The fact is that that roadway is under pressure. Over 12,000 vehicles of all types travel upon certain sections of that roadway every day. It urgently needs upgrading. The number of fatalities which occur on that road are greater than for any other road of such length and importance. We want to see something done in that regard. We want to know from the Minister the details of the national arterial road program. We know that the States have to put up their propositions to the Minister. We ask him to look sympathetically at this important road that serves this area of growth.

I remember years ago Mr Dusseldorp said that that area would be a major growth area-and so it is. People are moving to Page, Lyne and other electorates in that area. The tourism industry will continue to grow, as will primary industry, the area's importance as a retirement area, and the other factors that attract people to that area. We would be most grateful if we could be advised fairly clearly as to the details of national arterial road funding.

If the States put up a proposition that the Pacific Highway be a national arterial road, will he agree to that classification? We realise that the Minister has only a certain amount of money in his pocket. He has only $1,221.5m to work with. This is the important thing: What road programs will be cut back? We are concerned about the rural arterial roads, the rural local roads and the urban local roads because they are very important. They carry the produce, our school bus services and all the other things one likes to think about.

We are very concerned also about how the Minister will allocate funding under this program after the next two years. We are concerned about clause 10 of the Bill. If the Minister could say a little about that clause in his response I would be grateful. I would like him to tell us how funding will work out under the indexation factor. It is not the consumer price index but that is the term I use. We know that for the next two years the funding level will be maintained. But local government and the Australian community want to know about what the increases will be in the remaining 3 1/2 years. There will be at least a 3 per cent increase a year in traffic on the roads of Australia. Because of the great demand we see for roads we want to know what the increase will be. As I said at the outset, we believe the legislation does not measure up to the requirements for transport in this country. Fifteen per cent of the retail price of imported goods is attributable to transport. Industry-whether rural, natural resources, or service-faces an exceptionally high cost component, up to 15 per cent in some cases, directly related to the cost of transport.

I warn the Minister. We know he is sympathetic to our cause; we do not challenge him on that. We know that the Minister will have to be darn strong in Cabinet and in the Government to be able to get the extra money that is needed for road maintenance and construction within this country. The Opposition will give him every support. I am not being critical of the Minister; I respect him. But we will pursue him on these particular issues because we have such a belief in the priority that roads should hold in the Budget. That is what we are fighting for. That is what we are asking to have favourably considered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill is a very important piece of legislation. All honourable members who listened to the just concluded speech by the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) would probably agree with me that it was a very interesting and valuable contribution to the debate this afternoon. I congratulate the honourable member for Lyne on his very constructive comments and his well-deserved praise for the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown). All honourable members, particularly those who represent country Australia, would join with the honourable member for Lyne and others in this House in urging the Minister to prevail upon his Cabinet colleagues in future deliberations to recognise the importance of the road network, particularly for country Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It was a refreshing change to hear a very positive contribution from the Opposition this afternoon. However, I must say that the Opposition generally has launched a rather spurious attack on the Government for its record on road funding, spurred on by the Australian Automobile Association (AAA). The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) earlier this afternoon talked about road fatalities and accidents. He sought to blame inadequate road funding. He implied that if we had a four-lane highway system all around Australia this would probably significantly reduce road fatalities and accidents. That is probably true. But I think the honourable member was drawing a very long bow indeed when he suggested that all the problems could be solved in that way. Take, for example, the fine city of Canberra. Most people would agree that there are very fine roads throughout the city. But honourable members should also have a look at some of the accidents that take place on what are some of the finest roads in Australia. There are many other fine highways with significant accident records. It is not a question of attributing road fatalities and accidents generally to the level of road funding.

Many members of the Opposition have simply resorted to regurgitating the lines of the Australian Automobile Association and its affiliates. The Opposition needs to consider whether it is living in glasshouses and simply throwing stones. Figures that have been obtained from the Economic Planning Advisory Council paper No. 33, entitled `Economic Infrastructure in Australia', indicate a dramatic fall in Commonwealth road expenditure during the Fraser-Howard years. If we use 1984-85 prices as a constant, Federal road funding fell under the Fraser-Howard Government from $1.350m in 1976 to just over $900m in 1982. The introduction of the Australian bicentennial road development program saw a very rapid increase in road funding. Many people have alluded to that very fine program. In 1984-85 prices, funding was back to almost $1,300m by mid-1983.

The ABRD was a great marketing tool and an excuse by the Fraser Government to make amends for its rather pathetic record on road infrastructure in the period from 1976 to 1982. All it was doing was essentially restoring the status quo that existed in 1976. The local and State government road funding, which had also declined during the years of the coalition Government, began to increase after 1982, following the introduction of the ABRD program, in response to the additional funding on a Federal level.

Both the Opposition and the Australian Automobile Association have chosen to ignore the positive approach that has been taken by the Hawke Government. For example, the proportion of rural local roads that are sealed is increasing and increasing quite significantly, from 15 per cent in 1981 to a forecast of 19 per cent by next year. As rural local roads constitute nearly 80 per cent of the Australian road network, this increase is a very significant one. It means that an additional 25,400 kilometres of rural local roads have been sealed, which is over 1 1/2 times the length of the national highway system which all honourable members would agree has been one of the great bipartisan projects in national infrastructure this decade.

The Australian centennial road development program will ensure that the real value of road funding this financial year is maintained next year and the year after. Naturally, we are keen to see that, as economic circumstances improve, we rally behind the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support because of the importance of road funding to our electorates. Most people expect and realise that it is not a task that can be accomplished simply by one plucking money from here, there or anywhere. It requires a very delicate balancing trick at times. We also need to stress, as many people have stressed here today, the significance of particular road funding projects that they see as important in their own electorates.

The Australian Automobile Association and other car clubs would agree that this is still not enough money. I think they have a Mr Micawber approach to the whole question of road funding. They whinge like Billabong Bill the whinger and hope that something will turn up from the Government as a result of their whinging. It just does not operate in that way. Responsible government has to set priorities for spending. More spending on roads either means higher taxes or means that money for other essential services required by the population at large will suffer-things such as hospitals, schools, pensions, care for the aged, child-care and so on.

The car organisations would say that much more of the money that is contributed through the fuel excise should go to road funding, as if to say that road users do not use the other, wide, range of government services, and that, therefore, their money should not be contributed to other things. The Opposition and these lobby groups carry on as if the Government is stealing their money for no good purpose, as if excise collected in excess of road funding requirements is wasted. But, as we all know, the money is well spent on much needed community services and facilities.

The attitude of some of the local councils intrigues me. A wide range of attitudes is being displayed by councils. Some councils simply write to individual members of parliament or to all parliamentarians throughout Australia and point out that road funding is a tripartite exercise-which it is. When I have taken the trouble to write back and agree with them that road funding is a tripartite exercise, and when I have sought information from those councils as to their level of contribution to road funding from their own sources of funds over the previous five years, I have been met with a deafening silence in most cases. Some local councils would probably be somewhat embarrassed by those figures. One has to keep things in perspective. If one maintains that road funding is a tripartite effort one should be prepared to say that one's bona fides in that regard are realistic.

To get back to organisations such as the National Roads and Motorists Association, for example, do they not know that the Hawke Government has demonstrated a much greater concern for road funding and maintenance than the Fraser-Howard Government ever demonstrated? In the period 1983-84 to 1988-89, $2,372.8m has been allocated to New South Wales roads by the Federal Government. I am somewhat concerned at times by the grandstanding of some Opposition members who seem to be blissfully ignorant of the way in which the road funding arrangements operate under our constitution. In many cases we do not have the opportunity at a Federal level to determine where the Commonwealth contribution is spent in a particular State. As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lyne has mentioned, often agreements must be entered into by the Commonwealth and the State concerned to the mutual benefit of both parties.

I refer to a recent and very positive meeting I had with the Minister and the Sydney Road Links Committee. That Committee is chaired by by alderman of the Bathurst City Council, Alderman Max Hanrahan. The Secretary is Mr Chris Pitken, the Deputy Clerk of the Bathurst City Council. As I said, we recently met with the Minister. We have met with his predecessor, State transport Ministers of all political parties and previous Federal transport Ministers of the Fraser Government. In my view-and I am sure that the Minister agrees with me-State transport Ministers have always adopted a very positive attitude. They are not there haranguing the Federal Minister, saying `We want our money, and we want it now. We want to spend it on this particular road'. They have taken the constructive attitude that the honourable member for Lyne took in his contribution to this debate, that is, that we should recognise that some roads have a very high usage component and that we need to examine priorities from time to time and to convince all the parties involved that a certain step is worthwhile.

I hope that all honourable members who make a contribution to this debate will follow the example of the Sydney Road Links Committee which was lobbied very hard and put up a very strong case. I think that, over the next few years, we will see very positive results regarding the road through the Blue Mountains to central western New South Wales. I am sure that we will also see positive results regarding the Pacific Highway in New South Wales. I congratulate the Minister on the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill. I think it will make a positive contribution to the betterment of road infrastructure in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take only half of my allotted and reduced time, notwithstanding the importance of the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill, because I appreciate the need to allow other members to speak in this debate. I support the second reading amendment moved by my colleague the shadow Minister for transport and aviation, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), which is all about getting a fair dinkum indexation factor into road funding rather than the much narrower and less generous factor which the legislation provides.

SPEECH.PARA: For too long road funding has been chiselled away at, cut back and reduced in such a way that the maintenance, revamping and reconstruction of major roads have broken down. We will pay an awful price for that, especially in times of extreme conditions such as periods of heavy rainfall. Whole sections of roads will collapse. That is exactly what happened in Balranald Shire earlier this year. I highlight that in the context of this legislation. The wording of the second reading amendment is all about injecting a fair dinkum indexation factor into the Bill, rather than a hybrid factor which would allow the Government to get away with lowering road funding in a disgraceful manner.

I refer to the Hume Highway, a national highway, which relates in part to the provisions of the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill. Partly in anticipation of this debate this week, last Friday night I left Sydney at 1.30 a.m. in a small Ford Telstar, which was the car I owned at the time. I drove it through the suburbs of Sydney and down the Hume Highway in all sorts of dry and wet conditions in the middle of the night after a busy sitting week, eventually arriving at Holbrook as daylight broke in time to attend and unofficially open at 8 a.m. the Holbrook Show, before going on to a number of electorate functions. After that experience, I am satisfied that the Hume Highway should be renamed the `Hume hellway', not so much because of the condition of the road-I know that the Princes Highway and other highways are deficient in terms of their construction-but because of the attitude of a minority of truck drivers who have decided to lay down their own laws, to set their own anti-social behavioural patterns in the way they conduct their vehicles down that highway each night in both directions, creating havoc for ordinary motorists in 101 different and very dangerous situations.

This was referred to in the Good Weekend magazine in the Sydney Morning Herald of 3 September 1988. It was pointed out that, in 1987, there were 147 accidents involving semi-trailers on the Hume Highway between Sydney and Albury. I invite honourable members to take into account another aspect of this statistic: 135 of those 147 accidents occurred at speeds above the legal limits, resulting in eight fatalities and many people being injured. This does not concern all semi-trailers, by any means-not even a majority of them. But there is a minority of semi-trailer drivers who deliberately terrorise motorists on the Hume Highway, night after night. They deliberately establish a shocking code of conduct.

Once they establish that there are no police cars out and about on a particular section of the highway, they deliberately travel at unbelievable speeds of 120, 130 and 140 kilometres an hour. They deliberately tailgate each other, notwithstanding the mist, fog and light rainshowers that might be falling at the time and in my experience notwithstanding the fact that the road was a difficult section of the Hume Highway-or hellway. I refer to the Cullarin range section of the highway between Goulburn and Yass in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp).

It is not good enough that that conduct is allowed to take place. Certainly, as more divided sections of the Hume Highway are constructed, the problem will ease by degrees; but, in the meantime, we should appeal to the heavy vehicle drivers who utilise the Hume Highway-and the other key highways between Sydney and Brisbane and elsewhere around Australia to behave in the interests of saving the lives of motorists, in the interests of their own safety and those of the nation.

Finally, I remind the House that the Bill before us provides funding for rail transport in certain circumstances. That is in accord with what the Australian land transport program legislation provided for. There is provision to fund railway development and that is not without its important ramifications as we start to succeed in getting across the message that the twenty-first century will be all about providing a revitalised, revamped, form of rail transport in this country on certain key corridors. Those rail funding provisions are there. No specific commitment is given to the actual funding, but it allows me to point out again to the House that in terms of direct comparison, a steel wheel on a steel rail has one-tenth of the friction of a rubber-tyred wheel on a bitumen surface. Therein lies the efficiency factor which confers the benefit provided by rail transport. That is why there is a future for rail, a future well into and beyond the next century. It is one we must start planning for. I am pleased that this legislation provides that basis, but it is at the expense of some road funding.

I add that for every kilometre of freeway constructed, approximately four times the land acreage is required than is needed for an extra kilometre of double track standard gauge railway line. That is not yet a significant factor in Australia but try the United Kingdom for size where land is very short and precious. That is one factor which is swinging transport planners back to rail as the way to go, ahead of the opening of the tunnel between the United Kingdom and France. That is why it is important that this rail funding provision is in this legislation being discussed by the House tonight.

I hope that it will lead to some actual funding, a revamping and a contribution by the Federal Government, especially on those key corridor routes, in particular, the Sydney-Goulburn-Wagga-Albury-Melbourne existing rail route which is now standardised but which is still very antiquated by any means of assessing that. It results in much freight going on the road which logically should go on rail. I commend the amendment so successfully moved to this legislation by my colleague the honourable member for Richmond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recognise the hour and the fact that there are other members of the coalition who would like to participate in this debate, so my remarks will be appropriately brief. I was forced into this House by comments made by the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), who said, in defending the Government's stand on this legislation, that the excise collected in excess of road funding is spent on essentials. I could not let the opportunity slip without standing in this House and saying, `What is more essential in the electorates of members creditably in the chamber'-all of them, with the exception of the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), represented by coalition members-`than upgraded road facilities?'. The constituents of the electorates of Page, Mallee, Richmond, and my own electorate of Wakefield, depend entirely upon roads for any reasonable form of transportation. Their lifestyle, whether it involves schooling, hospitals, or sporting facilities, is built on the capacity to get from a property to a community. More than that, these same people who live in rural Australia are entirely dependent upon roads in order to get from their properties to the ports the very products that this Government is currently relying on to turn around its balance of payments deficit. So I challenge the honourable member for Calare and ask him what it is that is more essential than roads that justifies his saying that we ought to be prepared to take from the bowser so much money in excise and cream it off into other government facilities. Does he suppose that murals for builders labourers or even child care facilities should have some precedence over road funding?

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the statements made by the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall). He effectively outlined what is the current statistical reality facing the Government and the nation in road funding. In the legislation currently being debated, the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill, we are determining to set aside $1.215 billion to be indexed for the nation's roads. Superficially, that sounds fine. In fact, it is the Minister's intention to earmark 4.95c per litre-variable as I understand it from the legislation-for just that purpose. If more fuel is sold less than 4.95c per litre will be made available. However, this money is to be indexed not according to the consumer price index (CPI) which has been the customary index for government expenditure but according to this figure known as the implicit price deflator for non-farm product. This figure represents 8 per cent less in real terms than the CPI has over recent years.

I do not want to delay the House, but I express on behalf of the constituents of Wakefield our concern that the funding currently being earmarked will not in any way meet what will be the need to rebuild roads in order to maintain this national infrastructure. If the Minister needs any evidence of what has happened to road funding over recent times, he might consider for a moment that there was a time when 66 per cent of the excise collected on fuel was spent on national roads. That, of course, was under conservative governments. Today, 23 per cent of the excise collected is spent on roads. Need any more be said to reinforce the point that this legislation simply does not address one of the fundamental needs of rural communities around Australia?

I pick up the remarks of the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) who pointed out this morning what is the statistical reality of road funding currently facing every resident, particularly residents in rural Australia. The Minister must be sensitive to the plea that comes from local government bodies and motoring organisations around this nation. Clearly the present system for road funding does not meet with the approval of electorates anywhere around the nation. We must be prepared to identify those areas of government expenditure which are no longer as essential as is the building up of our national road network.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) for giving me the opportunity to speak in this debate. As there are only a few moments in which to speak, I will refer directly to the Goulburn bypass, although there are a number of issues of concern in the electorate of Gilmore. Firstly, the Princes Highway running through the south coast of New South Wales and the Olympic Way running between Young, Cowra and Cootamundra are in a shocking condition. As the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) mentioned in his speech, from his drive along the Hume Highway the other day, he can confirm that the Cullarin range is also in critical need of improvement. It should have been improved by now. Work on the Goulburn bypass should have started in 1984. The promise was made to the people of Goulburn that it would begin in 1984 and be completed by 1988. By now, traffic should be going around Goulburn ensuring that Goulburn is able to retain its main street and keep it for itself, saving the city from evident danger.

SPEECH.PARA: I talk of danger because I can assure the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) that over the last few years there have been an number of major chemical spills in and around Goulburn. Spills have come off the back of trucks as they tear down the main street or drive around the district. If the spills had occurred in different circumstances they could have caused a loss of life or injury in the city of Goulburn itself. It is this very issue which drives not only me as the local Federal member of parliament but also the State member of parliament and the Goulburn City Council to urge the Government to introduce funding for the Goulburn bypass. We recognise that without that funding the city of Goulburn is at risk and the citizens who live within it are at risk. Goulburn is also at risk not only because chemicals are carried down the main street which could tip over and cause loss of life or injury, but also because highly explosive materials are carried down the main street of Goulburn every day. That puts at risk the lives of people in the cities. Therefore, the Opposition is asking that the Government go ahead with the promise made by the former Minister for Transport and Communications, the present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) at the opening of the Collector bypass during the election campaign in July 1987, and that it commence the bypass during its current term in office.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES AND NORTHERN TERRITORY GRANTS (RURAL ADJUSTMENT) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 October, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill 1988 is a most important piece of legislation. Adjustment is a never ending process in the agricultural area. Each year 2 per cent to 3 per cent of our farmers leave the land and the 170,000 farmers remaining drop in number a little each year. That is one of the main reasons why agricultural productivity is two to three times higher than that of our economy generally.

SPEECH.PARA: It is of great advantage to all Australians that this most significant sector of our export industries has higher productivity. It means that agriculture, through this self-adjustment process, is able to maintain exports during difficult international trading circumstances. It means that at times the income of farmers is very low. For example, in 1985 it was one-third that of average weekly earnings. It means that there are times of brutal adjustment. These times come when there is greater than usual corruption in the agricultural export marketing pricing arrangements, such as the export enhancement program of the United States of America or the support arrangements for surplus production of the European Economic Community. We have had some graphic examples of that with the dramatic switch from wheat production to wool production in this country over the last three or four years. That has been to the advantage of our balance of payments and of Australians generally, even if it has been very difficult for many people involved in grain production.

As well as the increased pressure during those periods there has been the problem of an efficient industry becoming non-viable or of individual participants in that industry becoming non-viable because our domestic inflation rate is higher than that of our competitors. Unfortunately for Australia, that is usually the case. Natural disasters can exacerbate the adjustment process that is probably under way to a certain degree because of the market situation. We actually have that in the Eyre Peninsula at present. Adjustment in agriculture in Australia is more brutal than it is in other sectors of our society. Firstly, there is less assistance for agriculture. Most other industries are not export-oriented or weather affected, so they are relieved of that uncertainty. Generally, they have higher protection and they are more likely to have special industry plans. Associated with that, there is now the general acceptance of redundancy payments for those who are forced out of the industry. Finally, they do not have the trauma of having to leave their homes when they leave their jobs. I will come back to that later.

There is a need to accommodate and assist this adjustment process so that it is not as brutal for the individuals caught up in it. Nevertheless, it should be allowed to continue, even with more humane circumstances, because that will ensure that our farmers remain world competitive and our ability to trade is maintained. In the late 1960s and early 1970s the then Minister for Primary Industry, Doug Anthony, introduced, to my knowledge, the first of the rural reconstruction or rural adjustment schemes. In fact, my maiden speech in the Parliament in May 1971 was made on the fruit growing reconstruction scheme, which was one of the associated reconstruction arrangements which followed the entry of the United Kingdom into the Common Market. Certainly the horticultural industry in my area had a very painful adjustment process during the 1970s.

In 1977, the then Minister, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), brought in significant changes to the scheme, including the introduction of the rehabilitation grant, which was then set at $8,000. I also want to talk about that a little later. There have been further changes since. Tonight we are seeing further changes to the rural adjustment scheme, and I believe that that is sensible. Government, responding to changing circumstances and priorities in that adjustment process and to the requests of industry, should be making adjustments as necessary from time to time. Generally speaking, the Opposition supports this legislation.

This particular round of changes follows the Australian Agriculture Council meeting in February 1987. The consultants Coopers and Lybrand and W. D. Scott looked at the whole question of adjustment, it went back to the Agriculture Council, and tonight we have this legislation. In brief, the new arrangements mean that the Commonwealth will set broad guidelines, but within those broad guidelines the States will have greater management, financial responsibility and flexibility, subject to some overall accounting. I support that. I hope that it will overcome one of the problems for those people caught up in the adjustment process over the years-that is, the buck passing that seems to go on between the States and the Commonwealth as to who should actually make the decision. I understand that it may create problems for some of the States because, as part of the new arrangement, they have to assume responsibility for the consideration of bad debts as well as anything that accrues to them from these arrangements. I do not disagree with that. I gather that this is a retrospective area, which means that the States could still be responsible for debts resulting from arrangements made prior to these new arrangements.

There is also provision for financial management advice. That also seems sensible, although it will be interesting to see how practical that will be in implementation. I can think of two situations: in one State, or perhaps more than one State, where the State department of agriculture is not the rural adjustment authority and some interesting crossing of boundaries occurs between two different State instrumentalities. The second is where debt mediation arrangements have been instituted over the last few years following the corruption of the world wheat market and, to a lesser degree, the world sugar market and arrangements were made between banks and those seeking accommodation in the use of consultants. This would seem to me to be an area where consultants could be used.

To my memory, household support was introduced in the 1977 amendments of the right honourable member for New England. I believe that this was a very sensible and important addition to the rural adjustment arrangements. Household support is there in place of unemployment benefit while a farmer considers whether he has a future in agriculture. Household support is more important than ever now that the assets test has been introduced by this Government. Basically, it means that it is impossible for even a bankrupt farmer to pass the assets test for unemployment benefit support-that is, the provision of those essential groceries, et cetera, when no other income is coming into the home. At that time a farmer could obtain household support for the first 12 months without having to make a decision to actually leave the farm and that support terminated after three years. That has been reduced to six months and it must all happen within two years. I understand that the reason for that is to put more pressure on the farmer to make a decision. I believe that six months is too short as we sometimes have to consider seasonal situations as distinct from longer term viability situations.

Until very recently the figure of $8,000 introduced by the right honourable member for New England more than 10 years ago remained and obviously that was not adequate. It is important that a farmer, who has no future in agriculture and has no cash left after his debts are taken into account, should be able to put a deposit on a house so that he can make a more genuine and realistic choice about getting out of agriculture. Unlike a person in any other occupation, when a farmer leaves his farm he leaves his home as well. Even coal miners in coalmining towns are better off. If they have to leave their industry the value of their houses may decline dramatically but they still have houses even though they may not still have jobs. Therefore, the increase to $28,000, which is on a reducible basis if the recipient gets household support after the first six months, and the fact that this sum is indexed is far more realistic and gives a more genuine choice to the person who faces the dreadful decision as to whether his only skill and his only home should be left behind him.

As I mentioned earlier, natural disasters and the arrangements covering them are related to rural adjustment. This is particularly so with drought, which can continue year after year and which, by itself, can trigger the adjustment pressure to force someone out of agriculture. Therefore, we should look at rural adjustment and natural disaster arrangements as complementary in the area of agriculture. One of the problems with natural disaster arrangements is that they are based on financial years and droughts do not follow financial years. Therefore, each year the State has to pay its up-front money before the Commonwealth comes in as well.

I am thinking particularly of the present situation in the Eyre Peninsula in South Australia where there has been yet another crop failure as a result of drought in a significant part of that peninsula. I spent a couple of days in that area earlier this year and I shall return before the end of the year. At present there are at least 300 farmers who have been told by their banks that that is the end of any sort of continuing assistance. The South Australian Government is not accepting its dual responsibility or complementary responsibility in this situation-that is, it is not accepting that it has a responsibility for natural disaster relief as well as rural adjustment relief. Those people, who are basically drought affected, or more specifically drought affected than under the ordinary requirements of rural adjustment, will not be able to get any help from drought relief measures.

I was interested in the very careful answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in this House last Thursday on the situation in the Eyre Peninsula because he mentioned both disaster relief and rural adjustment relief. He did not allocate any blame and I can understand his not doing that because the South Australia Government is a Labor Government, but he mentioned the point about natural disaster relief arrangements and the fact that South Australia must meet the first $8m itself. However, the South Australian Government refuses to make any drought declarations and without these there can be no natural disaster relief.

For example, at present water is desperately needed west of Ceduna to keep stock alive, but the $50,000 requested by the landholders in the area is not being provided by the South Australia Government. That should be a part of ordinary natural disaster relief. There is no freight assistance either for fodder to come in for livestock or to freight stock out. In fact, the policies of the South Australia Government which are to force early and, in some cases, cruel decisions on those landholders and to force them out, will have the opposite effect. By not providing transport assistance or fodder assistance, the South Australia Government will encourage soil erosion when its overall policy is to restructure that area so that its fragility is safeguard. Last week there was a storm in the area which covered 60 kilometres of local government road with sand, but there is no assistance forthcoming to help that local government body to clear the road. Thus, the farmers in the Eyre Peninsula have been deserted by the South Australia Labor Government. They certainly need rural adjustment assistance and that is coming in an approved form through this legislation. But the South Australia Government is using a brutal method of forcing reconstruction and I believe that this will create a backlash which will rebound on that Government and have the opposite effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill 1988 will put into effect many of the changes to the rural adjustment scheme (RAS) announced by the Government in the May economic statement. These initiatives are designed to increase the flexibility of the scheme; they will also allow RAS to operate in a more innovative way.

SPEECH.PARA: Changes to the scheme were recommended to the Government following a review conducted by Coopers and Lybrand during late 1987-early 1988. Coopers and Lybrand found that the scope of the scheme needed to be broadened and the direction improved. It was recommended that more flexibility be given to State administering authorities. This would allow them to improve their ability to provide assistance to farmers experiencing financial difficulties. Recommendations included the innovative step of providing grants to help farmers increase their skills and to obtain professional financial and management advice. The introduction of a one-off re-establishment grant was also recommended. The new grant will provide up to $28,000 for non-viable farmers who are leaving the industry.

The need for an effective rural adjustment scheme is vital to a State such as Queensland. Its importance becomes more evident following the series of natural disasters which have befallen Queensland recently. Droughts still plague many areas of the State while other areas such as the Lockyer and Fassifern valleys are suffering flood damage. A shire within my electorate has recently applied to the State Government to be declared a disaster area following heavy rains. Boonah Shire recorded a rainfall of 77.4 millimetres in the 24 hours to 9 a.m. on 6 July. This huge amount of rain has resulted in severe damage of public assets and major crop losses. In addition to natural disasters, commodity prices for crops remain seasonal and crops are continuing to fail. The importance of the rural adjustment scheme to Queensland farmers cannot be understated. The Federal Government should be commended on its efforts to restructure the scheme.

RAS is directed at promoting positive structural changes in the rural sector. Three categories of assistance are available under the scheme. Under part A, Federal Government funds are available as a concessional interest loan or a subsidy on interest currently being paid on borrowings. These funds are specifically targeted at capital reconstruction or improving productivity. It is provided to farmers who are assessed as having good, long-term prospects. Federal Government money will now, under the new legislation, be available in a grant to allow farmers to obtain appropriate training or professional advice.

Part B of the scheme provides carry-on finance to farmers who are in particular industries which have suffered a temporary downturn for reasons other than drought or natural disasters. Dollar for dollar assistance is subject to agreement between the Commonwealth and the States. Part C of the rural adjustment scheme provides funds as household support payments or as rehabilitation assistance. The household payments are provided for up to to two years. They can be paid as an advance which is converted to a grant when the farmer leaves the industry. However, farmers can be required to repay the advance with interest if they do not leave. Rehabilitation assistance of up to $28,000 will now be available under the new arrangements. This payment is indexed and subject to an asset test. It is payable when a farmer leaves the land. It will allow farmers to leave their farms with dignity.

Farmers are eligible for assistance under Part A of the scheme if they are considered to be viable. They must also have been unable to obtain finance from normal sources at reasonable market interest rates. Part B assistance is also available to farmers who have been unable to obtain finance through normal sources. Other criteria include being located in an industry which is suffering from a downturn but having sound prospects for long term viability. Part C assistance is only available to farmers who are ineligible under either Part A or Part B of the rural adjustment scheme. They must also have taken steps to leave their farms or be suffering from personal financial hardship.

Expenditure on the rural adjustment scheme is expected to total $44.4m in 1987-88. Under the new arrangements introduced by this Bill, expenditure will increase in the 1988-89 financial year to a total $56.4m. The increase in expenditure is in recognition of the importance of restructuring to the long term competitiveness of Australia's primary industries. Other measures to upgrade RAS were announced in the May statement and now will be incorporated into the scheme. Greater emphasis will be placed on targeting of Part A assistance. This will enable struggling farmers to remain in the industry by restructuring their capital, adopting new and improved farming practices or increasing farm size.

An amount of $1.2m will be provided by the Hawke Government under Part A of the scheme to assist farmers to gain increased skills and expert financial and management advice. This measure will greatly increase the skills of Australia's farmers and further boost their international competitiveness. It remains true in the rural sector, as it does in all sectors of the economy, that the ability of an industry to compete depends on the skills of its work force. Australian farmers are already considered to be among the world's best but constant improvement is needed to maintain this position. A one-off allocation of $600,000 will be made in 1988-89 to help improve the capability of farm financial and management advisers.

Another initiative includes changing the basis on which the Commonwealth contributes towards the cost of administration of the rural adjustment scheme. The States will also assume liability for bad debts arising from the operation of the scheme, both in relation to loans made under the existing agreement since 1985 and under the new agreement. However, the changes made in the State and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill 1988 will not have a significant financial impact on the cost of the rural adjustment scheme.

Another important recommendation arising from the consultant's report and adopted by the Government involved increasing the autonomy and accountability of State authorities that administer the rural adjustment scheme. The farmers of my electorate and the people of Queensland might well applaud the Federal Government's efforts to increase accountability in the distribution of funds under the rural adjustment scheme. However, I feel the changes made in this area may not be sufficient to stop the misspending of Federal money by the Queensland National Party Government. This Bill will provide the Queensland Industry Development Corporation (QICD) with, firstly, sole responsibility for the management and administration or policy measures available under the scheme and, secondly, total freedom, supposedly within the bounds of responsible financial administration, to manage funds provided for the purpose of the scheme. In return, the Federal Government has stated that State authorities such as the QIDC will be required to incorporate adequate audit and fraud control measures into their managerial arrangements.

This will not be adequate to prevent the Queensland Government from continuing with its methods of distributing funds. It seems that the accountability provisions depend a lot on the co-operation of the State governments and their adjustment authorities. One thing is for sure: the Queensland Government has never willingly cooperated with the Hawke Government over anything-even when Federal money has been involved. There have been many examples of the maladministration of previous schemes by the Queensland National Party Government, including examples such as the Behan lousy loan affair.

I have raised these matters with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). The Minister has assured me that although no guarantees exist to ensure that there are no abuses by State governments, any State found to have done so will lose Federal funding. I welcome this assurance, as would the people of Queensland, who are sick of hearing about the continuing financial exploits of the Queensland National Party Government.

The Government has previously considered transferring administration of the rural adjustment scheme to the Commonwealth Development Bank. This was designed to prevent further abuses. However, it was considered that such a move at this stage would make the scheme more remote from the knowledge and experience of State administrations. The Federal Government has taken some steps to ensure that State governments remain accountable. Several aspects of the new arrangements under this legislation will assist in preventing problems.

Australian farmers should remember that the main purpose of the rural adjustment scheme is to assist in maintaining and improving the efficiency of Australian rural industries. This is to ensure that those industries are able to compete effectively on international markets and contribute to the national economy. The rural adjustment scheme provides assistance to ensure that viable Australian farmers who may be undergoing some temporary difficulties are kept in their industries. The scheme aims to help farmers adjust to changing technical, economic and institutional circumstances. The rural adjustment scheme is not designed to be a crutch for those farmers who are no longer viable. It should not be used as a means for farmers to remain within an industry in which they can no longer contribute effectively.

The rural sector occupies a privileged place in Government policy. Not many other sectors can claim to have such an effective adjustment scheme as that supplied to primary industry. In other cases, if non-rural industry is unable to compete it goes out of business. I support the Bill and commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too support the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill. I endorse the remarks that my colleague the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has made in speaking to the Bill, as I endorse what other speakers have had to say. As has been pointed out, this Bill has two purposes. It will allow the rural adjustment scheme to operate in a more flexible way to react to structural adjustment forces and it will also meet new arrangements for the Commonwealth-State programs. In particular, the Commonwealth's role will be restricted to setting broad policy guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that over the years the rural adjustment scheme has developed into a very worthwhile adjunct to assist farmers in a way that is sensible and worth while. It has worked in a number of ways. It has assisted out of the industry some of those who could no longer remain in it, it has helped some to regain viability and it has also helped some to get more involved in the industry. In each case I would say that without the rural adjustment scheme there is no doubt that those particular individuals would have found it much more difficult and in many cases would have faced considerable hardship.

I want to address a couple of changes in the Bill to the rural adjustment scheme, and in particular I want to address one anomaly that the Bill should have addressed and which was alluded to in 1985. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) recognised it in 1985 but for some reason this Bill still has not managed to address it. The aim of the rural adjustment scheme has been very well summed up by the National Farmers Federation. When addressing the issue in its Farm Focus policy document for the 1980s, it said, in part:
In a broad sense, the aim of rural adjustment programs should be to `oil the wheels of change'; to assist, rather than impede market forces.

The objective should be to promote the long term viability of those remaining in farming. This will often be best achieved by removing impediments either to farm build-up, access to suitable credit, changes to product mix or inputs or obstacles to leaving farming.

Those are very worthwhile aims. They sum up extremely well what the rural adjustment scheme is all about. All members on both sides of the House would have no difficulty in supporting those aims. What must be realised when someone is faced with these difficulties in farming is that they are enormous personal difficulties. The cost and dislocation involved for those leaving farming can be enormous. As the honourable member for Murray has already pointed out, when someone leaves a farm, he does not just leave his business; in most cases he must also leave his home. That creates considerable distress and considerable hardship. Obviously, adjustment policies should aim to minimise these difficulties for the people concerned. There should be greater guidance, and more emphasis than in the past should be placed on rehabilitation and also on retaining people, where possible, in the right place. For that reason, I commend the Government for its efforts to address this problem. I believe it has made some very sensible improvements to the program.

I also suggest, in following up a point made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), that the various rural adjustment schemes have set an example which has yet to be followed by the manufacturing sector but which ought to be looked at. Obviously, adjustment programs must be carefully monitored to ensure that the intended objective of helping those in need is reached in a way that is fair and reasonable. Clearly, the farm build-up section of the legislation and the farm improvement assistance provided by the rural adjustment scheme should be seen as examples of measures which have already proved successful in facilitating change.

As has already been pointed out, there has been considerable consultation in reaching this amendment. The consultants obviously did a very good job and consulted widely. They certainly consulted in every State and in the Territory. One could say that the objectives of the scheme are now more clearly defined in the new legislation. It is clear that the responsibilities of each party are also more clearly defined. What is also commendable is the fact that a State which runs its rural adjustment scheme better-obviously, the States run the rural adjustment scheme in conjunction with the Commonwealth-can expect to benefit from that activity. Conversely, a State which makes unwise decisions will eventually have the consequences fall back on it and have less money to deliver to the recipients intended to benefit from the rural adjustment program. This is a very good principle and is one which could be adopted in many other areas in Commonwealth-State financing. I hope that we continue to assess many other programs under similar criteria. Obviously, it is to the benefit of those who have to provide the funds-in the long run, the taxpayers.

I alluded earlier to the fact that in 1985 there was in the legislation an anomaly which was recognised by the Minister at the time and which he suggested he would be able to address. However, unfortunately, for some reason he has not addressed it in this legislation. It has not been addressed in the ensuing period in any other amendments to previous legislation. The problem is that under the 1985 legislation and the agreement with the States the position with respect to continuing payments was legally in doubt, although the Minister had given an unqualified undertaking that the position was otherwise. It was also agreed that the 1985 legislation should be amended, but this still has not been done. Furthermore, this Bill has not addressed that problem. I hope that the Minister, in summing up the second reading debate, might refer to that point. Otherwise, there is some doubt on legal liability arising from the 1985 legislation and, in particular, from some of the obligations that were entered into by the States following 1985.

I would also like to draw the attention of honourable members to clause 14 and, in particular, to subclauses (1) and (2). I point out to honourable members that clause 14 contains an extremely complex set of points. They are so complex that it is rather difficult for those who will have to administer the Act to interpret them. There is concern that because of this complexity there could be some misunderstandings. I hope that the Minister will address this point. Those who have to administer the rural adjustment schemes would feel much more comfortable if any misunderstandings or any vagueness in the drafting could be cleared up before the Bill receives assent.

I also endorse some of the words contained in part C relating to household payments. The amount has been increased; people can receive household assistance for up to two years; and those who choose to receive household assistance-subject, of course, to a means test-and who, within the first six months, realise that the prudent decision is to leave the farm can receive assistance of up to $28,000. This assistance is means tested. This means that a person could leave his farm with a grant of $28,000, plus up to $28,000 of his own assets. That is not a lot of money for someone who is in dire straits. At least it shows a reasonably humane approach to someone who, as I said earlier, is not just leaving his farm or his business but, in most cases, is also leaving his home. It is more than just a financial wrench for someone who has lived in that home for many years; it is an emotional wrench. It can be devastating for the person involved and his family. This is a most sensible increase in the amount of assistance available to those people.

In conclusion, I commend the legislation. I believe it is a sensible improvement to the existing rural adjustment scheme. The point that I raised earlier, that those States who use the scheme wisely will benefit and those who do not use it wisely will be at a disadvantage, is a great incentive for better administration. I hope that such a principle can be applied to many other programs. I think we should continue to monitor the scheme. If there are ways and means of improving it, we should certainly bring those forward and bring them to the attention of the Government so that they can be implemented. Overall, I think it is a good scheme. It is being improved. It serves a very worthwhile function in the farming community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) for his support of the legislation. I guess it shows implicit recognition of the magnificent job that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) is doing. I also compliment the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) for his contribution. He highlighted the necessity for the States to be accountable in the way in which they address matters of agricultural policy. The States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill 1988 is yet another example of the Government's commitment to both the rural sector and the structural adjustment of Australian industry. Earlier today I had the privilege of being able to speak in a debate on the centennial roads program. In that speech I pointed out the need for structural adjustment. Again, I emphasise the fact that this Government is committed to structural adjustment of Australian industry. This Bill is yet another aspect of that commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: The States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill introduces flexibility and innovation in the manner in which the Commonwealth works with the States in addressing the changing economic forces which are affecting the Australian agricultural sector. Variability in world commodity prices, exchange rates, interest rates and changing climatic conditions have created circumstances in which rigid policy responses and smothering administrative regulations can no longer cope with the variables in the agricultural sector. This Bill will enable the Commonwealth to maintain its responsibility for defining broad policy parameters for the rural adjustment scheme while devolving responsibility to the States for its management and the administration of the policy measures available under the scheme.

The Bill seeks to aid the more effective operation and management of the scheme. It allows ends and means to be more directly related and allows for more efficient usage of funds. This more efficient use of funds, of course, is related to accountability. While the States will manage the scheme they will be accountable for the way in which it is run. Indeed, it places a responsibility upon the States and the Territory in the area of policy development. It is important that they encourage under this legislation industries that are sustainable. I will make a comment in a short time about the way in which the Northern Territory Government has addressed that problem. It will also aid the States in their accounting to the Commonwealth for the effective operation of the scheme, as I have said.

The Northern Territory has an agricultural base with a gross value in 1986-87 of $12.3m. There are 270 agricultural establishments within the Northern Territory, the majority of which are pastoral holdings. The rural adjustment scheme allows, significantly, interest subsidies for up to seven years. Debt reconstruction is the most common assistance; that is, consolidating debts into only one loan and getting an interest subsidy.

One of the more useful aspects of the amendments is that where a farmer is in strife because of poor financial management the rural adjustment scheme can provide for the costs of a consultant to put in an accounting system. That is very important because it recognises that in terms of contemporary management there may be some people involved in primary industries who do not have the capacity to be able to direct their resources in the most appropriate manner. This provides them with the ability to be able to seek that assistance.

In the last two to three years only two applicants under the scheme have actually left the land in the Northern Territory. In June 1988 this scheme was providing assistance to 39 different operators in the form of interest subsidies on debts totalling $8.7m. Of those 39, 16, or 41 per cent, came on stream in 1987-88. Of those 16, 10 were in the beef industry, one was a poultry producer, one a pig meat producer, one was involved in coarse grains and three in horticulture.

In terms of Northern Territory agriculture, as I have said previously, the gross value of crops in 1986-87 was $12.3m. The Local Value of all crops in 1986-87 was $9.8m. The local value, as I am sure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, are aware, is the gross value less the marketing costs. It is the value placed on the commodities at the place of production. In the Northern Territory crop production in 1986-87 comprised the following commodities: sorghum, 66 per cent; peanuts, 9 per cent; maize, 15 per cent; and other categories, 10 per cent. The number of establishments in the Northern Territory with Agricultural activity in 1986 was 239 while in 1987 there was a significant increase to 290. In 1987, 179 of these establishments were over 50,000 hectares. Fifty-four were less than 100 hectares. That does not include any with an estimated value of agricultural operations of less than $20,000.

This Bill is important. But in saying that, I would like to emphasise the need for accountability and appropriate administration of the primary industries within the various States and the Northern Territory. The majority of agricultural establishments in the Territory are pastoral holdings. As I have said, over 60 per cent of those establishments are greater than 50,000 hectares. There are two areas where we have agriculture. They are in the Douglas-Daly area to the south-west of Darwin and in Katherine. There is a history of failed agriculture in the Northern Territory. There were sugar cane plantations at Delissaville across the harbour from Darwin and in the Daly River from 1881 to 1884. There was mixed cropping along the Daly for a few years after 1911. Cotton and peanuts were grown in Katherine between 1923-1939. Rice was grown at Humpty Doo and Marrakai between 1954 and 1966 and grain sorghum was grown at Tipperary between 1967 and 1973.

Perhaps the most alarming illustration of the failure of agriculture in the Northern Territory arises out of an article in the Northern Territory News of 25 September 1988. The headline was `Farmers face disaster'. This article is about experimental farms established by the Agricultural Development and Marketing Authority in the Adelaide River and Douglas-Daly areas that I have mentioned previously. The hope in 1980 when this plan was introduced was that we would see 120 grain, oilseed and peanut farms established in the Douglas-Daly area over a period of 10 years and about 45 rice farms established in the Adelaide River region.

The Government initially pledged to pump about $52.5m into the Douglas-Daly area and $9.4m into the Adelaide River area. What we have seen, however, is a monumental disaster. I would like to quote from part of that article because it illustrates aptly the concerns of people in the Northern Territory who are involved in primary industry about the way in which the Northern Territory Government is managing its resources:
A multi-million dollar attempt by the Territory Government to kickstart new farming ventures south of Darwin is on its knees.
A group of experimental farms established by the NT Agricultural Development and Marketing Authority (ADMA) in the Adelaide River and Douglas-Daly areas is reeling after a run of poor seasons.
The Primary Industry and Fisheries Department's assistant director . . . said poor rainfalls has caused crop failure on project farms established by the ADMA in the early 1980s.
But . . . denied claims by the former owner of Oolloo Station, Mrs Pam Rixon, that ADMA's attempt to create a broadacre cropping industry in the Territory was a failure.

The fact is that it has been a failure. The Rixon family is one farming family who have been most dramatically affected by the way in which the Northern Territory Government embarked on this exercise. Before we see this sort of establishment in future, it is important that there be appropriate research into the ability of the areas concerned to sustain the sorts of industries that the Northern Territory in this case wanted to establish.

I might add that there is a great deal of feeling within the primary sector in the Northern Territory about the way in which the Northern Territory Government is administering the Department of Primary Production in that area. Indeed, at the moment there is a very low level of morale with the Northern Territory Department of Primary Production. There is a lack of confidence amongst its staff and people involved in the industry. In fact, I had a conversation with some pastoralists recently about their confidence in the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign. They said they had no confidence in the ability of the Northern Territory Department of Primary Production veterinary scientists to do their jobs appropriately. That is simply because with the effluxion of time there has been a disastrous movement of veterinary scientists out of the Northern Territory Department of Primary Production. That has been because of the way in which the Northern Territory Government has administered that Department and indeed has administered its responsibilities in the area of primary industry.

I would like to have been able to say that the Department had done a better job. It is very important that it get its act together because it is the farmers such as the Rixons who are prepared to put their heart and soul into industries such as that in the Douglas-Daly area-on the promises made by the Northern Territory Government, I might add-who are important to our future economy.
