I might say, while the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) is at the table, that if the Opposition had the same set of subjective analyses for the Northern Territory Government's management of the Northern Territory economy since self-government in 1978 as it has had for the performance of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio it would be calling for a royal commission into the administration of the Northern Territory Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate on the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill currently before the House. I would like, however, to take up a point or two made by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) when he indicated that he welcomed the remarks from the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) because, he said, the honourable member for Wannon's remarks were implicit recognition of the fine job the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) had done in shaping this legislation. I stand here as one who agrees that this is legislation that the Opposition is happy to welcome. But to paint this legislation as the panacea for all of rural Australia's ills or, even more, to suggest that the honourable member for Wannon, who is chairman of the Opposition's rural committee, is ecstatic about this legislation is, in fact, to mislead the House.
—It appeared as though he was.

—I dispute that with the honourable member for the Northern Territory. While I am on my feet and the honourable member for the Northern Territory is inviting me to make a comment or two, may I add, as one who is not as familiar with the Douglas-Daly area of the Northern Territory as the honourable member but one who nevertheless knows a number of farmers who are practising there, that he has rather conveniently used one farming family whose circumstances may well reinforce his case and ignored the fact, of which I am well aware, that there are a number of other families farming in the area assisted initially by the Northern Territory Government who are establishing what will be model farms for the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: Originally they were designed to be the sorts of farms on which future Northern Territory settlement could be modelled. As I have acknowledged, there may be a family or two in difficulty, but it would be unfair to paint the entire region as a disaster area as a result of that experience.

I have a particular concern about the legislation before the House. My electorate is the most northerly South Australian Federal electorate before one reaches the seat of Grey. There may be a good reason for this, and I have no reason to be critical of the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil), but I am little surprised that he has not chosen to participate in this debate. His electorate is the electorate most adversely affected by the present drought on the west coast of South Australia. His electorate is the electorate that stands both to win and lose most as a result of this legislation.

I recognise that, in the words of the honourable member for the Northern Territory, this legislation introduces both flexibility and innovation into the rural assistance scheme. However, the enthusiasm with which the honourable member has embraced the legislation before the House is less than timely, given that a number of other disasters that are not in any way addressed by this Bill face rural Australia. Flexibility and innovation may be all very well; I welcome them. In addition, I welcome the move from a $20,000 to a $28,000 relocation allowance that is in this legislation to assist farmers who are forced to move from their properties. But a number of other aspects of the Bill ought to be considered before it is presumed to have the overwhelming endorsement of the Opposition.
I take up one of the points in the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). In his second reading speech, he said:
. . . there is to be a much stronger emphasis on the notion that farming is first and foremost a business . . .
We would all applaud that sentiment. The Minister goes on to say:

Two provisions are made in the Bill specifically to facilitate meeting this objective. Training for farmers is recognised as an appropriate activity to be funded under the scheme. In addition, provision is made for ongoing funding to improve the quality of financial analysis which is undertaken before assistance is provided to the farmer. In this context the Bill aims to ensure that the real causes of a farmer's business problems are identified before assistance is provided.

No one would take issue with those sentiments. But the problem facing many farmers around Australia and the acute problem currently being faced for the third year in a row by drought-stricken farmers on the west coast of South Australia are that their difficulties could not have been identified before assistance was provided.

Their problems are not self-inflicted. Their problems are not corrected, as the honourable member for the Northern Territory would have had us believe, by some sort of innovative bookkeeping technique. Their problems are the problems of drought. In addressing the problems of drought on the west coast of South Australia, not only does this legislation fail to come to terms with what those farmers are facing but also the South Australian State Government has failed to recognise the important role that west coast farmers play in keeping the economy of the west coast afloat. Farmers on the west coast must be kept on the land so that they can make provision for future harvests when better seasons return to that part of the State.

It is fair to say that the legislation before the House will allow some of the farmers on the west coast of South Australia to be relocated. As the honourable member for Wannon has said, it will allow them to take with them a total of $56,000 as part of that relocation process. The legislation will allow some farmers on the west coast and in other areas of South Australia to choose to undertake an appropriate training program that will help them to trade their way out of their present difficulties, treating farming as a business.

What the legislation fails to do is to allow those west coast farmers to stay on their land, which they need to do if they are to be there to farm that land when better seasons return. My colleague Mr Graham Gunn, the State member for Eyre, has discovered that the State Government has denied to his west coast drought-stricken farmers any sort of government assistance in the transport of water. That came at the end of a week in South Australia that saw 38 degree days and hot north winds and a week that saw a loss of at least 50,000 tonnes of the State's barley crop. Imagine how the drought-stricken west coast looks after that sort of hammering. I acknowledge that the Minister has visited that area-or, more accurately, the fringe of that area-as recently as a week ago. But, in spite of that visit, the need those farmers have for some assistance to allow them to remain on their properties until inevitably better seasons arrive is not answered in this legislation. The real need of the west coast of South Australia, as some South Australian radio commentators would have us believe, is not to leave the farmers there and to return the land to its native state. Nor is it the need to take the farmers out of the area with $56,000 in their pockets and invite the land sharks to come in and buy the land at bargain basement prices. Rather is the need to allow those farmers to stay there, farming the farms they know well, so that, when inevitably better seasons arrive and the west coast returns, as it will, to being the grain bowl of South Australia, they are there to capitalise on it and to fuel part of the balance of payments recovery that this nation so desperately needs.
I refer to an article which appeared in the National Farmer on Friday, 4 November, written by Bruce Cullen. The article was headed `Farm export boom set to save the economy-again'. It stated:

An exclusive evaluation by National Farmer commodity analysts has revealed `hidden factors' which will boost rural exports by about $500,000 a month over expectations, in the second and third quarters.
I point out that this article was written before hot north winds lashed South Australia-key rural exporter that it is. Nonetheless, these are valid points. Mr Cullen goes on to say:

This would bring an additional $3 billion pouring into the nation's economy-enough to almost wipe out the first quarter deficit of $3.8 billion, and put Keating's forecast of a $9.5 billion end-of-year deficit back on track . . .

For the first quarter, Australia's rural exports averaged $1.1 billion a month. In the second and third quarters, the working of these hidden factors is likely to boost rural exports to $1.6 billion a month or more-an economic `windfall' worth about $500,000 a month.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) ought to be very pleased that rural Australia is responding as it is to the present favourable conditions in much of rural Australia and saving his economic bacon. The west coast of South Australia has a similar capacity to be productive. We need to ensure that the farmers remain there to keep it productive. In this legislation before the House, the Minister had a classic opportunity to offer to the State Government additional assistance to address the west coast dilemma. Whilst much of what this legislation does is commendable, the specific sorts of assistance that would allow farmers to remain on their farms are not to be found. I welcome the legislation but I regret that the west coast must continue to search for the assistance it so desperately needs if it is to make the contribution it can make to our balance of payments recovery.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 9, Schedule, subclauses 14 (1) and (2), omit the subclauses, insert the following subclauses:

``(1) Subject to this agreement, the amounts of financial assistance to be made available by the Commonwealth to each State for Part C assistance and, except as to amounts provided for by paragraph 2 (a), Part A assistance during a financial year shall be separately determined for each of those Parts by the Commonwealth after consultation with the States. Before the commencement of the financial year the Minister and State Ministers will consult taking into account such matters as are set out in clauses 4 and 5.
(2) The amount payable by the Commonwealth in relation to Part A assistance in respect of any financial year shall not be less than-
(a) in respect of each of the first seven financial years of this agreement as is a financial year within the first six financial years:
(i) after the first financial year of the amended Agreement, the amount of any Determination or Determinations of Part A assistance made in that first financial year under the amended Agreement;

(ii) after the second financial year of the amended Agreement, the incremental part of any Determination or Determinations of Part A assistance made in that second financial year under the amended Agreement; and

(iii) after the third or any subsequent financial year of the amended Agreement, the incremental part of any Determination or Determinations of Part A assistance made in that third or subsequent financial year as the case may be under the amended Agreement;

(b) in respect of each of the first seven financial years of this agreement the amount of Part A assistance determined under this agreement by the Minister as payable in respect of an immediately preceding financial year of this agreement; and
(c) in respect of each succeeding period of seven financial years of this agreement:

(i) as to the first year, the sum of the increments of amounts of Part A assistance determined under this agreement in respect of the second to the seventh inclusive of the immediately preceding seven financial years; and
(ii) as to the remaining six years, the sum of the increments of those amounts so determined in respect of the immediately preceding six financial years of this agreement.''

The amendment makes more clear the extent of the Commonwealth funding obligations under the legislation. The purpose of clause 14 is to establish the amount of financial assistance to be provided by the Commonwealth to the States and the Northern Territory under the scheme in any financial year. A fundamental aspect of the financial arrangements is that annual funding determinations for new part A assistance carry a commitment for the Commonwealth to provide an equivalent amount of funds in each of the next six financial years. The proposed amendment of subclauses 14 (1) and 14 (2) is required to remove ambiguities in the present wording which allow for differing interpretations of the extent of the Commonwealth's obligations flowing from the determinations made under the existing agreement in the period 1985-86 to 1987-88. The amendment clarifies that these obligations will continue under the new agreement, when executed, and will be subject to the same six-year forward commitment. The amendment was developed in close consultation with the States.

The amendment basically clarifies the anomaly referred to by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). It clears up all doubts about the whole question. I compliment all people who have participated in this debate for their constructive comments, particularly the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). I will not pick up all of his points. He pointed out at one stage that workers who get into a very bad situation when a company collapses or a company takes various decisions, have redundancy payments. I point out that farmers are businessmen and are subject to chance and choice. They enter with their eyes open. The problem for farmers as opposed to other small businessmen in our community is that they are also exposed to the vagaries of international trade, corrupted markets, and the weather.

With the so-called rural crisis and the setting up of the National Farmers Federation (NFF) debt mediation and rural counselling grants, we got a very real hold on some of the problems that farmers face and on some of the ways in which we could help them. That is why in this rural adjustment scheme we have moved into financial counselling. We are moving away from debt reconstruction just as a straight interest subsidy to capital reconstruction of the farm. We are trying to put into the hands of the State adjustment authorities a lot more flexibility.

The Eyre Peninsula has had a run tonight, and the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) will get plenty of cheers for the comments he made. He said something about the land sharks. Part of the reason the South Australian Government is taking the action it is to try to facilitate the amalgamation of farms is to avoid this problem. Queensland has about 1,000 to 1,500 farms in trouble at present. Various assessments say that the Eyre Peninsula has 200 to 400 farms in trouble. We have recently responded to the Queensland Government request for more flexibility under the natural disaster relief arrangement. I would like to put that in with what we know about farms.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics will come out soon with some very good figures on the prospects in the years ahead. The reality is that the grain farms, the cereal farms, that got into a lot of trouble are still in a lot of trouble. If we look at the budgets of those that are in trouble we will see that even if they got $200 a tonne for wheat they would still be in trouble. This is the real problem for farms on the Eyre Peninsula and for those farms in Queensland. Once farmers get to the point of such loss of equity, the schemes available-natural disaster relief arrangements if the problem is drought, or the rural adjustment scheme-simply cannot cope with the problem. A threshold decision then needs to be taken by governments as to what extent the taxpayers should pay to keep those people on those farms. It is a real problem. I have already said that I want to revisit the whole question of drought assistance, the problems of the declaration of drought and the revocation of drought declaration. I think that the National Drought Consultative Committee did not address all of these problems, even though farmers themselves are on that Committee. We have a real problem.

We are providing more choice for people who move off farms. I remember well the enormous problems the dairy industry went through in the 1970s. In those times people moved off farms into cities. Because of their skills and because of the expanding economy at that time, the adjustment for those people, so unfortunate to have to move off their farms, was easily facilitated. Again, part of the reason the Government's overall economic strategy takes the form it does is that we cannot get effective restructuring, we cannot get cuts in protection, we cannot get the fundamental restructuring of the Australian economy unless we have a growing domestic economy. So all of these things need to be taken into account.

The honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) put forward a very good point on some of the problems of administration over the years. He pointed to the problems with the corrupt Queensland National Party Government. I think some of the definitions he gave were very helpful as were those made by the honourable member for Wannon who picked up the NFF definition. I was particularly interested to hear the comments made by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). Many of the problems he pointed to reflected the problems of tropical agriculture. Often there, farmers do not have homogeneous soils, there are all sorts of vagaries with the weather, and there is a drought every season just as many of the colder areas have a drought every year.

By and large the comments have been very constructive. As honourable members know, we have changed this scheme once during the life of this Government. Now we are changing it for the second time. We have moved to a situation where the amount of Commonwealth money going in could be expanded by working on the loans principle. I think this year the estimate is about $37m from the Commonwealth which will finance, including the ongoing finance, something between $200m and $300m. We are literally helping thousands of farmers with this scheme.

Finally, the rural adjustment scheme is not a quasi drought scheme. The natural disasters relief arrangements must be looked at in terms of handling disasters and drought. Some of these arrangements are short term and some are long term. A bush fire or a flood is a very specific disaster and it can affect a farm quite dramatically, but a drought is a creeping disaster and that is the problem we have. Rural adjustment is really to assist farms that are assessed as being viable. This Bill is about trying to find better ways of keeping those farms just at the margin of viability, over the edge into the viable category. I thank honourable members.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 19 October, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the House will recall that, last year, legislation was passed in this House relating to both the Family Law Act and the Child Support Act of that year. These were significant pieces of legislation because they were a serious attempt by the Government, with the full support of the Opposition, to put into law arrangements that would go some way-we hope a long way-towards overcoming some of the endemic problems relating to children of broken marriages.

SPEECH.PARA: Some people argue that much of this goes back to the original Murphy reforms of the early 1970s. Nevertheless, the fact of the matter is that the changes introduced into Parliament last year, and which are now law, are of a significant nature. While we have seen only stage 1 of these new proposals and we wait, presumably until next year, before we see stage 2, nevertheless an important step forward has been made in this area, and I compliment the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) for the action he took in this direction.

However, I should also emphasise to him that, contrary to some of the comments I have heard him make in the past-that the previous Government did nothing, to use his words-it is fair to point out that the Joint Committee on the Family Law Act, the Ruddock Committee, in many respects set the ground for the later reforms which have, in fact, been introduced.

The fact of the matter is that, following the introduction of the Murphy reforms, irrespective of who was in government, we had to see, on the ground, precisely what the shortcomings of those reforms would be. In that context, to introduce far-reaching reforms on top of the Murphy changes would have been more than the system would have been able to bear at that stage. There would have been a real risk that major errors would have been made.

We are dealing with people's lives, not just with pieces of paper, and for that reason it is necessary that there be some delay in the system to ensure that we create as little major disruption to families and individuals, and especially to children, as possible.

The Bill will amend the Child Support Act 1988. It is essentially a collection mechanism to ensure that the Act can apply to ex-nuptial children in either the States of Queensland or Western Australia. I understand it is the intention of either State, or hopefully both States, that they adopt the Child Support Act, and therefore join the rest of Australia in a national legislative program in this particular direction.

I should point out, however, that at this stage neither Western Australia nor Queensland has yet adopted the amendments to the Family Law Act which passed through Parliament last year. That is quite significant because it means that the handling of maintenance for ex-nuptial children is different from the handling of maintenance for the children of marriages. The latter are covered by the State legislation which is now accepted under the Commonwealth legislation. However, it does not cover the question of children of ex-nuptial relationships.

The result of that in monetary terms is that the former will still receive the lower level of maintenance, which is currently set at $20 per week per child; but we hope-and I think we have reason to believe-that in due course both those States will adopt the amendments to the Family Law Act. Along with their agreement to the child support amendments, we will once again have a uniform system of family law across Australia.

The main features of the Bill provide for the collection of certain child and/or spousal maintenance payable under court orders and maintenance agreements. To date, the child support registrar, who is also, under the Bill, the Commissioner of Taxation, has only been able to collect maintenance where children are the children of a marriage or, if the child is not the child of a marriage, where a State has referred its power in respect of ex-nuptial children.

With the exception of the two States I mentioned earlier, Western Australia and Queensland, the other four States-New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania-have already agreed to refer their powers. Under the Child Support Act the registrar is also able to collect maintenance for ex-nuptial children in Queensland and Western Australia should either State adopt the Act in so far as it relates to the maintenance of children who are not children of a marriage. There is, however, a technical deficiency in several of the provisions for the Child Support Act that would, if unchanged, have defeated this adoption procedures, and it is precisely for that reason that this legislation has been introduced.

The Child Support Amendment Bill will effectively enable the operation of a Child Support Act in the States of Queensland and Western Australia, when and if those States adopt the Act in relation to ex-nuptial children, by ensuring that those provisions of the Child Support Act also apply where orders or agreements for the maintenance of ex-nuptial children are made under law of a State.

It goes without saying that the Opposition supports the Bill. It is a worthwhile step forward towards the achievement of a uniform system of family law in Australia. However, I should like to take a few moments to comment on a recent Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) report on income support policies and tax incentives, because it has a particular relevance, especially to families and in particular to single families.

One of the biggest problems in Australia is to define precisely what poverty means, and while we have indices based on American models and so forth, no-one has yet really developed a truly representative poverty formula for Australia. Perhaps, for that reason, it is invariably a relative concept; but the evidence suggests that many low income people, especially families with children, have to survive on insufficient nutrition, insufficient housing and various other problems related to a simple lack of money. These people are unable to heat their homes in winter and are unable to afford adequate medication and so forth. In many cases these families are denied adequate forms of recreation for their children or the normal opportunities one would expect of normal family life in Australia.

In fact it is quite clear that, in many instances, there have been long term adverse consequences for the education, health and, ultimately, the availability of employment opportunities for the children of such families. This leads me on to the question of one of the most difficult and deep-seated problems in social welfare policy and that is the question of poverty traps. The seriousness of the poverty trap in many respects depends more on the average drawback rate on the additional dollars which will be earned, if a person takes a particular employment opportunity, than on the marginal drawback rate.

In other words, the problem we are facing is to what extent people make decisions not to seek employment because of the effect that that can have on the availability of social security. In turn we must consider what impact that has, in the macro-sense, on the Budget and to what extent it is possible to alleviate or reduce poverty traps by tapering arrangements or other methodologies, all of which are valid to a degree but all of which, frankly, have built in problems.

Nevertheless, the very presence of poverty traps is clearly a disincentive for low income people to improve their station in life. In a sense, this runs counter to the capacity of any government to overcome those problems, even with all the will in the world. Money alone usually creates rather than reduces some of these problems. To give an example of this, which is included in the EPAC report, if a sole parent in New South Wales public housing increases her hours of work from, say, five hours a week to 20 hours a week, that person would attract an average drawback rate of 67c in the dollar. That is a significant reduction in any circumstances, and one can understand the problem that this creates.

It is estimated that approximately 40,000 people are in this situation. The effect of marginal tax rates can result in their being some 75 per cent above what would, in fact, be the case. Some 15 per cent of sole parents and some 8 per cent of unemployment beneficiaries experience these effective marginal tax rates which operate at a level higher than the top income tax rate. If ever there were an example of a disincentive, that surely is it.

Moving on to two other points, when we debated the Child Support Bill in Parliament in February of this year I drew to the attention of the House and, of course, the Minister two matters about which the Opposition was concerned. On one I actually moved an amendment which, regrettably, was not acceptable to the Minister. The simple fact is this: evidence in place now since the introduction of the legislation shows quite clearly that some 30 per cent of the people concerned have appropriate voluntary agreements with their ex-spouses who make regular payments. They are, in fact, being discouraged and in a sense have a built-in disincentive because of the application of the arrangement as it currently stands. When the Bill was debated in February, I said:

In doing so, however, we are concerned about the impact it can have on that not inconsiderable number-probably 30 per cent of non-custodial parents-who are currently the subject of mutually agreed arrangements between the ex-husband and wife in relation to the protection and financial support of their children.

I went on to move an amendment which, as I said, has proved to be completely accurate. Simply, what I said was that the Opposition wanted to ensure the protection of the rights of non-custodial parents who had entered into maintenance arrangements to share in the cost of supporting their children at no extra cost to the Commonwealth by not requiring these agreements to be registered with the Child Support Agency, except in the event that maintenance arrangements are not honoured.

The Government did not accept that particular amendment, the result of which is that many thousands of people in these circumstances-about 30 per cent of the total-are now experiencing financial delays, that is, delays in actually getting access to maintenance, of two months or longer. In his summing up, I hope the Minister for Social Security will draw the attention of the House to his response to that particular question. I also went on to say that this question needed to be asked:

Should those people who have entered into voluntary agreements and who have voluntary agreements in place, for which they are meeting their commitments, be treated the same as people who may not have met their commitments?

That question was asked then, and I have repeated it tonight. The evidence coming forward to members of this House and, no doubt, to the Minister suggests that there is the real prospect of a major and unfair disadvantage being built into the system. Perhaps it can be called an unintended consequence of the legislation; nevertheless, that is how it is.
For the benefit of the House, I shall read into Hansard a letter which I have received from a constituent in relation to the maintenance income test and the effect it has on supporting parents:
I would like to make you aware of the devastating effect of the introduction in June 1988 of a maintenance income test for sole supporting parents.

The legislation allows sole supporting parents to receive $15 per week for the first child plus $5 for each extra child. When this amount is exceeded, 50% of the excess is deducted from pension entitlement.

The Minister claimed, in the second reading of the bill, that total income of sole supporting parents would be protected by a ``saving provision'' in the act. This was also claimed in supplementary notes to the act, brochures dated May 1988 and letters to supporting parents dated 25 August 1988. The basis of these claims is subsection 21 (4) which protects total income as at the last day of the final pre-amendment period (9.6.88), subject to subsection 21 (5). However, this subsection overrides 21 (4) and protects pension entitlement only as at that date.

Since total income and pension entitlements are inversely related, the saving provision operates only when total income is increasing. The effect of ss21 (5) is, therefore, the opposite of that both explicitly and implicitly stated.
That is an unintended consequence, I would presume. The letter continues:

To reiterate-if total income stays the same or increases after 9/6/88, the saving provision operates, but if total income decreases (and pension entitlement increases), the saving provision does not operate.
The only criterion used to determine whether the saving provision applies is pension entitlement at 9/6/88. Therefore it only applies when total income increases.

The Department of Social Security has admitted that the brochures are ``somewhat misleading'' and yet continue to use them and the so-called saving provision as evidence that sole supporting parents are not being disadvantaged.

Sole supporting parents receiving the full amount of pension at 9/6/88 (not receiving income from other sources), lost cost of living increases payable 23/6/88. They will continue to lose cost of living increases until the calculated ``excess'' maintenance received is eliminated. Claims that these people are `not worse off'-
as made by both the Minister and the Department-
are absurd. Their dollar income may remain the same but their purchasing power and their standard of living has decreased.

My personal situation is this: I finished casual employment on 10/6/88 and my pension entitlement increased to the full amount. Due to the application of ss21(5), I immediately lost $26.20 from my pension entitlement of $352.10 per fortnight. My total income reduced from $270.39 per week to $209.10 due to the loss of casual income and the application of the maintenance income test. For the first time in eight years of receiving a pension I am unable to survive financially.

As well as challenging the effect of the saving provision (which I am attempting to do through the Minister for Social Security's Department), I would like to point out that the maintenance income test is discriminating (it cannot be applied to sole supporting parents not receiving a pension). It is also unfair, unjust and a disgrace to a government which regularly proclaims its concern for disadvantaged groups. The maintenance income test does not affect the non-custodial parent and the government saves money at the expense of the supporting parent and the children. I have at the moment before the court an application for an increase in maintenance of $34 per week. If successful, the net result to me will be $4 per week more than the pre-maintenance income test amount because the Government will reduce my pension by $30 per week.

I think that the point is made rather clearly. In the second reading debate on the initial legislation which was introduced into the Parliament last year, I identified unintended consequences. Those consequences are now occurring. I think that it is the Minister's responsibility to explain to the House precisely what the Government proposes to do about it.

I said in a debate in this House on 23 March 1988 that the Government claims that there will be no losers in this arrangement. I think I have clearly demonstrated that there are losers and unfortunately there will continue to be losers, at least for a relatively short period. Its commitment is that existing pensioners will not have their total income reduced to below what it was prior to the introduction of this scheme. As I have demonstrated from the letter from which I have quoted, at least one person has had a significant reduction in her income. I said on that earlier occasion that this problem will not be met, and this has certainly been proved to be correct. It is because the benchmark used-that is, the amount received prior to the scheme-will not be indexed. For example, in six months if a pensioner who now receives a total income of $118 per week-let us not forget that we are talking about March 1988-had stayed in the old scheme, that amount would be increased with the consumer price index and would be worth slightly more. Under the new scheme the pension will not be adjusted up to the new figures; it will be adjusted only to the original $118 and the pension would thus lose value at the original current rate of inflation.

I thought that I was pointing out for the benefit of the Government at that time what was, as I said, an unintended consequence. I am somewhat saddened to have to say that my expectations have been more than justified. While the Opposition supports the passage of this legislation, I hope that the Minister will spend a little time in the House trying to assure us and no doubt the many hundreds, if not thousands, of single parents in Australia that the circumstances in which they find themselves, in which they are suffering a reduction in their income, can, by one means or another, be overcome in the foreseeable future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Child Support Amendment Bill is a simple and almost technical amendment to the Child Support Act which was passed earlier this year. Although simple, the very fact that such an amendment is required tells a very disturbing story about the Government of Queensland. It reveals a State government that is hypocritical in the extreme, a government that is anti-family and a government that ranks power for power's sake well above the needs of children and parents. To understand the need for the amendment it is necessary to be familiar with the Government's reforms of both the Family Law Act and the collection of court maintenance awards which have occurred over the last 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year the Parliament approved a major rewriting of the provisions of the Family Law Act as it dealt with children. A new part VII was inserted into the Act and put into one place all the provisions, both substantive and procedural, which related to children. The significant feature of the new scheme was the referral of power by the States of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania to the Commonwealth pursuant to section 51 (xxxvii.) of the Constitution. The power referred was in terms of, firstly, the maintenance of children and the payment of expenses in relation to children and child bearing and, secondly, the custody and guardianship of, and access to, children. This means that the operation of the Family Law Act is extended to cover all children, not merely those deemed to be children of the marriage under the old section 5 of the Family Law Act. Two States, Queensland and Western Australia, have not referred power to the Commonwealth in this field. However, the situation of Western Australia is different in that it is the only State that has taken up the option to create a State, as opposed to a Federal, Family Court. Accordingly, the State court can exercise full jurisdiction concerning the custody, access and maintenance of children.

The importance of this change and the need to combine all jurisdiction involving children was made apparent by a series of decisions of the High Court of Australia earlier this decade. Essentially, the problem is that complicated jurisdictional issues come into play when the custody or access issues involve step-parents, grandparents, second marriages and de facto relationships. In some cases, the Family Court of Australia had exclusive jurisdiction. In other cases, the State Supreme Court had jurisdiction. Sometimes one set of facts, say, those involving a half-sister and a half-brother, resulted in the Family Court having jurisdiction to decide only part of the dispute and the other part of the dispute would have to go to the Supreme Court.

While battles over correct jurisdiction are not that uncommon in the Australian legal system, it is inconceivable and intolerable that they should exist where people's lives-and of most paramount consideration, the welfare of children-are at stake. The concern caused by the situation existing prior to the 1987 amendment to the Family Law Act was expressed by the justices of the High Court in the case of Fountain v. Alexander in 1982 to be found at page 615 of volume 150 of the Commonwealth Law Reports. At page 628 the then Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs, stated:

This case provides yet another example of the confusion and inconvenience that is caused by the fact that Jurisdiction in cases relating to the custody of children is divided between State and Federal Courts. Not only are the parties left uncertain as to the proper forum, thus causing costs to mount and delays to increase, but there is no one court which can determine the custody of the two children in the present case, notwithstanding that they are half brother and half sister.
The current Chief Justice, Sir Anthony Mason, commented, at page 637:

I agree with the comments of the Chief Justice urging that action should be taken to overcome the serious problems that beset the Family Court's limited jurisdiction. They are problems that this Court cannot solve: Yet they pose formidable obstacles to the prompt and just determination of Family Law controversies. The number of Family Law Cases which have come before this Court involving arid jurisdictional questions only is much too high for our comfort or for that of litigants generally.
His Honour Mr Justice Murphy also stated, at page 640:

The value of vesting jurisdiction exclusively in the Family Court of Australia is that it avoids the confusion, embarrassment and expense which would occur if different Courts had competing jurisdiction. Many of the unfortunate jurisdictional problems would be removed or diminished if the Family Court were vested with all the jurisdiction in Family Law matters permitted by the Constitution.

It took some five years after that case for the Commonwealth and New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania to come to terms with the problems identified by the justices of the High Court. But come to terms they did and, as I stated earlier, Western Australia has already overcome the issue of jurisdiction by having a State Family Court. This leaves Queensland. The National Party Government of Queensland will, no doubt, over the next few days, make an awful lot of noise about how it opposes the Commonwealth classification of non-violent erotic videos and how it supports families and so-called moral values. This is the same pious Government that leaves Queensland families and Queensland children in a situation where many are denied the help and advice offered by the counselling service of the Family Court at the most emotional and distressing time of their lives, when their major relationship has broken down.

Instead, the situation in Queensland is that parents, the litigants, are faced with three competing courts handling child disputes: the Family Court which, within the limitations of the Constitution, can deal only with the children of a marriage; the State Supreme Court, which has jurisdiction over ex-nuptial children and some disputes involving grandparents and step-parents, but not necessarily all disputes involving them; and the State Children's Court, a court which essentially deals with criminal matters or applications from the State Department of Family Services for care and control or supervision orders for children but which still has some jurisdiction in maintenance, custody and access orders for ex-nuptial children.

While both the Supreme Court and the Children's Court have access to welfare reports from social workers, these courts are not designed and are not set up to carry out the role of a conciliator in order to determine disputes without the parties actually going before a judge. That is the hallmark of the Family Court and that is what sets it apart from the State courts. This was one of the driving forces behind the establishment of the Family Court in the first place. The Family Court has attached to it a specialist counselling service which, hopefully, will resolve these sorts of problems. Yet, many parents and many children in Queensland now find themselves denied access to that Court.

Why do the States of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania find that they can forgo this power and give it to the Commonwealth to solve the problems? Why cannot Queensland do the same? The reality is that the Queensland Government places its paranoiac fear of Commonwealth power miles above any concern it may have for families. The pious concern and the rhetoric that one gets out of the Queensland Premier and the Queensland Government about family values is simply sickening when we look at the reality of this obscene situation, which could easily be resolved.

Since the Family Law Act was amended last year there have been many attempts by the Commonwealth Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and officers of his Department to try to negotiate some way to overcome these problems in Queensland. Those attempts have proved fruitless. The same situation has applied. The Queensland Government says, `We will not give away our power to the Commonwealth. Oh no, it is all a question of States rights. The Constitution gives us this power and we are going to keep it'. That is sheer and utter lunacy.

The amendment to the Child Support Act before the House tonight predicts that Queensland will pass legislation to allow the Child Support Agency to collect awards from the Children's Court and the magistrates courts made for ex-nuptial children pursuant to the terms of the Queensland Maintenance Act. This means that ex-nuptial children, who should not really have to be blamed for the Queensland Government's pious distaste for the decision of their parents not to get married, will gain the benefits of receiving regular assistance by way of maintenance from the non-custodial parent. This will go a long way towards lifting those children out of poverty, which is the main aim of the whole child support legislation. That is what this Parliament and the Queensland Parliament should be all about. It is certainly what this Government is about; it is what the measures in the Child Support Act are all about.

But, even when sole parents are receiving a little more income by way of regular maintenance, what does the Queensland Government do? It determines that this maintenance has to be taken into account in calculating the income of a family. Sole parent families which, prior to this extra income being granted, were getting concessions from the Main Roads Department on car registration, had their rents calculated in a certain way by the Queensland Housing Commission or were getting rate rebates from their local council, if they were fortunate enough to end up with a home as a result of a property settlement or some other circumstances, will now lose these concessions.

For every step that this Government takes to try to lift these families out of poverty, the Queensland Government comes in and takes a bit for itself. It militates against this Government's attempts to improve people's lifestyles and that simply is not good enough. It makes me sick when I hear the Queensland Premier and members of the Queensland Government uttering all this nonsense about their support for families when, in reality, if they cared about Queensland families and children they would do something to resolve these ridiculous jurisdictional problems caused by competing courts in Queensland. The other States have got it right. Western Australia has got it right by having its own State Family Court. Why can Queensland not get it right? This Bill deserves the support of the House and I welcome the Opposition's support but I really wish that Queensland Opposition members would try to make some representations to the Queensland Government in order to resolve this ludicrous situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the original Child Support Bill was debated by the House of Representatives earlier this year it was my lot to follow the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) then. On that occasion I recall congratulating him on his sincerity on the general subject of the Child Support Agency which is, of course, the proper support of children. I acknowledged his sincerity then and I do so again now, but I must say that he confuses me a little as does the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). The amendment to that legislation which we are debating today will facilitate the application of the Child Support Act to ex-nuptial children in Queensland and Western Australia. In his second reading speech the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the event, both Queensland and Western Australia have now indicated that they intend to adopt the Child Support Act as a means of including ex-nuptial children in their States in the Government's new child support scheme.

I would agree with some of the comments made by the honourable member for Fisher about the slowness of the Queensland Government over successive years in recognising that the arrangements with the Federal Government in this area have much to offer families and children of failed marriages, whether legal or de facto. I had taken a rather more optimistic line than the honourable member for Fisher in the light of the Minister's words in the belief that perhaps some progress was being made. However, I say to the honourable member that very little will be achieved if political grandstanding is indulged in at this stage. There has been too much grandstanding on this subject in the past by the Queensland Government, I agree, but grandstanding at this stage when some progress apparently is being made by the present Government, certainly will not help us.

The Child Support Amendment Bill provides for an extension of the Child Support Agency arrangements. To date the registrar has only been able to collect maintenance in respect of a child who is a child of a marriage or a child who is not a child of a marriage where the State had referred its powers for ex-nuptial children. Those were the States of New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania and South Australia. As the Minister said in his second reading speech, an indication has been given that Western Australia and Queensland are now prepared to move in that same direction. The Bill before us tonight is essentially a technical Bill to tidy up some aspects of the Child Support Act to enable that to happen. That gives us the opportunity to address the general subject of child support, and specifically the support of those children of de facto arrangements.

I wish to take this opportunity to say a couple of words on that general subject. A couple of weeks ago I was a little distressed to hear the Minister make the statement that the Fraser Government had never done anything about or shown any interest in the maintenance of children of failed marriages or de facto relationships. In 1980 a joint select committee of this Parliament, under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), brought in a report following a total review of the Family Law Act. The Family Law Act had then been in operation for less than five years and, having had the opportunity to operate for those few years, Parliament believed that it was timely in 1979 to review the operations of the Act. It was clear by then that an area that was not operating satisfactorily was that of maintenance and specifically the frequent resort that was being had to the supporting parent benefit in order to support children of failed relationships.

In 1980 the Joint Select Committee reported on a range of matters, including the matter of maintenance. As I recall, it recommended that a maintenance collection agency should be established; I think it also recommended a formula for maintenance. This proposal was considered by the Fraser Government in the normal way that governments consider committee proposals. I understand that the examination of this proposal for a maintenance collection agency ran into pretty energetic opposition from the Department of Social Security, which the Minister now oversees, on the ground that the Department did not see its role as one of collection but as one of disbursing government payments.

When Senator Chaney was Minister he commissioned a report on the subject of the supporting parent benefit and how parents might better be persuaded to face their financial responsibilities to their children. That report, which was not a public report, came to the Fraser Government only at the end of its period in power. The Hawke Government had that report available to it from the beginning of its time in power in 1983. There is no doubt, and I think the Minister should acknowledge this, that the Fraser Government was moving along the correct path of trying to establish a satisfactory maintenance situation for sole parents and their children in this country. It did not reach that position, but I do not think the timetable was so extraordinary that it deserves any particular criticism for that. I hope the Minister will also recognise that he has had the support of the Opposition on the subject of the Child Support Agency. There were some differences of detail when we debated the Bill earlier this year, but essentially it was supported, and it went through with strong support from the Opposition parties. As I said earlier, the Opposition has welcomed the indication by Western Australia and Queensland that they will accept the child support agency arrangement for ex-nuptial children. I would agree that this anomaly has caused many difficulties for children and their parents, particularly in Queensland. The Minister in his second reading speech on the original Child Support Bill said:
We are in a unique position to be able to use our family law, taxation and social security powers under the constitution to integrate a national system.

Of course the situation of children of de facto relationships, particularly in those two States, has shown that there were some weaknesses in our constitutional position, and we very much welcome that weakness now being addressed.

I think it is relevant in a debate on this subject that we should pay some attention to the fairly modern phenomenon of the growth of de facto marriages and the growth in the percentage of children who are ex-nuptial. It is a matter which concerns me and naturally it concerns a lot of women, certainly those of my generation. My concern is not a censorious one, as the Minister is aware, but it has concerned me for some time that women, particularly young women, allow themselves to be in a situation where they have children who become very heavily dependent on mothers and fathers-such is the pattern of our society-and the parents do not seek some legal protection not only for those children but also for themselves while those children are young and highly dependent. I have been concerned that the trend towards young couples not marrying and not accepting the legal arrangements that formerly obtained in this country under the Marriage Act has not been beneficial to women in the long run. I am not one who believes that people should be married against their will or that they should stay married once they are married against their will. But we seem, in my humble opinion, to have gone too far the other way, and it has become fashionable not to marry, to sneer at the institution and to spurn the very real legal protections that marriage gives without a proper examination of the desirability of those protections. Of course it is always the vulnerable people we have to consider, and it is the children who are the most vulnerable in this case.

I am also concerned about the superficial but nevertheless censorious treatment of the subject evident on occasions in this House. I am going to quote one of my colleagues. I regret that he is not in the country because he is doing this Parliament's business overseas. I would never want him to think that I have leapt at this opportunity, because I would certainly be quoting his words if he were here. I cannot let this debate pass by without making some reference to them. In the debate on the original Child Support Bill in February of this year, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) said:

Until the mid-1960s, a little under 6 per cent of children were born outside wedlock. Today about 16 per cent of all births are outside wedlock. That information comes from the Department of Social Security statistics section. It indicates that the number of never married mothers in receipt of a supporting parent's benefit has increased from 13,500 in 1974 to 45,000 in 1987. This is a trebling of the number which existed in 1974 at the time of the introduction of this benefit . . . Never married mothers received more than $400m of the $1.5 billion paid out under this benefit . . .

Another area of the supporting parents' benefit that has taken off like bushfire is that relative to those who have simply been living together, have had children and are no longer together. In 1974 there were 3,100 women in this group. In 13 short years that number has grown to 17,700.

I am sorry to have to say this, because it seems so obvious, but where there is a never married mother there is a father who has not married that mother. If there are 3,100 women accepting the supporting parent's benefit who have simply lived with the father of their children, then there may well be 3,100 men who have fathered those children. That is based on the 1974 figures, and in 13 years the figure had grown to 17,700. I think those figures indicate the trend I was referring to earlier.

It distresses me that argument on this matter is always cast in terms of females. It concerns me very deeply that young women-they are not always young women but a large number of them are-will enter into this arrangement without understanding that that sort of censure still will come on them. That, in itself, is enough. In that debate I said:
Criticism that has flowed to the female recipients of the supporting parent's benefit has rarely flowed to the unmarried fathers of those children.

I think it is worth noting that 85 per cent of recipients of the sole parent's benefit are divorced or separated. It is also worth noting in the context in which so many people choose to put it-a context of immoral young females-that only 4 per cent of all supporting parents are teenagers and that they are not exclusively female; there are some male teenagers who are on supporting parent's benefits.
That is fact, and I think that has to be stated.

I want to make a couple of other points. I do not know whether this is something the Minister for Social Security is addressing. If it is, I would welcome in his response an indication that he is, and, if it is not something that the Government is currently addressing, I hope it starts to move towards it. We must address the question of simply why this does happen. Why is it that so many of our young women-admittedly, a small percentage of recipients of supporting parent's benefit; nevertheless several thousand each year-enter into arrangements where very clearly there is not a commitment by both parents to the child that results from that arrangement. I have had stated to me, as I know other members of this House would have, by social workers and people who have worked in the past with the community youth support scheme, that they believe there is a link between the number of young unmarried mothers in our community and, for example, female unemployment. They say that in their experience of working with these young hopelessly long term unemployed teenagers they have found that the girls get a feeling of lack of self-worth. These girls believe that through becoming a mother they will be doing something worthwhile, something productive and something which contributes to society.

There are too many of these people saying it in all sincerity for me to brush it aside. Unfortunately, I am not aware that it has ever been properly studied. The information that I have is anecdotal. I would welcome it if the Minister for Social Security indicated whether he is aware of any studies of this. If not, to try to measure why we have this phenomenon to the extent that we do could be something worth studying.

I would also be very interested to know whether the Government is monitoring the application of the new maintenance arrangements to de facto situations. It has applied ever since the Child Support Agency was set up, but tonight we are talking about the extension of this legislation only to these two States. So already, there are the beginnings of experience of the activities of the Child Support Agency in relation to the children of de facto marriages.

I hope that the new maintenance arrangements will in themselves affect the situation. I expect that they will because the very arrangement will bring home to the potential young parents that it is not so easy and that they have a commitment and a responsibility. My basic concern has always been that those young people may not have understood fully the nature of their commitment to another human being-a child-when they decided to become a parent. I expect and hope that the new maintenance arrangements will bring home to these young people the understanding of the extent and the duration of that commitment.

As I have said, I am pleased to support the arrangements. I hope that the Minister is having the success with Queensland that I have taken as being indicated in his second reading speech, which is a little more optimistic in tone than that given to us this evening by the honourable member for Fisher. I look forward to the Minister's response on those other personal points I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very refreshing and pleasing to be able to rise after hearing two excellent contributions to debate in this House, from the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) and the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan). So often the debates in this House are characterised by trivialisation of important issues. Seeing here tonight the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), one cannot let pass the damage done to what would be a great landmark in social reform in Australia with the proposal that the Minister has brought forward for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission to look after Aboriginal affairs. Time after time we see sensible proposals being dealt with on a party, slighting and trivialising basis.

SPEECH.PARA: But tonight we have one of those rare instances where both sides of the House seem to be about the business of addressing an issue seriously and constructively. It is very refreshing. It is coming to a point in time where we can look back over a long period of Australia's history and say that we are proud of the fact that successive governments have brought really very substantial changes to the way in which we deal with the problem of marriages which do not succeed, circumstances where children are left dependent on one parent, and separations and family break-ups occur. It has a long history and one which goes back to the prewar days when social security was virtually non-existent in those circumstances and the sort of support structures that we now take for granted in our community were deficient.

Slowly, we evolve mechanisms to cope with the inevitable tragedies that occur from time to time in the break-up of marriages. I guess that we would all like to see most marriages not break up, but we recognise that it is inevitable that some marriages will not succeed. It is inevitable that some children will find themselves the victims of marriages which do not work. We also know that it is a reality, whether we like it or not, that people will bear children out of marriage who then have the responsibility of bringing up those children, caring for them and providing for them a loving and warm environment.

Over the years the different legislative means that governments have provided to look after children in this situation have changed. In the past we had the Matrimonial Causes Act. That involved questions of fault which meant that decisions about custody, maintenance and access turned on notions of who was wrong in the broken marriage that had preceded the situation in which the children's needs came to be at issue. Obviously, as our attitudes have changed, we have had to respond differently than was the case under the pre-Family Law Act mechanisms. The Family Law Act brought a breath of fresh air into the way in which Australians dealt with the problems of broken marriages and the needs of children. We saw the institution of a system of counselling, priority being given to the interests of children, and a break away from the idea that retribution was to be meted out to blameworthy partners of marriages that had failed. We got away from that idea and looked instead to the fundamental needs of the parties and, of course, to the needs of children. That has been a very successful and significant step.

In the case of children who are born to women who are unmarried, our social services and legislative framework has changed. Originally, pressure was put on such mothers to have their children adopted. They were made to feel the opprobrium of society and, even when adoption was an option, we know that there were some very unsatisfactory outcomes. We now have a very good system of adoption for those single parents who wish their children to be adopted. Such parents can be sure that their children will find loving, warm and caring homes, but if they wish to keep their child and rear and nurture the child themselves, there is a system of support for those parents. That system has been the subject of careful and constructive review.

The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who is at the table, needs to be commended for the way in which he has moved to make sure that if one is a single parent one will not be perpetually dependent on the State; rather, that there will be a temporary situation during which priority for care and nurture of the children can be given, but the person who has completed that nurturing role will be encouraged to return to full time employment in the community through innovative schemes such as the jobs, education and training (JET) scheme which the Minister has introduced and publicised following the last Budget. Australia has started to deal with that real social issue in a constructive and positive way. It has moved people away from dependence and encouraged them to return to the work force. It has moved away from some of the negative aspects that have characterised the relationship between the role of supporting parent and the State in the past.

There is a commitment to the obligation not only of the State to the custodial parent but also of the non-custodial parent. Frequently, the non-custodial parent will be male but that is not always the case. There are custodial parents who are male and non-custodial parents who are female. But whatever, in the past it was far too easy for non-custodial parents to avoid their responsibility towards the maintenance and care of their offspring. This situation is slowly being remedied. The landmark initiative of the Minister in introducing the Child Support Act in 1988-the Child Support Agency-brings in measures that will ensure that those who foster children, who procreate children, will have the responsibility of their care in the future so that those burdens cannot simply be placed on another human being and on the State.

These are important forward steps. They will not be introduced without teething problems. I noted a comment earlier in this debate about some of the transition arrangements. I am sure that the Minister will have noted those comments. There are bound to be other instances where people suggest that review or revision of the arrangements are appropriate. But I think it is important to put this in an historical context because what we are seeing now is a rounding out of a very important process of our Australian history. We have moved from fault and a situation of lack of social support to a situation now where we are looking to have one of the most enlightened, sensible and constructive systems of social security support and family law anywhere in the world. It is one we should be proud of. I suppose that we only see the snapshot, the small part of which we have been involved in, but if honourable members look back over the 40 years of recent history in Australia, they will see that both parties have reason to be proud of these developments. The present Minister, who has taken these fairly important recent steps, has much to be proud of.

I will pick up one point that was made earlier in this debate by the honourable member for Fisher. There are still a couple of steps to go before we can say that we have a national scheme or that we have a system that is truly functional and truly effective. It is absurd that Queensland still declines to refer powers over the question of custody of ex-nuptial children to the Commonwealth or to establish a court such as the Western Australian Government has done cooperatively with the Commonwealth. The failure to do this leaves a great weakness in the system and can lead to enormous family tragedies where disputes over important issues of custody, maintenance and care of children degenerates into trivial point scoring between jurisdictions and questions of which court is the appropriate forum. Perhaps even more insidious are the partial arguments, some parts of a question involving custody being resolved in a Federal court and issues relating to other children being resolved in State courts. This is a disgrace.

I am pleased, however, to see that, at least in so far as the question of collection of maintenance for ex-nuptial children is concerned, it is now clear that the Queensland Government will come to the party. The Child Support Amendment Bill reflects that willingness. So yet again we have come one step closer to being, I suppose, in relation to this issue, a nation at last.

In closing this debate, using the phrase `a nation at last', I commend to the House and to those who may be listening to the broadcast a recent book that was written by a very close friend of mine, Dr Stephen Alomes, of Deakin University in Geelong. His recent book called A Nation at Last looks at the way in which nationalism has been used and abused over the last 100 years of our nation. But certainly we are coming close to a national scheme for the care and protection of those most in need-children of fractured marriages, children whose parents have never married, and children whose parents have separated and perhaps left them dependent on only one parent.

This is an historic opportunity. We have moved one step closer to a useful constructive national scheme. We only need the Queensland Government to take a few more steps in the right direction to exercise either the Western Australian option, that is, to establish a State family court which can work in conjunction with the Commonwealth court so that all the disputes can be heard in that State's jurisdiction, or, alternatively, for it to refer powers to the Commonwealth so that the Family Court of Australia can deal with all matters as has been the case in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania. Either of those options will make sense and will close the door on one of the shonky episodes of Australia's history in which families in distress have been sent forum shopping between the State and Federal jurisdictions.

In closing, let me commend the Minister. Let me also commend the previous speakers in this debate because it has been a pleasure to sit through what I believe has been one of the more constructive debates I have had the privilege to participate in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in support of the Child Support Amendment Bill 1988. Initially, the States of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania agreed to refer their powers relating to ex-nuptial children to the Commonwealth. Now, Queensland and Western Australia have also indicated their agreement to refer their powers to the Commonwealth in regard to ex-nuptial children in their States. The purpose of this Bill, therefore, is to amend the Child Support Act to bring Queensland and Western Australia into line with the other States and enable the child support scheme to operate in those States. The child support scheme, of course, is the centrepiece of the Government strategy to eliminate child poverty. Previously, 70 per cent of non-custodial parents failed to make any contribution to the welfare of their children and thus condemned thousands of children to a life of unnecessary hardship and poverty.

SPEECH.PARA: Stage one of the child support scheme has been operating since June this year. Already there are indications of its success. Nationally, there are 11,000 orders registered with the Child Support Agency with another 2,200 applications now being processed. At the moment without automatic withholding the Agency is experiencing a payment rate of five out of 10 compared with the previous payment rate of only three out of 10. To that degree this scheme is a great success. The Child Support Agency is in the process of issuing 82 notices to employers to start deducting from wages and salaries. There are 14,000 children covered and 700 spouses. Another thing to consider is that of the payment rate of five out of 10 a considerable number of payers who originally were failing to meet their obligations are now doing so. The payment rate is most pleasing when we consider that the scheme has been operating only since June. The Child Support Agency is confident that it will reach the 90 per cent target which it has set itself.

Over $1m per month, nationally, is now being paid to the Agency. New South Wales, which includes the Australian Capital Territory, has 2,079 orders registered, with another 990 in the pipeline. Out of those 11,000 orders registered with the Child Support Agency, only 554 have been deemed ineligible because they separated before the start of the scheme and were non-pensioners. Only 41 people have been deemed untraceable which is a good result out of 11,000. We should remember Opposition claims that the scheme would not work. It claimed that thousands would flee Australia to avoid meeting their obligations. At this stage only 41 out of 11,000 are deemed untraceable. The Child Support Agency has another 400 people subject to tracing but it is confident that with the new tax file number legislation, these will be easily traced.

We now find that since amendments to the Family Law Act the Family Courts are making more realistic maintenance orders and these orders are now enforceable. This is a very different state of affairs from that which existed prior to the introduction of the child support scheme. One Family Court solicitor in my electorate of Hunter has expressed some reservations about Family Court maintenance orders because he believes that in some instances the orders have been too high. However, without pre-empting the stage 2 legislation, I believe that this legislation will address his concern.

Generally the child support scheme has won widespread community support and parents are now much more aware of their obligations towards their ex-nuptial children. In an article in the Australian Law News in June 1988, a contributor acknowledged the aims of the child support scheme as unchallengeable but questioned whether the package of measures would achieve the end sought. However, that contributor was unable to come up with any alternative to the child support scheme. That article was written pre-Budget and the author will be pleased to know that the concerns he expressed about the availability of adequate training schemes for women have been addressed in the August Budget. I am referring to the jobs, education and training (JET) program for women on supporting parent's benefit which will start in the new year. The innovative JET program has been specifically tailored to helping sole parents into the work force.

Without going into too much detail, because the JET program and other social security Budget measures will be debated in separate legislation, I would like to make a brief comment on the program. It is a voluntary program whose target groups are sole parents of school age children-sole parents whose youngest child will reach 16 years of age within two years and sole parents who are under 20 years of age. JET will provide special help in the form of counselling, training, education, job search assistance and child care. The program is important particularly because it recognises the special difficulties faced by sole parents when they attempt to enter or re-enter the work force. Turning back to the Australian Law News article, the author said:

One thing is certain, appropriate measures must be taken to alleviate poverty among children, to bring home to the progenitors of children the real nature of their obligation and to require them to live up to it and to remove from the supporting parents the poverty traps which have been created.

I have no argument at all with this statement for I firmly believe the child support scheme is a positive step in the right direction. The Government has appointed the Australian Institute of Family Studies (AIFS) to monitor and evaluate the impact of stage 1. The major objectives of the Institute's research are to measure the effectiveness of the procedures in accordance with its aims. Ms Margaret Harrison, a fellow of the AIFS, is project co-ordinator of the Institute's evaluation of the child support scheme. She states that information is being obtained from people whose dates of separation or children's birthdates predate the introduction of stage 1, as well as those people who pay or receive maintenance via the Child Support Agency. The AIFS also will monitor how employers are affected by the scheme because of their obligation to withhold salaries and transmit money to the Agency. The AIFS recognises that greater financial participation in the rearing of children may have an impact on parenting after separation. This also will be a focus of research. Visiting patterns, the sharing of non-financial responsibilities and any increases or decreases in court disputes about children will be monitored in mailed questionnaires.

The Institute's evaluation of this important program will assess the impact it has on a proportion of the population which has for many years been financially vulnerable. The feedback in my electorate of Hunter on stage one of the child support program indicates that the majority of sole parents are extremely happy about receiving maintenance payments without the hassles that previously existed when the courts tried to enforce maintenance orders. Some have indicated that they are now receiving maintenance for the first time. It is also true to say that I have had one or two irate sole parents contact me claiming that they would be worse off under the new child support scheme. When I checked the information provided to me I found that this was not correct. In real terms the average sole parent family will be better off.

With the December increase in additional pension for children, sole parents will receive a maximum of $24 a week for each dependent child under age 13 and a maximum of $31 a week for children aged 13 to 15.
