The Australian Taxation Office has already indicated that it is planning to take court action against a number of non-custodial parents for failing to meet their child maintenance payments. Obviously, the Tax Office is much better placed to locate defaulting payers than was the case under the previous arrangement, whereby State courts made the collections. No longer will maintenance defaulters be able simply to ignore court orders and shirk their responsibilities as they have in the past.

Despite having undergone a period of difficult economic restraint, this Hawke Labor Government has implemented sound economic strategies. It has taken positive steps to alleviate the problem of child poverty. The child support scheme means that hundreds of thousands of children will have regular maintenance to depend on for the first time. Now the children in Queensland and Western Australia will benefit from the child support scheme in the same way as children in the other States. I congratulate the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time I have available to me I would like to add my congratulations to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), to the Opposition and to the Queensland Government. It is very rare for me to congratulate the Queensland Government, but at least for once in this place I can stand here and say that, perhaps as a result of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, the Queensland Government is now looking beyond its own pockets and its own self-aggrandisement. It is actually starting to think about the constituency it supposedly represents-the people of Queensland. The Child Support Amendment Bill, if nothing else, will ensure that Queenslanders get the same benefits from the family law system that other Australians have long had.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is but another thread in the fabric of social and legal change affecting families since 1975. All parliamentarians, particularly those of us who have practised the law and those of us who have had experience in the Family Law Courts, would know only too well the great change that was wrought in 1975 and the great need for further changes down the track. From my point of view, as one who has practised in that jurisdiction, it has taken a long time for apparent and needed changes to occur. The fact that ex-nuptial children are still outside the scope of the Family Law Act is, to me, a source of great regret. I look forward to the day when the States collectively understand that the most appropriate way to deal with custody and similar matters regarding ex-nuptial children is under a Commonwealth Act, a Family Law Act, so that all children are treated the same and a similar system of law applies to all questions of custody and maintenance.

The child support scheme, of course, brings into effect something which is socially desirable, economically desirable and morally desirable-that is, that those people who create children, the parents of children, undertake the economic support of those children irrespective of whether the couples remain married. For many years while I practised family law the Commonwealth government of the day provided benefits to single parents-single because they were single at the time they bore the children or as a result of divorce. But in calculating the appropriate maintenance to be paid as a result of the separation or the birth of the child, the fact that the Commonwealth Government paid money was always taken into account in assessing the amount that the non-custodial parent would pay. To my way of thinking that was a great shame. Some Family Court judges, counsellors and lawyers still have to answer why they took that attitude, why they did not ignore the fact that a Commonwealth payment was available and why they did not seek the appropriate maintenance payment for the non-custodial spouse at the time of the separation rather than allowing the Commonwealth government of the day to pick up the tab and then work out how much extra should be paid in order that that custodial child should receive a fair maintenance payment. I think it probably still operates that way, although this legislation makes it far more difficult for that to occur.

I commend the Bill to the House. I do not want to hold up the House further; I know the Minister for Social Security would like to make a few comments before the guillotine comes into effect at 10.30 p.m. But I am pleased to see all members of this House recognise the importance of the child support program. We can look forward to the day in the future when ex-nuptial children will receive the same protection under the Family Law Act as other children now have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I would like to say how much I appreciated the contributions from members on both sides of the House to this debate. We have had a series of very constructive contributions. It is pleasing that the States of Western Australia and Queensland have been able to commit themselves to legislation. In fact, I was just saying to the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) that the Queensland Government is actually introducing this legislation, as I understand it, tomorrow, and it is a very important step towards achieving a national scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: We would like to see a national approach in terms of family law legislation, and we would like to see further changes in relation to Queensland. Without holding up the House, I repeat that it has been a very constructive debate in relation to this further stage of the development of child support legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Howe) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: RICHARD FARMER AND ASSOCIATES PTY LTD

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the indulgence of the House to make a statement.
—Indulgence is granted.

—I thank the House. In concluding an answer at Question Time today I said, `In any event, Farmer Brothers is a private company', et cetera. I should have said, `In any event, Richard Farmer and Associates Pty Ltd is a private company', et cetera. I said that inadvertently and I have amended the Hansard accordingly.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation we are debating tonight is the Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. The coalition parties do not oppose the Bill. It seeks to amend various existing insurance legislation to levy an annual supervisory fee on general insurers and life insurers and to overcome certain deficiencies in the existing legislation so as to maintain effective supervision over the general insurance and life insurance industries. I understand that these proposals have been the subject of extensive negotiations between the Government and various industry bodies such as the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, the Insurance Council of Australia, the Institute of Actuaries of Australia, and the National Insurance Brokers Association of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: While expressing initial reservation about certain aspects of the Government's proposals, for example the question of a levy, I understand these groups are prepared to accept the outcome. However, at this point I would like to register the Opposition's dissatisfaction with the Government's disregard of Parliament in this case. We frequently know that there might be a week between the introduction of legislation and its debate. On this occasion the legislation came in with seven other Bills, some of them making extensive modifications to the tax law in Australia. It may be that there are few problems with this legislation, it may be that there are significant problems, having to consider eight pieces of legislation introduced late last Thursday, we would have little chance of knowing. It is now only Wednesday and we are expected, given the heavy legislative program and other parliamentary business, to debate this Bill in an informed and intelligent way.

It shows an arrogance by this Government towards the role of Parliament-something I have mentioned before-and towards the people of Australia whom this body represents. Such haste leads to bad and slipshod government. We had two further instances of legislation this afternoon, to which I was responding that had to be amended in the Senate. Too often legislation introduced into the Parliament has been ill considered and badly drafted. I trust that is not the case with this Bill. The taxation area, which like this Bill falls under the responsibility of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), is a classic case of foul-ups and rewriting. Last year we saw close to 10 Bills amending taxation laws, many running upwards of 50 pages. This year is just as bad. Without mentioning other legislation, we are expected to debate Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) tomorrow. That came in only last Thursday and makes about 13 significant amendments to the law, including the gold tax. There is the classic case of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), who last month had to introduce 280 amendments to legislation that he himself had brought in only a short time before. I trust that this Bill we are debating will not need 280 amendments.

As this is a Bill to amend the law relating to insurance, there is a particular point concerning the treatment of the insurance industry that I would like to raise with the Government. Prior to the May economic statement this year, the tax system treated life offices and friendly societies on a concessional basis. Life offices were taxed at 49c in the dollar, but on a concessional tax base because of certain tax deductions under sections 46, 115 and 116 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Friendly societies were taxed at 20 per cent, albeit on a more comprehensive base. Following the May statement, the deductions allowable for life offices will be severely cut back. As from 1988-89 they will now be subject to the 39 per cent tax rate and dividends received by life insurance funds are to be subject to the imputation system. The rate of tax applying to the life insurance business of friendly societies is to be increased from the present rate of 20 per cent to 30 per cent from the 1988-89 income year. It would seem that, as a result of these changes, most taxpayers would be better off not investing in ordinary life insurance but investing in their personal accounts. The Government's assumption that this will not be the case is based on a familiar story to all of those who have been interested in the new 15 per cent tax on superannuation funds.

With the various tax concessions removed, life offices will have to take significant advantage of the newly applying imputation rules to maintain them in a neutral position-that is, not a worse position. It has been estimated that it necessitates life insurers holding 35 per cent of their portfolio in assets which would yield franked dividends. Most life offices say they do not hold such a mix, nor will they, given their duties to follow prudent investment practices. I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations and the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris), who is responsible for this piece of legislation: Until and unless they attain such a mix, is it true that the ordinary taxpayer paying an average tax rate of, say, about 30 per cent would be penalised for investing in ordinary life insurance? For this year, will thousands of taxpayers suffer greater tax because of their existing investment in life insurance? Indeed, there is yet again the same old question: When will we see the legislation in that arena and how long must we wait?

Returning to the Bill at hand, I note that it will be introducing an annual supervisory levy for the insurance industry. The Opposition supports such a move. The concept of user pays is a profound one. It is one of the bases of the rational economics which the coalition parties have adopted. We welcome the Government's often belated steps into the realm of rationality. It is so much more satisfying and coherent compared to the Government's usual knee-jerk damage control on economic issues. In his second reading speech the Minister said:

The proposed fee reflects the Government's view that, generally, where a service is designed to benefit a particular group, the cost should be borne by that immediate group of beneficiaries of the service rather than by taxpayers in general.

As I said, the principle is correct, but there is something strange about such a statement coming out of the mouth of one of this Government's Ministers. The reference to relieving the burden on `taxpayers in general' is nothing more than the crying of crocodile tears. Nothing can hide the fact that this Government and its Treasurer have not the slightest regard for the taxpayer in general. After all, this is the highest taxing Government in Australia's post-war, if not entire, history. The Grim Reaper, in the guise of the Treasurer, has slashed away at the living standards of Australians. As I have noted before in other debates, by mid-1989, when our long awaited tax cuts are due, a person on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and two children will need a tax cut of $56 per week to restore his or her disposable income to what it was in March 1983 when this Labor Government came to power. That is a statistic that has not been and cannot be refuted by the Government. It will take a tax cut of $56 a week simply to restore an average family to the situation they were in before the Labor Government came to power.

Given that I have quoted a passage from the Minister's second reading speech which refers to the liability of taxpayers and the insurance industry, I now turn to a gross attack on taxpayers by an insurance institution in this country. I am, of course, refer- ring to the activities of the Western Australian State Government Insurance Commission (SGIC) and its role in WA Inc.-Western Australia Incorporated-and also the failure of the Rothwells merchant bank.

The State Government Insurance Commission was originally involved in the rescue package to save Rothwells following the stock market crash in October last year. At the time I raised publicly the Opposition's concerns about this use of government funds to prop up an ailing finance company. Serious doubts were raised by the Opposition, both here and in Western Australia, about the shadiness of the deals done, the lack of public disclosure, the secrecy and backroom deals of Premier Burke, the SGIC and other government bodies.

Of uppermost concern was the extent to which taxpayers' money was being put at risk to prop up the mates of the Western Australian Government. But the dirty linen usually ends up in the open. Last week Rothwells went into receivership.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Speaker: I find what the honourable member for Kooyong is talking about to be very interesting but I put it to you that it has nothing at all to do with the provisions of the Bill, and the honourable member should get down to the actual aspects of the Bill instead of talking about the Government of Western Australia.

—The Chair has been inclined over some time, as have previous occupants of the chair, to allow a certain latitude. I am sure the honourable member for Kooyong will not go beyond that latitude-I am sorry, I should have said `the Deputy Leader of the Opposition'.

—Madam Speaker, there is no need to apologise; your words are taken and received with the consideration they deserve. But on the point of order, and recognising what you said-I thank you for any expressions about latitude-as I am talking about the State Government Insurance Commission, which, as an insurance corporation, is affected by this legislation, my remarks are relevant to the Bill. All insurance corporations have to pay a levy. One of those insurance corporations is the State Government Insurance Commission and it is having to pay a levy for the general supervision of it and other associated insurance bodies, I am entitled, therefore, to direct attention to the activities of an insurance body which is under the jurisdiction of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. The reason for the Bill coming before the Parliament is to apply the principle of user pays so that the Government can recover some of the cost of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner's activities in scrutinising and scrutineering insurance corporations. I am merely singling out one particular insurance corporation which is under the ambit, I would suggest, of insurance generally. But I thank you, Madam Speaker, for your references to latitude and may I take them up on another occasion when they are necessary.
—Have a raincheck!

—Thank you. Again, that is warmly received. We now find, as I said, that last week Rothwells went into receivership. We now find that $100m of taxpayers' funds are in jeopardy. Some say that figure could go as high as $400m. Premier Dowding and ex-Premier Burke may think that they stopped a run on Rothwells bank, which, as I said, was propped up by an insurance corporation-the State Government Insurance Commission of Western Australia. However, as one commentator noted, what they really ensured was that the big corporate depositors had time to arrange their affairs securely while the small or naive ones were lulled into a false sense of security. I am informed that about 1,200 small businesses and individuals stand to lose substantially from Rothwells' collapse.

SPEECH.PARA: Such government intervention which has resulted in these individual and taxpayer losses is anathema to the philosophy of Opposition members. Of course, it is a government's duty to maintain a strong financial market, but the corporatism of the Government of Western Australia and, indeed, of this Government in Canberra, reaches far beyond this and sets off a warning bell for the future of this country. For example, why should the Western Australian Government-owned State Government Insurance Commission have a shareholding in Perth's main daily newspaper-the West Australian? No matter the answer here, fortunately the Western Australian voters will soon have a chance to register their disgust at such activities in the forthcoming State election.

In a wider context I have raised concerns on a number of occasions about the apparent blow-out in the net borrowing by public financial enterprises. Last year's Budget Paper No. 1 revealed, on page 418, that the total annual run-down in insurance office assets-that is, net borrowings-is estimated to have increased from just under $200m in 1982-83 to more than $2,000m in 1986-87. The Budget Paper went on to note:
However, as some State governments are in the process of addressing this problem the current situation may not persist.

Such faith is possibly touching, but does not disguise the fact that when I asked the Treasurer in this House about the progress State governments are allegedly making to address the problem virtually no response was forthcoming. I was informed later by correspondence from the Treasurer that due to discrepancies between recent developments in the funding of insurance schemes and the unchanged national accounts statistical treatment of these schemes the raw numbers exaggerate the problem. Nonetheless, the Treasurer simply went on to restate:
To the extent that some insurance schemes had been running down financial assets, reforms are being put in place by the States to remedy the situation.

The point is that if a public financial enterprise, such as an insurance commission, experiences difficulties by failing to reduce its net borrowings State governments, and possibly the Commonwealth Government, may be called upon to bail it out. The reality there is that it is not the State Government's money or the Commonwealth Government's money that is used to bail it out. It is the taxpayers' money. That might be an original thought for members of this Government, who assume an endless flow of revenue to prop up their large spending programs, but in the main what flows to them is flowing from the taxpayers. State Government owned insurers are not subject to the provisions of the Insurance Act, and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner has no supervisory role in regard to those insurers. Therefore, the extent to which I affirmed that before is technically incorrect. Nevertheless, they set a model for those public institutions to follow in terms of prudential management. There may not be, as I affirmed earlier, the overall control, but the model is there.

Finally, I simply restate that the coalition parties do not oppose this legislation. We hope that the improvements to the administration and supervision of the insurance industry will effectively strengthen that industry into the future and provide an example that publicly owned insurance institutions will try to emulate in an effective and non-partisan manner. That would be a departure from the norm in the behaviour of the State Government Insurance Commission in Western Australia. There are examples around Australia that probably set a pattern that others could follow. In the case of the State Government Insurance Commission in Western Australia, there should be a large sign hanging on the door, `Don't let this happen to you'. To the extent that there is any moral qualm on the part of honourable members opposite about the treatment of taxpayers' money, one would have thought that the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), who sought to take a point of order during my speech, would now be rising, bearing in mind the faction he represents and the stances he has taken on behalf of alleged downtrodden people in the community, and would have taken a stance in the Caucus earlier, to ensure that the rapacious rip-offs that have occurred in Western Australia did not go without some intervention on his behalf.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter for the State of Western Australia. It is not a matter to be brought up here.

—I hear the honourable member in this Parliament year in and year out proclaiming the rights of leftist movements overseas. He should not sit there and say that this is in the State of Western Australia. It is part of the federation of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate, therefore, that rather than holding up the House at this hour of the night, the Opposition does not oppose the Bill. I trust that the remarks that I have made in regard to Western Australia, though they may not stir the conscience of the honourable member, may stir the Treasurer through the fiduciary controls that he can bring to bear as well as the prudential controls and the straight element of proper management of taxpayers' funds, and might stir this Government, if not in legal terms at least in political terms, into nudging its colleagues in Western Australia back on to the straight and narrow path.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), who has just resumed his seat, made the thrust of his debate, in the latter part of his contribution, an attack on the Western Australian Labor Government. It always amazes me that members of the Opposition will stand up in this House and both criticise and challenge any role played by a Labor government with private enterprise, but members opposite never seem to put the spotlight on Queensland. It seems to be hypocritical for the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, the honourable member for Kooyong, to keep talking about Labor States-in this instance, Western Australia, which has done so much for the people of that State. Members opposite do not seem to worry about Queensland. Maybe they ought to. If they want to talk about the insurance industry and the way in which it has been used by a government, they ought to target Queensland to see what has taken place there. I do not intend to dwell on that issue but I think it would be a fair comment.
—I wouldn't dwell on it, otherwise you will have a quorum called on you.

—Well, you can call a quorum. It is typical of you people over there. You like two sets of rules-one for yourselves and one for us. Your Deputy Leader spoke about all sorts of issues but you sat back dumb, with your thumb in your mouth.
—Speak through the Chair, please.

—Members opposite do not like it when they are shown to be hypocritical. The Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill is an important one because it is based on the user pays principle, and one might even say on the ability to pay. It will amend the Insurance Act of 1973 and also the Life Insurance Act of 1945, to enable an annual supervisory fee to be imposed. That fee will be levied on both general insurance companies and life insurance companies to recover the cost of supervision that is carried out by government in the realm of the Insurance Superannuation Commission. I do not think that anyone would argue with that; and I am pleased to see that the Opposition will not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the insurance industry is too often the butt of criticism. That is a pity. Although it is often considered as an aspect of the private sector that is making multi-million dollar profits, the insurance industry also plays a very important part in our community. It is important to state in this House that, in more recent times, the insurance industry has become very consumer oriented. It is rather fitting that I speak in this debate, because only this day I met with members of the Insurance Council of Australia to talk about a number of issues that are affecting the consumers of this country.

It was most fitting and most important that at the discussions that did take place, we had representatives of the Insurance Superannuation Council-in fact the Insurance Commissioner, Mr Beatham, as well as Mr Richard Smith and Mr Frank Keenan, all of whom have great expertise in this area. They sat down with members of this Government, members of the consumer affairs committee, and members of the Trade Practices Commission (TPC) as well as members of the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations (AFCO) and the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs. In fact, I suppose that anyone who was anyone in this field was at the meeting, trying to resolve many of the problems in the insurance industry.

There are problems, but when people come together, and when there is dialogue, many of the problems that do exist can be overcome. I want to place on the record my personal appreciation of the willingness of the Insurance Council of Australia (ICA) to work with others in the industry to resolve the problems that do exist. Surely one such problem is the issue of consumer credit insurance. It was the subject of a major study by the Financial Counsellors Association in Victoria. I notice that the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) is here. He would be well aware of that because of his special interest in consumer affairs. I refer to the role played by Colin Kent and others in bringing the attention of members of Parliament to the problems that exist in consumer credit insurance such as the high cost of premiums and the commissions paid to retailers, particularly in the second-hand car industry but in the broad motor vehicle industry as well. Concerns were expressed about the ignorance of consumers when they walk into a sale unconcerned about the sorts of premiums and commissions they are paying as long as, at the end of the day when they sign the document, they are up for a certain amount of money that they believe they can repay. There have been problems of high pressure tactics being used by some. Regrettably, a number-it is minute-have caused a dilemma for the total insurance industry. Of the 100 different insurance companies which are part of the ICA, it is regrettable that one or two, such as HFC Finance Services Ltd, cause major problems in terms of profile and public perception because of their high pressure tactics and attitude to get massive penetration within the consumer area.

We will not resolve those problems by legislation alone. We will resolve them only when industry sits around the table and talks through the sorts of solutions that are available. The industry argues, and I can understand it, that unless there is high penetration and a number of consumers form a very broad base, up goes the cost of individual premiums. I suppose it is like Medicare. If Medicare were available only to certain people, as the Opposition would argue, there would be a massive unit cost for those covered by Medicare. But if the cover can be broadened the overall cost per person, per unit, will be reduced.

I therefore understand some of this idea for high penetration. It is also argued that high penetration brings about efficiency, maintains costs and also maintains viability. However, there is some concern that if an industry does not have true competition it is the consumer who suffers. Concern is also expressed that where there is a close link between the retailer of consumer credit insurance and the wholesaler, true competition does not necessarily prevail.

Those are the sorts of issues which I suppose, in the past, would have been cast aside and members of Parliament would have had to stand up and criticise insurance companies. But I give some credit to people such as Mr Harold Levick, the President of ICA; Graeme Bond and Ray Willing-men who have sat down over a period and tried to find the solutions, who looked at the various models, understood that there was concern and realised that it is not just a matter of responding, when someone attacks the insurance industry, by trying to attack the Parliament and politicians. Those people were willing to sit down and come up with an approach. Whilst we have a long way to go in talking through a code of conduct, which has been the subject of long discussion for many months, we are getting there.

I think we need to say publicly that members of the insurance industry are not a group of ogres; they are not a group of people trying to rip off every consumer. Instead, they are a group of people who in many instances, representing their shareholders, are trying to provide a service. Again, it is regrettable that there are those in the industry who are out for the quick buck. Most of those companies-there are only a few-seem to be foreign-owned and foreign-based. They come to this country to ravage the market-place, to make the quickest profit that they possibly can.

One suggestion that has been put forward by the ICA, and which I think must be canvassed further, is for a code of conduct. Part of that code of conduct would be to have a cap on commissions. There are those who say that if we put a cap on commissions all that does is force everyone else in the industry to move towards the cap: if we set the commission at 25 or 35 per cent, everyone moves towards that 25 or 35 per cent. But it must be appreciated, from some of the current surveys, that the commissions are extremely high and in some instances are well over 35 per cent. At the same time, whilst we can argue about the cap on commissions, the real essence of success in the industry is when an appeals system works and is seen to be independent, instead of being one of Caesar until Caesar. As one who has worked in the consumer industry for a long time that seems to be one of the main criticisms about the insurance industry.

There are those who argue that the easiest way is to legislate, to set up the structure of an ombudsman to follow the British model. Others say that we need to look at the Singaporean model; that we should have an ombudsman-like committee made up of a representative from the insurance industry, someone from the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC), someone from the consumer affairs field and an independent chairman who could be a lawyer who is well versed in the insurance industry and particularly in contract law. But whatever happens we must end up with a system of appeal, a system whereby consumer complaints can be dealt with.

When I first took this issue on I believed that there were tens of thousands of complaints about the insurance industry. The facts do not establish that. If one looks at the Bureau of Consumer Affairs, not only federally but also on a State by State basis, one finds that one could limit the number to probably 2,000 at the very most. In fact, whilst the complaints received across Australia amount to almost 10,000 judging from the reports those that have been unresolved in recent times bring the figure back to about 1,300. When we weigh that against the number of contracts that are written and the number of people who have entered into policies we see that it is a minute amount. It does not matter to me whether it be 300 or 300,000; there has to be a proper appeal system if one has a complaint.

I am hoping that, as we continue to canvass this issue with those various players in the industry, we can come up with some model. The Trade Practices Commission is very keen to do this, as is the Insurance Commission. Honourable members may be aware that the Insurance Commission has taken upon itself a reference. It has to report back to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), I think by the end of this year and put forward some models as to the way in which we might resolve the complaint system problem.

Another issue is that of disclosure and transparency. I think consumers have a right to know the in-built costs in any premium that they are paying. Regrettably, this has not been the case in many instances in the insurance industry. So there is a need for greater disclosure. There is a need to know what sort of commissions are being paid, particularly to the retailers. I say that because the retailers have an incentive to get people locked into credit insurance. If that incentive is worth while in monetary terms-it could be worth far more than selling the car, I suppose, to stretch the limit a little-the retailers will try to get everybody into credit insurance. It is no wonder that some companies have gone for high penetration, paying high commission to those people who work in second-hand car dealing firms to try to get people locked into credit insurance policies. I am not sure that consumers always understand what they are getting into. I have had some examples presented to me where people might buy a car for $10,000 and the cost of the credit insurance is another $3,000 on top of that, and sometimes far more.

People have a right to know. They have a right to true competition. When they walk into a car yard and they are offered credit insurance, they ought to be given the opportunity to walk away, go out in the marketplace and find providers of credit insurance who will offer them a cheaper policy. As honourable members would understand, that is not always possible. Half the time, people who go to car dealers on a Saturday morning or a Saturday afternoon have spotted the car and tested it out mechanically, and that is all they are concerned about. They know that they can afford the $70 a week, the $240 a month, or whatever it is, and that is their main consideration. But we need to educate consumers more. We need to educate them as to their rights and their responsibilities.

I suppose we need to come up with some objectives. Whilst the Bill does not pertain to this, the Insurance Commission has a special interest in these issues. From talking to Mr Peter Beatham I am very much aware not only of his expertise but also of his special interest in this field. We need more informed consumers. Obviously we need an efficient and viable industry otherwise we will not have the insurance industry prevailing. We need the lowest possible cost to consumers. We need fairness in the commission system. We certainly need a true choice when it comes to the provision of insurance credit. We need limited controls-and I stress `limited controls'-over the marketplace because those controls ultimately result in cost to the consumers. Finally, we need a complaint resolution-type system that will bring justice to the consumer and to the insurance industry.

I have spoken to people in the general insurance industry in Queensland, whose concern is that too often they have to bring down a judgment on the side of the consumer because they are afraid not to. They are afraid that if they do not bring down that judgment they will be criticised as being the crooks and rorters in the system, so they tend to move towards the consumer's position irrespective of the validity of the claim made against them.

In recent times I have had a lot of confidence in the executive members of the ICA, the executive members of AFCO such as Robin Brown, and members of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, the Bureau of Consumer Affairs and the credit council group. I am confident that as these groups continue to work together we are going to solve many of the problems that exist. I would hope that more members of parliament will get involved in this area, because all of us have in our electorates people who have particular complaints. We need to bring down a model which will be in the best interests of everybody. As I said, we could follow the British model of using an ombudsman. We could come up with our own Australian model. But we have to keep in mind the costs of establishing such a complaint mechanism. We have to ensure that the industry is still given the incentives to continue to be the provider of general insurance, life insurance and particularly, in this instance, credit insurance.

I am extremely confident that, in view of the calibre of people involved in the industry-I mention John Tamblyn from the TPC, Darryl Maddern from the Bureau of Consumer Affairs and the people involved in AFCO, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and ICA-we can achieve our aims. But, if we do not resolve the problem, we will have to act in a legislative way. My final message to the House of Representatives this evening is that we have a special responsibility to ensure that the consumer is protected. I personally believe that we can do that with an industry-based scheme. But if we cannot get that cooperation and that consensus, we must go down the legislative path.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I would like to thank the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), and the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) for their contributions to the debate. I was disappointed with the contribution of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition which, like his contribution last evening, was mostly irrelevant to the matter before the House. The contribution of the honourable member for Capricornia was constructive and thoughtful. I would like to add that the insurance industry of Australia is increasingly looking to the insurance of our international trade. That is an area that it should properly aspire to. The development of industry in that area will provide considerable benefit to this country in the production of our invisibles.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, this legislation provides only for the recovery of the costs of supervision of the general life insurance industries. Its measures will also provide worthwhile increased protection for the insuring public and, consistent with the Government's broad approach to regulation, it will not impose undue burdens on the industries involved.

Two matters were raised by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Firstly, the Bill does not deal with the taxation of life offices or friendly societies. Secondly, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition raised the matter of the Western Australian State Government Insurance Commission. I just say for the record that the Constitution does not give scope for the Commonwealth to supervise the operations of State government insurance offices. I think that is very well known to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. As I said, most of his contribution was irrelevant to the legislation before the chamber. I welcome the support of the Opposition and I commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Peter Morris) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRITICALE LEVY BILL 1988[COGNATE BILLS:TRITICALE LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1988RURAL INDUSTRIES RESEARCH AMENDMENT BILL 1988WHEAT MARKETING AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 November, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill concurrently with the Triticale Levy Collection Bill, the Rural Industries Research Amendment Bill and the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill: There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill is the major of the four Bills which are before us tonight, but they are all connected with grain or rural research. All the Bills are supported by the Opposition. The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill implements those aspects of the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport which refer to grain handling and storage and which are implementable at Federal level. The Royal Commission made three sets of specific recommendations-one concerning storage and handling, one concerning land transport and a third concerning ports and shipping. This legislation alters the requirements of the Australian Wheat Board by removing the sole receiver requirement for the Board in dealing with wheat storage in each of the States-that is, it removes the State bulk handling monopoly for the storage of wheat relating to the Wheat Board in each State, Secondly, it requires the Australian Wheat Board to maximise net returns to growers and, thirdly, it requires the Board to disaggregate costs.

SPEECH.PARA: All these proposals have the strong support of the Government-obviously, as it is its legislation-and equally of the Grains Council of Australia, the Australian Wheat Board and the Federal coalition. The reactions of the State governments and the State bulk handling authorities vary from hostility to acceptance. Some are concerned about the effect that this legislation will have on the operations of the State bulk handling authorities and some are concerned as to what it will mean for the profitability of the State rail monopolies and also the potential weakening of the power of the States through the State rail monopolies to direct grain to certain ports. However, I point out that the States continue to have constitutional responsibility over the bulk handling monopolies although that could be contestable, using the foreign affairs or export power in relation to the Wheat Board and the movement of grain for export.

In spite of the reactions, which have varied, the response by the bulk handling authorities has been very good. For the harvest that is under way in Queensland and northern New South Wales we already have in place all those reforms that can be implemented by this legislation. These were negotiated in advance by the Wheat Board, the Grains Council and the State bulk handling authorities and they have been achieved in a remarkably short time. This is a great achievement and those bodies should be congratulated.

What is being implemented in practice this season as a result of this legislation? First of all, with storage and handling, the statutory charges have been replaced with actual costs or charges and the deductions of those charges will be made at the time they are incurred-that is, disaggregation of costs. Secondly, there will be a warehousing or storage facility provided for wheat growers. They will have possibly until next July to make up their minds when they store the wheat in the approved storage facility whether they sell it for cash, particularly for domestic stock feed through the Wheat Board, put it into the pooling system or use it on a grower-to-buyer arrangement which itself is improved by the flexibility of these new provisions. The legislation also allows the Wheat Board to return to the domestic stock feed market which it has been shut out of for several years. One million tonnes of wheat has been sold for that purpose. Because of the flexible storage and handling and better cash payment arrangements, the Wheat Board can once again become a force in the domestic stock feed markets, and it is already. In Queensland it has lifted the price by at least $5 a tonne compared with what was being offered by the traders. It also puts a floor into that market.

Months ago the coalition shadow Ministry supported in principle these proposals for more flexible marketing, storage and handling arrangements and for the Wheat Board to retain it export monopoly. I am pleased that the Government at least appears to be accepting the commonsense of the export monopoly by the Wheat Board and the practicality of it by backing off its original proposal to remove the Wheat Board's export monopoly.

What we have seen so far is fine. It is all positive and remarkably quick action by the wheat industry and those organisations involved with it. But that is only one-third of the Royal Commission's recommendations. The other two-thirds relate to transport and ports and shipping. In fact, the major part of the $10 per tonne saving that the McColl Royal Commission claimed could be made by the implementation of its recommendations comes from surface transport and competition at that level and not from grain handling and storage. So once again we see the double standard of this Government. When a problem relates to farmers, to rural people, action is required instantly, but when it relates to the other sectors of this society there is a very long timetable and sometimes a never-never timetable.

I want to support the point I am making by referring to the speech by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in Ballarat during the last week of the election campaign in July last year. He repeated the comments he made in Ballarat in his speech to the Business Council of Australia on 11 October this year. He indicated that micro-reform of the economy would be the chief priority of this Government. He listed grain handling, transport, the two airlines agreement, the waterfront and coastal shipping as those areas of micro-reform. What is the Government's record so far? We know what it is with grain handling. It is abrupt action. In spite of problems and difficulties for those State bulk handling authorities and for the growers, whether directly as growers or as shareholders or users of the bulk handling authorities, everything is in place in remarkably short time for this harvest. But after that, the achievement record of this Government shows very little. Very little has been achieved for transport, nothing for the airlines, nothing for the waterfront and nothing for coastal shipping.

In regard to surface transport, the Royal Commission indicated that the main savings to growers could come from competition between road and rail for the transport of wheat. With the exception of South Australia, which has had no restrictions on competition-it has been easy for South Australia, because it does not own the State railways, the Commonwealth owns them-and I understand now New South Wales, there are very severe road restrictions in all of the wheat growing States because the State governments rely on the controlled transport of grain to prop up their inefficient railways. In New South Wales and Victoria alone the State railways incur deficits each year of about $1 billion in each State. One of the few profitable sections of those State railways is the transport of grain. In Victoria it is estimated that there is a cost recovery on grain transport of 110 or 120 per cent. Of course, they are also able to control the port destination.

TALK.START.PARA: —Such as Geelong.
—Yes, Geelong versus Port Kembla or Brisbane versus Newcastle-or South Australia versus Victoria, for that matter.
—Southern Riverina wheat to Geelong.
—No, Portland.

—I acknowledged all of those points made by my colleagues. For road transport to be competitive, the restrictions on the limits of road transport, not only for contractors but also for growers, to carry grain have to be lifted, that is, up to the 42.5 tonne maximum limit for ordinary semi-trailers and the introduction of B-doubles in a more general form, because two B-doubles will carry the same as three maximum weight semitrailers and do less road damage. This can be done by the Federal Government either through Federal interstate registrations or, as the Grains Council of Australia and the Business Council of Australia have recommended, through the introduction of Federal international registrations, once again using the export power. Progress has been made with the 42.5 tonne limit but I understand that, instead of the Federal Government unilaterally allowing Federal interstate B-double registrations so that they can take on State railways, there are negotiations taking place with the States.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again we see the double standard-introduce it to expose the farmers, the wheat growers, but, when it comes to things that would help them in the other related industries, do not introduce it abruptly but discuss, negotiate and take years to achieve it. Of course, if there is to be more use of road transport, there will be some damage to roads, but, as McColl was suggesting, instead of putting more finance into road construction and maintenance there has been a dramatic reduction by this Government; and that continues even under the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill, which was debated earlier today. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) referred in his speech to the recommendation of the Royal Commission for Australian National to remove the $2.50 per tonne levy when wheat is transported by road in South Australia. I certainly want confirmation that that has happened, or is happening and is not just being promised, because the South Australian harvest is fast approaching.

What about the waterfront? Absolutely nothing has been done. We can go back to the Webber task force of 1984, the first of the so-called reform committees. Four years later there is no progress whatsoever. The Inter-State Commission has released its preliminary report, and it is the third body to have investigated the waterfront in the last four years. A symposium was arranged to discuss that matter, and even some of the major employers boycotted it. How about the Government taking some action on the waterfront similar to that which it has taken in rural areas, whether in relation to sugar and the embargo, or the wheat growers--

TALK.START.PARA: —Let's have a bit of adjustment on the waterfront.

—That is right. Four years have been wasted; nothing whatsoever has been achieved. The same action should be taken by the Government in relation to the waterfront as it has taken in the rural sector, which it has quite often exposed to corrupt world trading practices.
—The industry sector has to adjust to the problems the unions have caused.

—My colleague the honourable member for Gwydir will be very interested in this. The Prime Minister indicated there would be micro-reform in the two airlines agreement. Three years' notice was given for the termination of that agreement, and this Government even wasted nine months before it actually made that decision.
—Your Government put the three years into it--

—But this Government supported it, and it also wasted nine months before it even made the decision. I would keep quiet if I were the Minister, unless he is prepared to take similar action in those related industries that the Prime Minister talked about. I acknowledge that there has been some progress in coastal shipping, and I acknowledge that the parties to coastal shipping are willing to talk and introduce further reform. But it is a painfully slow timetable and they want some Government cash in there as well. Rural people are aware of this Government's double standard: that their costs are loaded and that they are exposed to world risks while all of these related measures that would assist them to be profitably competitive are on the never-never.

SPEECH.PARA: I now move to the Triticale Levy Bill and related Bills. The triticale industry is a developing grain producing industry in this country. Triticale is a cross of wheat and rye and can be grown in harsher or more marginal areas than wheat can be grown in. Until now there has been a voluntary levy arrangement, which is to the credit of those growers. This is a legislative levy under the special rural research fund arrangements, the dollar for dollar matching system which is part of the rural industry research funds. I understand that it will raise $160,000 from growers and the same amount from the Government for this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity manufacturing industry did not do the same.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia needs no assistance from those sitting on the back benches.

—I was coming to that. Associated with it is the Rural Industries Research Amendment Bill which corrects some of the anomalies and also introduces the user pays system in the sense that the costs of the administration are deducted from the levy. The Opposition parties support both pieces of legislation as well as commending the triticale growers.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I want to make is that which the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) made: that is, the remarkable way in which the farmers of this country contribute to research. They contribute far more to research than any other sector of our society. That is why they remain the most efficient. Although there has been an increase of the Government's commitment, through the rural industry research funds, because the farmers themselves are prepared to put in more on the dollar for dollar arrangement, that is no substitute for the dramatic reduction in research funds, particularly to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, which has now suffered a reduction of over 30 per cent under this Government. We now have a badly skewed balance on research because of the greater amount of money going into the rural industry research fund arrangements with not an adequate amount going into CSIRO and the more basic research.

I conclude by saying that the coalition supports the legislation but criticises the Government for its double standards and its failure to maintain an adequate contribution to the research requirements of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to support this legislation and the comments made by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd). The Australian Wheat Board (AWB), as we know, is a marketing cooperative. Its only goal is to serve the Australian wheat growers. The main functions of the Wheat Board are to market and control marketing of Australian wheat; to encourage and promote the use and sale of Australian wheat; and to consult, cooperate and enter into agreements with authorised receivers. The Australian market is without doubt one of the most important and largest to the Wheat Board, with sales in 1986-87 totalling 1.6 million tonnes. Total domestic sales in that period were worth $326m. Export sales through the Wheat Board were worth $1,982m. Export sales of wheat continue to be affected by the subsidies of European Economic Community countries. In 1986-87 some of Australia's markets were lost.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Wheat Board has just released its latest harvest forecast at 13.9 million tonnes-some 400,000 tonnes and $82m less than previously anticipated. Wheat prices today remain at close to their highest levels on record in Australian dollar terms, with the Wheat Board quoting Australian standard white at $US170 as of yesterday. The importance of the industry can be seen from these figures. This cannot be overemphasised.

The current debate before the Parliament on the proposed restructuring of wheat marketing is of great significance to this large and important industry. The McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport was formed with separate terms of reference issued by the Commonwealth and the States to report on the nature of the most efficient and cost-effective system for meeting Australia's future grain distribution needs and to make recommendations to implement such a system. The final report of this Royal Commission has made a number of recommendations for change. The Commission believes that the changes which affect the responsibility of marketing boards concerning the minimisation of storage, handling and transport costs, the ability to appoint more than one licensed receiver, and the disaggregation of the costs of port services and sea transport, should be implemented immediately.

There are a number of areas in which the present transport and handling system does not provide maximum benefits to producers. McColl concluded that up to $10 per tonne in savings could be achieved by a more flexible and competitive system of handling, storage and transport; in fact, a possible annual benefit across Australia of $100m could be achieved. It should be noted, however-and this was emphasised by the Deputy Leader of our Party-that the Royal Commission kept out of the marketing area by intent, but seemed to avoid the industrial issues, I assume, because of their difficulty and potential for controversy. This is to be regretted, as industrial practices and restrictive working arrangements have cost the Australian wheat grower dearly over the past few years.

I turn to the main thrust of the legislation, which I fully support and which has the support of the Australian Wheat Board and the Grains Council of Australia. The Bill provides for the AWB to enter into contracts for services related to grain storage and transport and includes all bodies corporate with whom the AWB has a contract for wheat receival. No longer will the AWB be disallowed from dealing with bodies other than the sole receiver authorised in each State. The Board will be able to contract with whoever will provide the best returns for growers. The Board must also provide disaggregated charges for these services in its accounts to growers to the extent that this is possible and does not incur significant net additional costs. Growers will therefore be more aware of the costs associated with each individual service employed to receive, handle and transport their grain and will be in a better position to make choices. Such changes will allow the AWB more flexibility, a capacity to exercise choice between various receivers, the removal of sole receiver rights, the commercialisation of bulk handling authorities, and it will bring them under the Trade Practices Act.

While this Bill does not have the authority to implement recommendations of the Royal Commission on other aspects of our transport system, I place the Government and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) on notice that this legislation will not have full impact if action is not taken to provide adequate funding for local roads or to attack the abuses and corruption of our ports and shipping. Rural people and primary producers in particular have borne the full brunt of cost cutting, restructuring and the harsh winds of corrupt markets over the last few years, and they have had enough.

This issue is most vital. It affects the very heart and soul of the wheat growing industry in Australia, particularly and specifically the Mallee and Wimmera regions of my electorate. Wheat growers have been plundered by the greed of governments through excessive rail costs that have not been imposed on urban transport users. They have been plundered by the taxes imposed on growers' facilities. It is a crime for which any commercial company ought to be thrown in gaol, particularly the taxes imposed on our handling authorities in Victoria by the Victorian Government. We have seen inefficiencies in handling and storage, particularly on wharves and, as I have already mentioned, restrictive work practices and in some cases industrial blackmail. State and Federal governments are therefore on notice that the McColl report's recommendations are a stark reminder of the rorts and rip-offs that have brought the most convenient, extensive and efficient handling system into disrepute and decay.

Compounding this issue have been the worst economic conditions in the history of our economic development. Low commodity prices and corrupt world trading conditions are out of Australia's control, but those that are within our control include high fuel prices and social policies such as the assets test discrimination which requires the asset of land to earn income. This Bill is fully supported by the Opposition. It is one step forward. Unfortunately, if the other recommendations of McColl are not implemented, it will be two steps backwards.

I refer very briefly to other matters in this cognate debate, particularly the Triticale Levy Bill. This legislation provides for the imposition and collection of a levy on growers of triticale to finance research. It is similar to many other research Acts that are already in operation for other rural industries, such as grain legumes, cotton and sugar. It allows for a levy of $1 per tonne to be applied, with provision for the rate to be varied to a maximum of $2.

As my Deputy Leader, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has already mentioned, rural industries participate fully and cooperate under these research Acts in order to assist both their own industries and the general economy of Australia. It is therefore appalling to me that our major research organisation, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, has seen a 32 per cent cut from its last five budgets. We know that rural industries fund 22 per cent of its overall research effort and it has, unfortunately, been subsidising through this research into manufacturing industry over the years. Yet in the CSIRO we see the Division of Plant Industry research capacity has been cut by 33 per cent. The Division of Entomology has had a loss of some 20 scientific staff this year and there have been some cuts in the Division of Animal Production of 50 per cent over the last six years. Rural industry is worth $22 billion to this country and it is worth $15 billion in exports. It is vital to Australia's future. Because of what has happened in the area of scientific research over the last few years in this country there will be serious consequences. I support this legislation. I believe that it will bring long term benefits to the Australian grain industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —More flexibility.

—I hope that it also brings more flexibility from the Government particularly in the transport sector. It should be recognised that grain should have more flexibility on its routes to the various ports particularly from southern New South Wales, Riverina to Geelong and in my area from Victoria into the port of Portland. I support the legislation and I sincerely hope that the sort of legislation that we see here tonight is also brought forward in the area of transport in the very short term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in this cognate debate I must comment that in listening to the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) one would think that it is all doom and gloom. That is not the case and there is probably a revitalised interest in farming and I think farmers have probably got more confidence than they have had for a long time. This is largely due to the excellent season and also I believe due to the actions taken by this Government. Both the honourable member for Mallee and the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) lamented the lack of action on behalf of this Government. This is a joke. What did these people do when they were in power? They did nothing, nothing at all. When in government they had the power to do it and they did not act.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address my remarks initially to the Triticale Levy Bill. I think that this is a very sensible piece of legislation. It will set up a fund for research into triticale. I think there is a lot of potential there, and it will be funded on an equal basis by the Commonwealth up to a value of 0.5 per cent of the crop. Many people believe that triticale is a port in Sri Lanka; it is actually a grain cross between rye and wheat, a fertile hybrid, and it is very useful particularly in the chicken feed industry because of its higher digestibility. It is also very useful in my State of Western Australia which is the biggest wheat growing State in the Commonwealth. The varieties used there mainly are, kooyong, triala and currency, all of which I understand are South Australian varieties. There is a very good reason for doing research to find types of triticale which will grow even better on the acid sand plains that exist in Western Australia in quite large areas. It has the added value that it grows on fragile sands and I believe has a part to play in rehabilitation in those areas that have perhaps been overcropped before or do not stand up too much chemical cropping. As I said earlier, I think that this is a very commendable move. For this reason I know that it has the complete support of the Opposition, perhaps a little churlishly given.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—I think that is quite fair, given the constant criticism by those opposite. I now turn to the wheat marketing aspects of this Bill. I strongly support the direction of this Bill and support entirely what it endeavours to do. Unlike the Opposition, however, I have great reservations about the deregulation of the domestic market. This was not mentioned by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take issue with a few things that were said. For instance, we heard the great cry that we must see more road transport of wheat. The Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport itself pointed out that there was a massive subsidy by the taxpayer of the levy haulage of grain by road. From memory, it estimated that the subsidy was something like $33,000 per eight-wheeled truck. It is a significant cost. If we are to talk about costs we have to talk about real costs. Somebody has to end up paying. That is what honourable members opposite seem to forget. They lament that the Government is seeking to implement these changes by negotiation. They should bear in mind that most grain is carted over local roads. The Government has increased funding for local roads. But no organisation, no government could increase funds to counter the degradation of those roads by heavy trucks. The wear is simply enormous. I believe that we must look at the real costs of that haulage. It may be that with the real cost to society grain haulage is still cheaper by rail.

When we look at raid costs we see Opposition members lambasting the Government. They imply, of course, that the Federal Government controls rail freight but, of course, the State governments do so. It is interesting to know that the worst offenders are in eastern Australia where the inefficient railways are. Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria have all had their share of Liberal governments which have maintained extortionate rates for the haulage of wheat. In Western Australia, on the other hand, where we have arguably the most efficient rail system in the world, the railway has managed to keep down the cost of grain haulage and is very competitive against road transport. There has probably been a greater measure of deregulation in Western Australia than in any State except South Australia. I think it was the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) who pointed out that South Australia no longer owns railways and therefore no longer has to worry about these issues. It is commendable that the Western Australian railway, Westrail, has managed to keep down its haulage costs on grain. In fact, for two years it has actually reduced the costs. Credit should be given there.

Other aspects of this Bill are very important. Opposition members have alluded to the chaos on the water front. This clearly is a problem that the Government has to face. I am sure this Government will not run away from those problems as the previous did.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—The honourable member for Wannon says, `Come on' but the Opposition was in government for a long time and it did nothing. It took no action whatsoever. This Government will endeavour to take action. We are already starting to see a shift in attitudes. For instance, the Seamen's Union of Australia is probably more amenable to change and increases in efficiency than it has ever been in its whole existence. It is a trend that I hope continues. I agree that waterfront inefficiencies are there and they have to be tackled. But to lambast this Government for failing to act when the Opposition had so much opportunity itself is manifestly unfair. It will be seen as unfair and hypocritical by the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the initiatives benefit the Australian Wheat Board, its ability to offer new services and its ability to choose who will receive and handle its grain. They are initiatives that are long overdue. I do not think it will make much difference in Western Australia which has the facilities and where bulk handling has a good record. I do not expect to see many changes there. But it has certainly served notice on the various handling authorities that there will be competition and already we have seen a dramatic improvement in efficiency and a willingness to explore new ideas in this regard.

I believe the overwhelming bulk of the savings identified by the Royal Commission can be achieved without deregulating domestic wheat marketing. It is an area that concerns me greatly. I would like to be sure, before I support that proposal, that the benefits will flow to growers. At the moment, I am certainly not convinced of that. It is my view that if these benefits cannot be identified, they probably do not exist. I would like to spend more time on this legislation but with the agreed allotted time of 10 minutes I have probably covered all the ground I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the Triticale Levy Bill, the Triticale Levy Collection Bill, the Rural Industries Research Amendment Bill and the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill I would like to start by taking up a few points mentioned by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). I thought it was amazing that he would criticise the previous speaker, the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), when he was not even in the House to listen to him. He then went on to say how the Government had increased funding for local roads. We debated in the House earlier today the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill, which pointed out very clearly how the Government has cut funding for roads. The honourable member also accused the previous coalition Government of doing nothing to try to reduce the waterfront costs. The first thing I point out to the honourable member is that the present Government has been in office now for 5 1/2 years and has done nothing. On the other hand, the previous Government set about reducing the manning levels on the waterfront. It is my understanding that under the previous Government the number of waterside workers was reduced from 23,000 to about 5,000. Therefore, to say that that Government did nothing shows an extraordinary amount of ignorance. Furthermore, that Government, to its very great cost, had the courage to institute the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union to look into some of the worst practices one could ever see when it comes to dishonesty on the waterfront. To say that the previous Government did nothing I think shows sheer, utter ignorance.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to address a few points in regard to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill. As has been mentioned by previous speakers, this Bill will, in fact, give the Australian Wheat Board the opportunity to allow growers to benefit from the Board no longer having to have a sole receiver in each State. Of course, this will have the advantage of giving the growers the chance to see what their real costs are because these will be disaggregated. Also there will be options for growers in regard to warehousing. For those growers who want to take advantage of this it will allow them to store things such as feed wheat and to market their wheat to their best advantage. There will also be other opportunities for introducing special segregations for the domestic market. Clearly, the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport highlighted that there are indeed substantial savings available for wheat growers in the storage, handling and transport area. Obviously, this legislation is a first step. We wish that the Government could move a bit faster on this, but at least it has started to move in the storage area.

The thing that concerns me is whether the Government will be prepared to take the next step in the transport area. One of the reasons I raise that point is that earlier this year the Australian Railways Union in its re-election manifesto was very quick to boast:
The ARU leads the way in the fight to keep Grain Regulated to Rail in this state of Victoria.

When there is something like $10 a tonne riding on various excess costs it is clear that rail is one of those significant factors. The other factor that has been alluded to by other members is, of course, the ports. As I have already mentioned earlier in response to some of the comments of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, I am very concerned that the Government will not have the strength or the determination to act on the ports. Some of the rorts in the ports and in the railways really have to be seen to be believed.

I think it is worth reminding honourable members of some of the things that have been going on. When we look at, say, the waterfront, we find that over-regulated, union-controlled coastal shipping and waterfronts are costing dearly. Of course, the grain industry is just one industry that is paying a very high price for this. In fact, research by the McColl Royal Commission showed that shore based costs associated with the export of grain amount to about $1 billion annually or nearly $60 a tonne. That is equivalent to around 36 per cent of the f.o.b. value of wheat. As the McColl Royal Commission has pointed out, at least $3.50 a tonne could be saved by abolishing restrictive work practices and putting an end to the disputes that have been going on at the waterfront. We are often reminded of the stupidity which went on in New South Wales a couple of years ago and which cost grain growers in that State, and to a lesser extent in other States, at least $200m-in fact, more than the total amount of annual savings that the McColl Royal Commission outlined.

As ACIL pointed out in its submission to the Royal Commission, some of the excessive costs of restrictive practices have to be seen to be believed. ACIL outlined just a few, which I will describe to honourable members tonight. The State Rail Authority of New South Wales still changes the crews of its modern diesel electric locomotives at the same times and places as it did for its long gone steam engines; that is, at the points of taking on coal and water. The result is an unnecessary reduction in the effective operational hours of trains and a corresponding loss of productivity. It sounds almost unbelievable, but that is the sort of thing that has been going on, not only in New South Wales but also in other States. As ACIL pointed out, train crews are paid for a seven-hour shift, even if they have to work only one to two hours. There is also the enormous cost of ferrying them around the country in taxis. Again, that does not occur only in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't even have alarm clocks to wake up with. They have to be woken up.

—That is right. On occasions cheaper and more flexible private sector port terminal and loading facilities have been opposed because they have conflicted with the entrenched position or future plans of the railways or the bulk handling authorities. When the continuous running of grain loading facilities, offsetting the problems of staggered working hours-which is a story in itself-was introduced in Sydney in May 1986, productivity rose by a staggering 35 per cent, the gain being equivalent to Newcastle's traditional grain shipments. However, because it reduced the overtime worked, the unions kicked up a fuss and the policy was discontinued after only two months.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of these things are so outrageous they are almost impossible to believe, but they are the sorts of things that have been going on. They are the sorts of things that the Royal Commission was alluding to when it said that savings would be available if some of the restrictive work practices were removed, together with the disaggregation of costs and the removal of sole receiver rights for storage. We have now to see whether the sole transport rights that are still available in a number of States are removed by the Government.

The Government should do a little more than just talk about how it is going to do something to clean up the waterfront. We have seen the Government bring out report after report. In fact, there has been about one a year for every year of this Government. Each report tells us the same thing. Each time the answer is, `We had better have another report because we do not know what to do'.

Another point that has been raised by a couple of honourable members tonight is funding for research. Clearly, the primary industry sector can be proud of its efforts in research. This Government certainly has been prepared to support the rural industry research funds. However, I cannot say the same for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. For five years in a row its funding has been cut. Each year the Government has ignored the pleas of the Opposition, when we have pointed out the damage the cuts would do, not only to our research effort but also to long term increases in productivity, that it do something positive to improve our export performance in areas other than primary industries. Yet, despite this, the Government has continued to ignore our pleas until now-just this year-when the pressure has finally built up. What has the Government done? It has announced another inquiry. A committee will consider the matter. It has taken five years to reach this point and now we are going to have another inquiry. Apparently, the Yes, Minister syndrome is alive and well.
