I conclude by saying that we support the Bills. I hope that the changes in the Wheat Marketing Act will bring substantial savings to growers. These savings are long overdue. Clearly, the growers have been paying far too much of the costs associated with getting their crop onto the ships. This one step is welcome, but there are many more steps to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in speaking to the Triticale Levy Bill, the Triticale Levy Collection Bill, the Rural Industries Research Amendment Bill and the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill. I am pleased to see the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) at the table. Often when we speak to Bills such as these we do not have the Minister present. It is good that at least the Minister has been prepared to give up his time to be here tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all I should like to express my amazement at some of the speakers on the Labor side who have spoken in the debate this afternoon on the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill. We have heard some nonsense from them. The report of the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport recommended that there be a freeing up of the grain industry, yet the Labor Government has seen fit not only to reduce spending on local roads throughout Australia and the roads we use to cart grain to our rail heads or to port, but also there has been a massive increase in fuel taxes in that time. People on the Government side conveniently forget that the Government has introduced the indexation of fuel excise, and there have been increases of billions of dollars coming into Consolidated Revenue from the road users of this nation. Yet tonight we are asking the grain growers of Australia to look to other traders in the market, to free up the system and to use our road system more.

I put it to the Minister that unless his Government and Cabinet are prepared to allocate more funds to roads, the whole system will collapse under the weight of tonnes of grain moving across our now inadequate road system, the maintenance of which is falling way behind. The Minister need only travel across the electorates of Mallee and Maranoa to see what is happening. In addition, all sorts of cuts have been made to the rural industries across Australia, particularly the wheat industry and people growing triticale. There have been massive cuts in support for primary industry. It is amazing to think that primary industry is one of the few industries that contributes dollar for dollar to research, and the Rural Industries Research Amendment Bill deals with research.

There has been a $37m cut in the superphosphate subsidy; a $50m cut in road funding; a $190m cut in the depreciation allowances; a $124m increase in levies and charges; a 4.5 per cent increase in fuel excise; a $5.4m cut in assistance for isolated children, and so it goes on and on. There has also been the introduction of assets testing in respect of isolated children. Wheat farmers have to send their children to boarding school in many instances. There has been an 8.7 per cent cut in finance to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation which is dealt with in the Rural Industries Research Amendment Bill. I have two other pages of examples to refer to. Since 1972 when the Labor Government came to office there has been a massive removal of up to $1 billion from various aspects of primary industry and wheat growing across the nation. Yet Government members continue to crow and think we are doing better than ever, but we are not. The industry needs support and encouragement, particularly in the taxation area, to encourage it to invest and produce.

While all these things have been going on we have seen a massive increase in our debt structure and a massive fall in our balance of payments; we are running at $1 billion a month in debt. The only people who are really trying to get us out of that problem are those in the farming industry. If it were not for the increase in the price of wheat, wool and beef, we would be in severe financial difficulty in this nation; so we must thank the farmers once again. Australia still rides on the sheep's back, and that situation is gong to continue. It is the job of those of us who represent rural electorates to support rural industry.

The Triticale Levy Bill has been introduced. Triticale is a cross-breeding of barley and rye, and for the first time the growers of this grain have asked the Government to set up a research regime to which the three cognate Bills make it compulsory for farmers growing this grain to contribute. The Government's intention is to pick up $160,000 to be used in research. We do not oppose the Bill.

Those of us in primary industry are prepared to contribute to research. The government puts up a dollar and we put up a dollar, and get on and do the job. We hope that at the end of the day we will see some improvement. That is the only way we can continue to keep ahead of the rest of the world. We have to be efficient and we have to earn the export dollars that are so badly needed to help the Treasurer (Mr Keating) put his Budget in place. The initial levy rate will be set at $1 a tonne, with provision for the rate to be varied to a maximum of $2 a tonne. In other words, the levy is in place at $1 to start with and it can be increased to $2 without the need to introduce a Bill for a $50 increase. That is something that has happened in most of the research Bills and it saves a lot of work within the Department and within the Parliament. We support that concept, provided the Government does not take the opportunity to increase levies at too fast a rate.

There are two Bills associated with the main Bill, the Triticale Levy Bill, which sets up the regime, and the Triticale Levy Collection Bill, which strikes the rate for the research levy on the industry. One of the other Bills is the Rural Industries Research Amendment Bill. The Government cut $8.7m from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's allocation in the last Budget and we have heard all sorts of screams coming from that organisation. At a time when emphasis needs to be placed on research in rural industries we seem to have a push towards high-tech industries. I do not know what they have come up with of late. Barry has been in here pulling a few things out of his pocket, but nothing much has happened to help the balance of payments.

The people who have been helping, the balance of payments are the farmers, but all we have copped is a kick in the guts and a decrease in the amount of money the Government is prepared to put up. I remind the House again that while farmers put up their dollar for dollar share, the great CSIRO, which is now being run by an ex-Premier of New South Wales, is being ripped apart. Every scientist working in that area will vouch for that. The CSIRO is no longer the world leader in research into primary industries, as it used to be. It was set up and financed and run exceptionally well under various heads, but now it is falling away and is attempting to concentrate on other areas of industry-secondary industry, if you like. Primary industry is being affected by the lack of research. The CSIRO has been at the cutting edge of all sorts of new fly sprays, new drenches, new everything, but this Government does not seem to wish to support it as previous governments used to. I think that is very poor.
The explanatory notes on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill state:
The proposed amendments will provide for the Australian Wheat Board to enter into contracts for the provision of grain storage, handling, carriage and port services.

This is part of the McColl report-the first part that the Government has introduced. The Minister is suggesting all sorts of radical changes in the wheat industry. We have had rallies across the country, some of which the Minister has attended. At some he has been howled down and at others he has been supported. Basically, the wheat growers of this nation have told the Minister in no uncertain terms that they do not support the concept he is putting forward. He has already backed off on the export of feed grains. He was going to let Elders-IXL and other big companies get involved in feed grain export, but he has backed off that concept and has allowed the Australian Wheat Board to remain the sole exporter of all grains. I think that is a good thing. The Board has been set up for many years and does a very efficient and good job.

My main purpose tonight is to point out to the Minister the problems that the Queensland grain industry has with this legislation. As he knows, some years ago the State Wheat Board, which is the agent of the Australian Wheat Board, appointed Bulk Grains Queensland as its agent. The growers, who own Bulk Grains Queensland, have a through put with that organisation of about 2.5 million tonnes. The interest and redemption costs about $8 a tonne. The interest and redemption of the $80m which they have borrowed is now $18m a year. This is the problem with the industry in Queensland. The Queensland Government is prepared to prepare separate legislation to appoint the Wheat Board as the sole handler of wheat in Queensland and to appoint the Australian Wheat Board as the agent to export. This is the only way that we can see around this piece of legislation.

I remind the House that it is the growers that own the wheat boards across this nation; it is not some bogey in the Government or any other person. The grain growers are levied each year. When they deliver their grain there is a storage levy. They contribute and collect millions of dollars that are reinvested into storage facilities across the nation. This has been done in Queensland. They have had to build new port sites. They have set out to reorganise the industry and have borrowed a lot of money in doing so. They are $80m in debt. This Labor Government turns around and says to them, `Well, we are going to put some more players in the market for you. We are going to level off a few wheat fields and give you a bit of competition'. That would be all very well it we did not owe the sort of money that we owe and if we had not spent the money previously to try to increase the efficiency of our industry.

We now find that we have an $18m interest and redemption payment per year. We cannot afford to lose a grain of wheat, sorghum, triticale, barley, oats or whatever it is that is put through Bulk Grains because Bulk Grains handles all grains in Queensland that come through the system. Some grains are still traded privately-there always has been and there always will be-but we cannot support the concept of allowing the Australian Wheat Board and the Australian Government, the Labor Government, to foist upon Bulk Grains Queensland and, indirectly, the Wheat Board this sort of legislation. Fortunately, in Queensland we have the National Party in Government. We are not going to accept the sort of suggestion that is on board in this piece of legislation.

The other thing we must remember is that the more we force people away from the existing arrangements which have been set up-and I agree that there are some inefficiencies-the dearer the system becomes for those who stay in it. That is the other problem we have. We will find that, instead of paying $8 a tonne to move grain, growers will be will be paying $10 and $12 a tonne to move the same tonne of wheat. I would like to impress very much upon the Minister that we in Queensland are finding it practically impossible to live with this legislation. It is the intention of Bulk Grains and the State Wheat Board not to allow any other agencies to receive the grain that is produced in our State, because we have an established responsibility to Bulk Grains and we have to pay off the $80m, debt before we can contemplate any other agents coming into the market.

I have much pleasure in speaking to these Bills. My brother, Brian Cameron, is a member of the State Wheat Board in Queensland and Bulk Grains. I have spoken with Don McKechnie, who is the Chairman of the Queensland Grain Growers Association, and with Don Christmas, who heads the Queensland Grain Growers Executive. I have also spoken with many members of the industry and those in my electorate. I represent practically every wheat grower in Queensland, because Maranoa covers the whole of the Darling Downs and central Queensland where the high protein quality grains are grown and we cannot accept the proposal put forward in the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer briefly to the new proposal in the Triticale Levy Bill 1988 to establish a triticale levy for research purposes. This represents, of course, as does the whole ambit of the research levies, a combination in the interest of the grower and user, and I believe this is an admirable move in an evolving smaller grain industry. It is aimed, as indeed research is, to increase the profit of the grower and the quality of the goods put to good use in processing by the user. Achieving the profit for the grower and the quality for the user requires a matching of the productive capacity of the land with the correct plant variety, and research in grains continues a long process which began with selection and then evolved into breeding, and it is a good thing that the support of the research has been extended into the triticale grain industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It comes, of course, with fairly draconian measures to support a levy, as all levies must be so supported in law. However, we know that other industries have shown quite clearly the value of research, and as we look at the wheat varieties and barley varieties today we are grateful for the input of research scientists and the previous support given by the industry and the Government in those areas.

I am particularly interested in the triticale, not that my State is a large grower by national standards. Figures I have show that South Australia produces only 7 per cent of the triticale in Australia. However, notable research has been conducted at the Waite Agricultural Research Institute. I have been contacted from time to time by those involved with that research. Dr Kath Cooper is a research fellow at the Waite Agricultural Research Institute. She is responsible for the national triticale breeding program and has been working on the program for six years. She works under the supervision of Professor D. Marshall, who is professor of agronomy and project chief investigator.

In 1982 the Reserve Bank of Australia funded a program for the development of a drought resistant triticale. The funding terminated in 1985 but the work continued under the Australian special rural research fund. In 1984 a new stem rust strain affected all but one of the triticale cultivars. This meant that the selection of a rust resistant strain became a high priority. The Waite breeding program became a vital source of disease free material for Australian triticale programs. There have been regular dispatches of cultivars from the Waite to other projects since 1986.

The Waite triticale program has continued to expand, and the emphasis was changing to cultivars for specific problem areas. In 1987 the most advanced generation yield data indicated an advantage over traditional cereals on soils deficient in zinc and manganese, infected with cereal cyst nematodes and those subject to waterlogging and toxic with boron. The best performing lines from 1987-88 were advanced to trials for 1988-89. It was anticipated this year that two more seasons would lead to new triticale cultivars adapted to specific environments. However, in April 1988 the Australian Special Rural Research Council conducted an inquiry into the funding of triticale research and found that the industry had developed to the point where it could reasonably be expected to contribute significantly to funding its own research. No funds were approved for continuation of the Waite program and no funds were approved for any triticale research in Australia.

Dr Cooper's work is of the highest scientific quality, and she was given a grant of $20,000 to close down the program over a six-month period, which was called a final `rationalisation'. The news, however, of the proposed introduction of the levy caused Dr Cooper to keep working, without salary, as funding finished in June and the $20,000 was not given until September. She has now obtained a one-off grant from the South Australian wheat and barley committees to continue her work until 1 July 1989.

She is one of a number of scientists who have been involved in research programs on triticale. I certainly commend the work that she has put into this new industry. I trust that the funds which will be disbursed under this collection and the Government's support will be available for her in the sense that she will be able to put up a program which will be worthy of support on behalf of the industry.

The industry, I am told, in 1986-87 grew 220,000 tonnes on 140,000 hectares and that 60 per cent of this was grown in New South Wales. However, the industry is spread in smaller amounts: in Western Australia, 16 per cent; Victoria, 9 per cent; South Australia, 7 per cent, as I have already indicated; Queensland, 5 per cent; and Tasmania, 3 per cent. Therefore, although it is a specialist line of cereal, it is spread across Australia. No doubt it will remain a minor component of the cereals grown in Australia. We are well aware, as in all productive activities, that there are specialist areas which can use specialist plant varieties. I am sure that triticale will fulfil that role.

It is interesting to read that the first serious research into triticale began in Manitoba when the Seagram family was interested in a new flavour, so I am told, for its whiskey. I do not know whether it was successful but certainly the research has lead to a new cereal variety. I commend the triticale levy research Bills and trust that the Waite research program will be supported by them.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I wish briefly to comment on some of the points made by honourable members. I particularly thank the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) for his very informative words on triticale. I want particularly to talk about the wheat Bills, part of this package being debated cognately. This legislation relates to the Commonwealth part of the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport recommendations. As we all know, these matters are mainly the responsibility of State governments.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to realise that since the McColl report came down, and since I announced various Government moves on wheat marketing in general, we have had a Green Paper from Queensland which indicates that Queensland will take some steps with respect to its wheat marketing. The New South Wales Government has implemented, or is in process of implementing, much of the McColl recommendations, which is very welcome. The Australian Wheat Board is doing a range of things that I believe it could have done before, and even the Grains Council of Australia is also moving and making various suggestions. This makes the point that a little pressure every now and then gets things moving.

I would point to the hotel analogy mentioned by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). If one protects industries too much with regulations, they do not change and other things take over. The in-principle part of the wheat package which will be debated in the autumn session is to get continuing savings, general economy-wide efficiency and also to look to the future when we will have more and more a livestock-grain sector rather than a traditional wheat-sheep belt.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd) made several points about reform in other areas. He said that this one was being done pretty abruptly but that in other areas the Government was being tardy. I am sure that he would accept that there are many areas where one just cannot get synchronisation of every reform at once. He instanced transport, waterfront, shipping and airlines. In respect of airlines, there is quite an amount of deregulation policy in place. As to shipping, the maritime unions have moved an enormous way, and much credit should go to the present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris). I would point to the fact that Mrs Thatcher is just introducing cabotage on the English coast, and there are only two countries in the world which have done away with it I refer to the Netherlands and Belgium, which do not have a big coastal shipping problem. The waterfront package is being addressed by the Government. Decisions have been taken, so we are moving.

In regard to road funding, I would relate that back to the general thrust of wheat marketing reform in this Bill. It is aimed at providing a competitive spur. At the end of the day the traditional system will be used, but I think it will be used more efficiently. The problem is that we have about $45m tonnes of storage, and there is probably a lot that we do not need. The means are available for designation for road funding and specific assistance to national arterial roads. I think that we will see that coming into better and better shape.

I will respond on the question of $2.50 mentioned by the Deputy Leader of the National Party. SPEECH.PARA: The Government is restructuring the Australian economy and it has put in place a 30 per cent tariff cut, which is worth between $350m and $400m in savings on costs to the farm sector; so it is not as if there is no quid pro quo. The honourable member asked me about high technology and research. A lot of it is in wool, a lot of it is in primary industries, and a lot of it is in wool textile production areas; it is in those areas that a lot of high technology is being put into place.

It is important that the Government gets that message through to those who are not so wise in this matter. There is a lot of high technology research in our primary industries. The honourable member for Maranoa talked about all the rallies that had occurred. Recently I saw a poll which showed that 41 per cent of wheat farmers support me. I do not know where I have gone wrong! I am used to 3 per cent or 6 per cent support. I am a bit worried about that.

The growers do own the wheat; that is quite true. There is a big public investment in wheat, and that is through underwriting and the national interest cover. The honourable member for Maranoa said that Queensland growers own $80m. I will just say that the McColl recommendations showed where savings could be made. If any State wishes to do what I think the Queensland Government will do, which is not to put itself in a position to pass on those savings to wheat farmers then so be it.
